Rava replied: <b>Actually,</b> my ruling is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that one is suspected only about those items that are related to the prohibition in question. <b>And we are</b> in fact <b>penalizing him with regard to</b> items related to <b>the prohibition itself.</b> How so? <b>Ordinary children are enticed by nuts, and</b> that individual <b>went and misled the children of butchers and enticed them with nuts, and they brought him fat of the</b> kidney that is adjacent to the <b>thigh, and he sold it as</b> though it were <b>fat of the intestines.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who is suspect with regard to the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>is not suspect with regard to tithes;</b> and likewise, <b>one who is suspect with regard to tithes is not suspect with regard to the Sabbatical</b> Year. <b>One who is suspect with regard to this,</b> the Sabbatical Year, <b>or with regard to that,</b> tithes, is <b>suspect with regard to</b> selling ritually impure foods as though they were <b>ritually pure</b> items. <b>But there are those who are suspect with regard to ritually pure</b> items <b>who are not suspect with regard to this,</b> the Sabbatical Year, <b>nor with regard to that,</b> tithes. <b>This is the principle</b> with regard to these matters: Anyone <b>who is suspect with regard to</b> a specific <b>matter</b> may <b>neither adjudicate</b> cases <b>nor testify</b> in cases involving that matter.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that one who is suspect with regard to the Sabbatical Year is not suspect with regard to tithes. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason?</b> One is <b>not required</b> to eat produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year within the <b>wall</b> of Jerusalem, and therefore he treats it lightly. As for second <b>tithe, since</b> one is <b>required</b> to eat it only within the <b>wall</b> of Jerusalem, it is possible that it seems more <b>stringent for him,</b> and therefore he is not suspect, despite the suspicions with regard to produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year.
The mishna teaches: <b>One who is suspect with regard to tithe</b> is not suspect with regard to the Sabbatical Year. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason?</b> The Gemara answers: Since <b>there is redemption</b> for <b>tithes,</b> one might treat them lightly. As for produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>since it is</b> always <b>prohibited to him and there is no redemption</b> of it, it is possible that it seems more <b>stringent for him,</b> and therefore he is not suspect.
The mishna teaches: <b>One who is suspect with regard to this,</b> the Sabbatical Year, <b>or with regard to that,</b> tithes, is suspect with regard to selling ritually impure foods as though they were ritually pure items. The Gemara explains: <b>Since he is suspect</b> with regard to matters that apply <b>by Torah law, all the more so that he</b> is suspect with regard to matters that are <b>by rabbinic law.</b> Eating non-sacred food in a state of ritual purity is an ordinance of the Sages; it does not apply by Torah law. Consequently, he is certainly not trusted with regard to that matter.
The mishna teaches: <b>But there are those who are suspect with regard to ritually pure</b> items who are not suspect with regard to this, the Sabbatical Year, or with regard to that, tithes. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason? Granted,</b> he is <b>suspect</b> with regard to prohibitions that are <b>by rabbinic law,</b> but <b>he is not suspect</b> with regard to prohibitions that are <b>by Torah law. And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If one is <b>trusted with regard to ritually pure</b> items he is <b>trusted with regard to</b> produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year. It can be inferred from here that if he is <b>suspect</b> with regard to ritually pure items he is likewise <b>suspect</b> with regard to produce of the Sabbatical Year.
<b>Rabbi Ilai says: The mishna</b> is referring to a case <b>where they saw him practicing</b> stringencies with regard to produce of the Sabbatical Year and tithes <b>privately, within his home.</b> Since he himself is known to be trustworthy in these matters in private, he is not suspected of violating these prohibitions in his business, despite his lack of trustworthiness with regard to ritual purity.
<b>Rabbi Yannai, son of Rabbi Yishmael, said</b> that there is an alternative answer: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where one was suspect with regard to both</b> ritually pure items and produce of the Sabbatical Year, <b>and he came before the Sages and accepted</b> upon himself <b>that</b> he would observe <b>both of them, and afterward he was suspected with regard to one of them.</b> The reason for the <i>halakha</i> here is <b>that we say: Since he is suspect with regard to this</b> one of them, <b>he is also suspect with regard to the other</b> one. Although one of the prohibitions is more stringent than the other, the court has seen that he cannot be trusted to keep his word about either of them.
§ The mishna teaches: One who is suspect with regard to the Sabbatical Year is not suspect with regard to tithes. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This is the statement of Rabbi Akiva, the unattributed.</b> Most unattributed statements of <i>tanna’im</i> were formulated by Rabbi Akiva’s students and reflect his opinions. <b>But the Rabbis say:</b> One who is <b>suspect with regard to</b> produce of <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>is suspect with regard to tithe.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> are the Sages referred to here as <b>the Rabbis?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as in Rabbi Yehuda’s locale they</b> considered produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year an especially <b>stringent</b> prohibition. Therefore, if a resident of that place was suspect with regard to the Sabbatical Year, he was certainly not trusted with regard to tithes. <b>As</b> in that locale, if <b>a certain</b> person <b>would call another: A convert, son of</b> a female <b>convert,</b> wishing to insult him, that person would <b>say to him</b> in reply: <b>I have</b> a blessing <b>coming to me, as I do not eat produce of the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>like you</b> do. This indicates that the accusation of eating produce of the Sabbatical Year was a great insult, since they treated the Sabbatical Year stringently.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This is the statement of Rabbi Akiva, the unattributed. But the Rabbis say:</b> One who is <b>suspect with regard to tithe is suspect with regard to</b> produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year. <b>And who</b> are the Sages referred to here as <b>the Rabbis? It is Rabbi Meir, who says:</b> One who is <b>suspect with regard to one matter is suspect with regard to the entire Torah.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yona and Rabbi Yirmeya,</b> who were <b>students of Rabbi Zeira,</b> disagreed about this matter. <b>And some say</b> that it was <b>Rabbi Yona and Rabbi Zeira, students of Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who disagreed. <b>One said: But the Rabbis say</b> that one who is <b>suspect with regard to</b> produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year

Daf 30b

is <b>suspect with regard to tithe. And who</b> are the Sages referred to here as <b>the Rabbis?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as in his locale they treated the prohibition of produce of the Sabbatical Year stringently. <b>And</b> the other <b>one says: One who is suspect with regard to tithe is suspect with regard to</b> produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year. <b>And who</b> are the Sages referred to here as <b>the Rabbis?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Demai</i> 2:4): With regard to <b>an <i>am ha’aretz</i>,</b> i.e., one who is unreliable with regard to ritual impurity and tithes, <b>who accepts upon himself</b> the commitment to observe <b>the matters</b> associated with <b><i>ḥaver</i> status,</b> i.e., that he will be stringent in all matters observed by <i>ḥaverim</i>, including <i>teruma</i>, tithes, and <i>ḥalla</i>, and also undertake to eat only food that is ritually pure, and the Sages accepted him as trustworthy <b>but</b> subsequently he <b>was suspected with regard to one matter</b> in which others saw him act improperly, <b>he is suspected with regard to the entire Torah.</b> This is the <b>statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: He is suspected only with regard to that particular matter.</b>
It is also taught in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Demai</i> 2:4): With regard to <b>a convert who accepted upon himself</b> upon his conversion <b>matters of Torah,</b> i.e., all of the mitzvot, <b>even if he is suspect with regard to one matter</b> alone, <b>he is suspect with regard to the entire Torah, and he is</b> considered <b>like a Jewish transgressor [<i>meshummad</i>],</b> who habitually transgresses the mitzvot. The Gemara explains that the practical <b>difference</b> resulting from the fact that he is considered like a Jewish transgressor is <b>that if he betroths</b> a woman, <b>his betrothal is</b> a valid <b>betrothal,</b> and they are married. Although he is suspect with regard to the entire Torah, he does not return to his prior gentile status.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who comes to accept upon himself</b> the commitment to observe <b>the matters</b> associated with <b><i>ḥaver</i> status except for one matter,</b> which he does not wish to observe, <b>he is not accepted,</b> and he is not trustworthy even with regard to those matters that he does wish to accept upon himself. Likewise, in the case of <b>a gentile who comes to</b> convert and takes upon himself to <b>accept the words of Torah except for one matter, he is not accepted</b> as a convert. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: Even</b> if he refuses to accept <b>one detail of rabbinic law,</b> he is not accepted.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And similarly,</b> in the case of <b>a Levite who comes to accept the matters of a Levite, or a priest who comes to accept the matters of priesthood, except for one matter, he is not accepted. As it is stated:</b> “He among the sons of Aaron, <b>that sacrifices the blood of the peace offerings,</b> and the fat, shall have the right thigh for a portion” (Leviticus 7:33). This means that with regard to <b>the</b> Temple <b>service, which is handed</b> over <b>to the sons of Aaron, any priest who does not admit to it</b> in its entirety <b>has no share in the priesthood.</b>
The Gemara continues on a similar topic. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who comes to accept upon himself</b> a commitment to observe <b>the matters</b> associated with <b><i>ḥaver</i> status, if we have seen that he practices</b> such matters <b>in private, within his home, he is accepted, and afterward he is taught</b> the precise details of being a <i>ḥaver</i>. <b>But if</b> we have <b>not</b> seen him act as a <i>ḥaver</i> in his home, <b>he is taught</b> first <b>and afterward accepted. Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: Whether</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>or that</b> case, <b>he is</b> first <b>accepted, and he</b> then <b>continues to learn in</b> the <b>usual manner,</b> i.e., as a <i>ḥaver</i> he learns from others how to behave.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: An <i>am ha’aretz</i> who wishes to become a <i>ḥaver</i> <b>is accepted</b> first <b>with regard to hands,</b> i.e., he is presumed to be stringent concerning the ritual purity of his hands by making sure to wash his hands before handling pure items, <b>and afterward he is accepted</b> as trustworthy <b>for purity</b> in general. <b>And if he says: I</b> wish to <b>accept</b> purity <b>only with regard to hands, he is accepted</b> for this. If he wishes to <b>accept</b> upon himself the stringencies of a <i>ḥaver</i> <b>with regard to ritual purity but he does not accept</b> upon himself the stringencies <b>with regard to hands,</b> i.e., to wash his hands, which is a simple act, <b>he is not accepted even for purity</b> in general.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Until when is he accepted,</b> i.e., how much time must elapse before he is considered trustworthy as a <i>ḥaver</i>? <b>Beit Shammai say: With regard to liquids, thirty days. With regard to</b> impurity of <b>clothing,</b> about which <i>ḥaverim</i> would be careful as well, <b>twelve months. And Beit Hillel say: Both</b> with regard to <b>this,</b> liquids, <b>and that,</b> clothing, he must maintain the practice <b>for twelve months</b> before he is fully accepted as a <i>ḥaver</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, this is</b> one <b>of</b> the rare cases of <b>the leniencies of Beit Shammai and of the stringencies of Beit Hillel,</b> and yet it is not included in tractate <i>Eduyyot</i>, which lists all of the cases where Beit Shammai are more lenient than Beit Hillel. <b>Rather,</b> the text of the <i>baraita</i> must be emended so that it reads: <b>Beit Hillel say: Both</b> with regard to <b>this,</b> liquids <b>and that,</b> clothing, he must maintain the practice <b>for thirty</b> days before he is fully accepted as a <i>ḥaver</i>.
§ The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> to remember the topics from here until the end of the chapter: <b><i>Ḥaver</i>; student; sky-blue dye [<i>tekhelet</i>]; tax; return;</b> tax <b>collector; by himself.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who comes to accept upon himself</b> a commitment to observe <b>the matters</b> associated with <b><i>ḥaver</i> status must accept</b> it <b>in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>. But his children and</b> the <b>members of his household are not required to accept</b> the status of <i>ḥaver</i> separately <b>in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even his children and</b> the <b>members of his household must accept</b> the status of <i>ḥaver</i> <b>in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>, because a <i>ḥaver</i>, who accepted it</b> himself in the presence of three others, <b>is not comparable to the son of a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> who <b>accepted</b> that status only due to his father but did not accept it himself explicitly, and their accepting the status not in the presence of three people is insufficient.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who comes to accept upon himself</b> a commitment to observe <b>the matters</b> associated with <b><i>ḥaver</i> status must accept</b> it <b>in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>, and even a Torah scholar</b> who wishes to become a <i>ḥaver</i> <b>must accept</b> the status of <i>ḥaver</i> <b>in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>.</b> But <b>an elder who sits</b> and studies Torah <b>in a yeshiva is not required to accept</b> the status of <i>ḥaver</i> <b>in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>, as he already accepted it upon himself from the moment he sat</b> and dedicated himself to study Torah in yeshiva. <b>Abba Shaul says: Even a Torah scholar is not required to accept</b> the status of <i>ḥaver</i> <b>in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>; and not only</b> does he have the status of <i>ḥaver</i> without an explicit declaration in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>, <b>but others</b> can <b>accept</b> that they wish to become a <i>ḥaver</i> <b>in his presence.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This mishna,</b> i.e., the ruling that a Torah scholar must declare his intent to become a <i>ḥaver</i> in the presence of three <i>ḥaverim</i>, <b>was taught in the days of the son of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus.</b> At that time, <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei were uncertain about</b> a certain <b>matter of ritual purity. The Sages sent</b> a delegation of their students <b>to the son of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus</b> and told them to <b>go</b> and <b>tell him to examine</b> this matter. The students <b>found him while he was carrying</b> items that were ritually <b>pure.</b> The son of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus <b>seated Sages from his own</b> yeshiva <b>next to</b> the students who came to ask the question, because he did not trust these students to keep his items pure. <b>And he stood and examined</b> the matter.
The students returned and <b>came and told Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei</b> that the son of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus had treated them as though they had the status of <i>amei ha’aretz</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said to them</b> in anger: <b>This one’s father,</b> i.e., Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus, <b>degraded Torah scholars</b> by not trusting them with matters of ritual purity. And <b>he too,</b> the son of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus, <b>degrades Torah scholars.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei said to him: Let the honor of the elder,</b> i.e., both the father and son, <b>be left in its place.</b> He did not act in this manner to degrade Torah scholars. <b>Rather, from the day the Temple was destroyed, the priests were accustomed to act with a higher standard for themselves,</b> and they decided <b>that they will not pass ritually pure</b> items <b>to any</b> other <b>person.</b> Therefore, the son of Rabbi Ḥanina, as a priest, acted appropriately.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a <i>ḥaver</i> that died, his wife and children and members of his household retain their presumptive</b> status <b>until they are suspected</b> of engaging in inappropriate deeds. <b>And similarly,</b> in the case of <b>a courtyard in which one sells sky-blue dye, it retains its presumptive</b> status as a place in which fit sky-blue dye is sold <b>until it is disqualified</b> due to the merchant’s unscrupulous behavior.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The</b> former <b>wife an <i>am ha’aretz</i> who</b> later <b>marries a <i>ḥaver</i>, and likewise the daughter of an <i>am ha’aretz</i> who marries a <i>ḥaver</i>, and likewise the slave of an <i>am ha’aretz</i> who is sold to a <i>ḥaver</i>, must all accept</b> upon themselves a commitment to observe <b>the matters</b> associated with <b><i>ḥaver</i> status. But</b> with regard to <b>the</b> former <b>wife of a <i>ḥaver</i> who</b> later <b>marries an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, and likewise the daughter of a <i>ḥaver</i> who marries an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, and likewise the slave of a <i>ḥaver</i> who was sold to an <i>am ha’aretz</i>,</b> these people <b>need not accept</b> upon themselves a commitment to observe <b>the matters</b> associated with <b><i>ḥaver</i> status <i>ab initio</i>,</b> as each of them is already accustomed to behave as a <i>ḥaver</i>.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Meir says: They too must accept</b> upon themselves a commitment to observe <b>the matters</b> associated with <b><i>ḥaver</i> status <i>ab initio</i>. And similarly, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar would</b> illustrate this point and <b>say in the name of Rabbi Meir:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a certain woman who married a <i>ḥaver</i> and would tie [<i>koma’at</i>] for him phylacteries on his hand,</b> and she later <b>married a tax collector and would tie for him tax seals on his hand,</b> which shows that her new husband had a great influence on her level of piety.

Daf 31a

With regard to an <i>am ha’aretz</i> who accepts upon himself the stringent practices of a <i>ḥaver</i>, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of them, when they retract</b> and return to being <i>amei ha’aretz</i>, <b>they are never accepted</b> as <i>ḥaverim</i>; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If <b>they retracted in private,</b> while in public they continue to act as <i>ḥaverim</i>, <b>they are not accepted,</b> but if they retract <b>in public [<i>befarheseya</i>], they are accepted,</b> as they can be trusted.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> another version of this discussion: If <b>they performed their actions</b> as <i>ḥaverim</i> even <b>in private,</b> when they initially accepted the status of <i>ḥaverim</i>, then <b>they are accepted</b> when they wish to return to that status. Conversely, if they performed their actions as <i>ḥaverim</i> only <b>in public, they are not accepted.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa say: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>they are accepted, as it is stated: “Return, you backsliding children;</b> I will heal your backslidings” (Jeremiah 3:22). <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak of the village of Akko says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that pair,</b> Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa, i.e., those who return are accepted in both cases.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Initially,</b> the Sages <b>would say</b> with regard to one who is <b>a <i>ḥaver</i> and became</b> a tax <b>collector</b> that <b>he is rejected from his</b> status as <b>a <i>ḥaver</i>.</b> Even if he later <b>resigns</b> from his position as a tax collector, <b>he is not accepted.</b> In later generations <b>they went back to saying</b> that if <b>he resigns</b> from his position as a tax collector <b>he is like any other person</b> and may be accepted once again as a <i>ḥaver</i>.
The Gemara relates that one <b>time</b> the Sages <b>needed Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya</b> for a certain matter. <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef and four hundred pairs of Sages ascended to his</b> home. When <b>he heard that they were coming,</b> he <b>tied</b> for <b>them four hundred chairs [<i>takhtekei</i>]</b> to sit on. <b>Eventually</b> the Sages <b>heard that he had become</b> a tax <b>collector. They sent him</b> the following message: <b>Go to your</b> important position as a tax collector, and <b>go to your former</b> status, as we no longer need you. <b>He sent to them</b> the following message: <b>I have repented</b> and am no longer a tax collector. <b>Rav Yosef did not go</b> to him, but <b>Rabba went</b> to him.
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> in explanation of why he did not go: <b>We learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that even if such an individual <b>resigns</b> from his position as a tax collector <b>he is not accepted. Rabba said: We learn</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that in later generations <b>they went back to saying</b> that if <b>he resigns</b> from his position as a tax collector <b>he is like any other person</b> and may be accepted once again as a <i>ḥaver</i>.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person may inspect all firstborns</b> for blemishes <b>except for his own</b> firstborns, as he has a vested interest. <b>And</b> despite his vested interest in these cases, one may <b>inspect his own sanctified animals</b> that he consecrated for the Temple, to determine whether they have blemishes and may be redeemed; <b>and</b> he may inspect <b>his</b> animal <b>tithes</b> to decide whether they are fit for sacrifice in the Temple; <b>and</b> one <b>may ask</b> himself <b>with regard to his ritually pure</b> foods, i.e., he may decide for himself whether or not they have become impure, and he is not suspected of claiming that impure food is actually pure.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said: A person may inspect all firstborns except for his own</b> firstborns. <b>What are we dealing with</b> here? <b>If we say</b> that we are dealing with a case <b>of one</b> person examining a blemish, <b>is he trusted</b> by himself to deem any firstborn animal permitted for slaughter? The mishna on 36b states that only three people may permit a firstborn animal to be slaughtered. <b>Rather,</b> it must be dealing with one <b>of three</b> who jointly decide the status of the firstborn animal. <b>And is he suspect</b> in such a case? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Yevamot</i> 25b): A judge before whom a woman <b>performed refusal</b> when she was a minor, by declaring that she did not desire the husband chosen for her by her family, <b>or before whom she performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, may marry her,because</b> he was only one member of <b>the court,</b> and therefore there is no suspicion of conflict of interest?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> we are dealing with a case <b>of a single</b> judge, <b>and</b> this is <b>as Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> with regard to a different matter: Vows may be dissolved even <b>by a single expert,</b> and a three-member court is not always necessary. <b>Here too,</b> we are dealing <b>with a single expert</b> who deems the firstborn animal permitted. A single expert may rule with regard to the firstborn animals belonging to others, but not his own animals, due to his vested interest.
The Gemara analyzes the last section of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>And</b> despite his vested interest, one may <b>inspect his own sanctified animals.</b> Why is it permitted for him to inspect them? The reason is <b>that if he wants</b> to avoid giving the animal to the Temple, he can <b>issue a request</b> from a halakhic authority to annul his oath. Consequently, he does not truly have a vested interest.
The <i>baraita</i> also teaches: <b>And</b> he may rule with regard to <b>his</b> own animal <b>tithes</b> to decide whether they are fit to be sacrificed in the Temple. The Gemara explains that the reason is <b>that if he wants</b> to avoid bringing the animals as offerings, he can <b>inflict a blemish upon his entire herd</b> before separating the tithe, which would render them all unfit for sacrifice in the Temple.
Finally, the <i>baraita</i> states: <b>And</b> one <b>may ask</b> himself <b>with regard to his ritually pure</b> foods, i.e., he may decide for himself whether or not they have become impure, and he is not suspected of claiming that impure food is actually pure. The Gemara explains that his vested interested in this case is not so great, <b>as</b> the food <b>is fit for him</b> to eat <b>in his days of impurity.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>all disqualified consecrated</b> animals that were disqualified for sacrifice due to blemishes and were redeemed, all <b>benefit</b> accrued from <b>their</b> sale belongs <b>to the Temple</b> treasury. In order to ensure that the Temple treasury will not suffer a loss, these animals <b>are sold in the butchers’ market [<i>ba’itliz</i>] and slaughtered in the butchers’ market,</b> where the demand is great and the price is consequently higher. <b>And</b> their meat <b>is weighed</b> and sold <b>by the <i>litra</i>,</b> in the manner that non-sacred meat is sold.
This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all consecrated animals <b>except for the firstborn</b> offering <b>and</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering. When these become blemished and their slaughter is permitted, they are sold and slaughtered only in the owner’s house and are not weighed; rather, they are sold by estimate. The reason is <b>that</b> all <b>benefit</b> accrued from <b>their</b> sale belongs <b>to the owner,</b> i.e., the priest in the case of the firstborn and the owner in the case of the animal tithe offering. It is not permitted to treat disqualified consecrated animals as one treats non-sacred animals merely to guarantee that the owner will receive the optimal price. This is in contrast to <b>disqualified consecrated</b> animals, where all <b>benefit</b> accrued from <b>their</b> sale belongs <b>to the Temple</b> treasury, and therefore the animal is sold in the market to ensure that the optimal price is received.
<b>And</b> although the meat of the firstborn is not weighed and sold by the <i>litra</i>, nevertheless, if one has non-sacred meat weighing one hundred dinars, <b>one may weigh one portion</b> of non-sacred meat <b>against one portion</b> of the meat <b>of the firstborn,</b> because that is unlike the manner in which non-sacred meat is weighed.

Daf 31b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that with regard to <b>all disqualified consecrated</b> animals that were disqualified for sacrifice due to blemishes and were redeemed, all <b>benefit</b> accrued from <b>their</b> sale belongs <b>to the Temple</b> treasury, and the animals may consequently be sold in the manner of non-sacred meat. The Gemara asks: <b>When</b> does this apply? <b>If we say</b> that it applies to an animal <b>after its redemption,</b> i.e., after the owner redeemed it from the Temple treasury, does the <b>benefit</b> accrued belong <b>to the Temple?</b> Certainly not. Once a consecrated animal is redeemed from the Temple treasury, it is in the possession of its owner, which means that the <b>benefit</b> accrued belongs <b>to the owner.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it applies to an animal <b>before its redemption,</b> in which case the money accrued from its sale, which renders it non-sacred, belongs to the Temple treasury. But if so, the mishna’s statement that the animals <b>may be slaughtered</b> in the butchers’ market is problematic. The Gemara explains the difficulty: How can the animal be evaluated after having been slaughtered? Redeeming a sanctified animal <b>requires standing and valuation,</b> i.e., it has to be set standing before a priest for him to appraise its monetary value and only then is it redeemed (see Leviticus 27:11–12).
The Gemara adds: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that items <b>consecrated</b> to be sacrificed on the <b>altar</b> that were then disqualified due to a blemish <b>were not included in</b> the requirement of <b>standing and valuation.</b> If so, the animal may be slaughtered and subsequently sold. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that items consecrated to be sacrificed on the <b>altar were included in</b> the requirement of <b>standing and valuation, what is there to say</b> in explanation of the mishna?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> the ruling of the mishna <b>actually</b> applies to a case where the animals are sold and slaughtered <b>after their redemption</b> by the owner. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the mishna’s statement that all <b>benefit</b> accrued from <b>their</b> sale belongs <b>to the Temple</b> treasury? This is not referring to the profit from the sale in the butchers’ market, as was previously assumed. Instead, it is referring <b>to</b> their <b>initial</b> redemption from the Temple treasury.
The Gemara explains: <b>Since the Sage</b> in the mishna <b>deems</b> it <b>permitted</b> for the redeemed animals to be subsequently <b>sold in the butchers’ market and slaughtered in the butchers’ market, and weighed</b> and sold <b>by the <i>litra</i>,</b> there is a higher probability that the owner will <b>redeem</b> the animal for <b>more</b> money <b>initially.</b> The owner’s later ability to sell the redeemed animal for the highest market value is in effect a benefit that eventually accrues to the Temple treasury, as he will be willing to spend more money to redeem the animal.
§ The mishna teaches that the meat of blemished, consecrated animals may be sold in the same manner as non-sacred meat, <b>except for the firstborn</b> animal <b>and</b> animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>as</b> all <b>benefit</b> accrued from <b>their</b> sale belongs <b>to the owner.</b> Accordingly, even if it is blemished, the meat may be sold only in the owner’s house. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> in the case of <b>a firstborn</b> offering, <b>it is in the butchers’ market that it may not be sold,</b> whereas <b>it may be sold in its</b> owner’s <b>house. But</b> with regard to the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>may it be sold in its</b> owner’s <b>house?</b>
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to a firstborn</b> animal it <b>is stated: “You shall not redeem”</b> (Numbers 18:17), indicating that its sanctity can never be removed from it and transferred to non-sacred objects. <b>But it can be sold</b> after it comes into the possession of the priest, while it is <b>alive.</b> By contrast, <b>with regard to</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, it <b>is stated: “It shall not be redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:33), which teaches that its sanctity can never be removed from it, <b>and it cannot be sold</b> either, as the Gemara will explain (32a–b), <b>not</b> when <b>alive and not</b> when <b>slaughtered, not</b> when <b>unblemished and not</b> when <b>blemished.</b> This <i>baraita</i> clearly states that the animal tithe offering may not be sold no matter what its status, which seems to contradict the mishna.
The Gemara notes: <b>At night, Rav Sheshet found this matter difficult, and he resolved it in the morning from a <i>baraita</i>.</b> He explains that in the mishna <b>we are dealing with</b> a case of <b>an animal tithe</b> offering <b>belonging to</b> young <b>orphans</b> that was blemished and slaughtered. Since the orphans are unable to consume the entire animal and would therefore suffer a monetary loss if the meat were to spoil, the Sages permitted its sale, <b>and</b> it is <b>due to</b> the principle of <b>returning a lost item</b> that <b>they touched upon it,</b> i.e., allowed for this.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Idi, the attendant [<i>saraseih</i>] of Rav Sheshet, heard</b> this explanation <b>from</b> Rav Sheshet. Rav Idi <b>went and stated</b> the matter <b>in the study hall, but did not say it in his</b> master’s <b>name. Rav Sheshet heard</b> what he had done and <b>was annoyed.</b> Rav Sheshet <b>said: The one who stung me, let him be stung by a scorpion.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rav Sheshet, what difference does it make to him</b> whether or not his interpretation was cited in his name? The Gemara answers that this is <b>as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “I will dwell in Your tent forever [<i>olamim</i>]”</b> (Psalms 61:5)? Rav asked: <b>But is it possible for a person to live in two worlds [<i>olamim</i>],</b> this world and the next, simultaneously?
<b>Rather, David,</b> who recited this psalm, <b>said</b> to God: <b>Master of the Universe, let</b> people <b>say a matter of <i>halakha</i> in my name in this world</b> after I have passed on to another world. <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai:</b> With regard to <b>any Torah scholar in whose name a matter of <i>halakha</i> is stated in this world, his lips mouth</b> the words <b>in the grave,</b> as though he were speaking.
<b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Ze’eiri says: What is the verse</b> from which this is derived? The verse states: <b>“And the roof of your mouth is like the best wine that glides down smoothly for my beloved, moving gently the lips of those who are asleep”</b> (Song of Songs 7:10). Here, words of Torah in the mouths of the Jewish people are likened <b>to a pile [<i>kekhomer</i>] of grapes</b> left to warm before they are pressed, which causes the wine to exude from them easily: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a pile of grapes, when a person</b> places his finger on it and <b>touches it, it moves</b> and issues a sound as the wine bursts forth, <b>so too</b> with regard to <b>Torah scholars, when a matter of <i>halakha</i> is stated in their name, their lips mouth</b> the words <b>in the grave.</b>
The Gemara returns to Rav Sheshet’s explanation: <b>What</b> is the <b><i>baraita</i></b> mentioned by Rav Sheshet, upon which he based his resolution? The Gemara explains: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>an animal tithe</b> offering <b>of</b> young <b>orphans, one may sell it. And</b> with regard to <b>an animal tithe</b> offering <b>that one has slaughtered,</b> whose meat may not be sold, <b>one may include</b> the cost of the meat <b>in</b> the cost of its negligent parts, thereby inflating the cost of those parts, i.e., the animal’s <b>hide, its fat, its sinews, and its horns,</b> which are permitted to be sold.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying?</b> Initially, the <i>baraita</i> stated that one may sell the meat of an animal tithe offering belonging to young orphans, which indicates that this may be done in the normal fashion. The <i>baraita</i> then proceeds to state that the sale of the meat must be performed in the indirect manner of inclusion. <b>Abaye said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is actually referring to only one case, and <b>this</b> is what it <b>is saying:</b> With regard to the meat of <b>an animal tithe</b> offering <b>of</b> young <b>orphans, it may be sold,</b> but only <b>by</b> means of <b>inclusion.</b>
The Gemara states: One can conclude <b>by inference</b> from this <i>baraita</i> <b>that</b> in the case of an animal tithe offering of <b>an adult,</b> i.e., a non-orphan, its meat may <b>not</b> be sold even <b>by</b> means of <b>inclusion. What is different</b> in this case <b>from that which is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Sukka</i> 3:11): In the case of <b>one who purchases a <i>lulav</i> from another,</b> who is an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, <b>during the Sabbatical</b> Year, the seller <b>gives him an <i>etrog</i></b> together with the <i>lulav</i> <b>as a gift, as it is not permitted for one to purchase</b> the <i>etrog</i> <b>during the Sabbatical</b> Year, and one may not give the value of Sabbatical-Year produce to an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, lest he engage in commerce with it, which is prohibited.
The Gemara continues: <b>And we discussed this</b> mishna and asked: If the seller <b>did not want to give him</b> the <i>etrog</i> <b>as a gift, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? How can the buyer receive the <i>etrog</i>? <b>And Rav Huna said:</b> The seller <b>includes the value of the <i>etrog</i> in</b> the cost of <b>the <i>lulav</i>.</b> The buyer should purchase the <i>lulav</i> at an elevated price to cover the cost of the <i>etrog</i> as well. If inclusion is allowed in the case of the <i>etrog</i>, why would it not be permitted in the case of the meat of an animal tithe offering belonging to an adult?
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of the <i>etrog</i>, <b>the matter is not evident,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> with regard to the meat of an animal tithe offering, <b>the matter is evident.</b> The inclusion of the cost of the <i>etrog</i> in the elevated cost of the <i>lulav</i> is not evident, as it is reasonable that the price of a <i>lulav</i> might fluctuate. By contrast, inflating the cost of the negligible parts of the animal tithe offering to include the cost of its expensive meat is obviously an artifice and is therefore not permitted.
<b>Rava said</b> to Abaye in response: <b>If so,</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to only one case, <b>why do I</b> need it to use the expression: <b>Animal tithe</b> offering, <b>twice? Rather, Rava said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing two distinct cases, and <b>this</b> is what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying:</b> With regard to the meat of <b>an animal tithe</b> offering <b>of</b> young <b>orphans, one may sell it in its</b> usual <b>manner, but</b> in the case of <b>an animal tithe</b> offering <b>belonging to an adult that was slaughtered,</b> one may sell its meat only by means of <b>including its</b> cost <b>in</b> the elevated price of the animal’s <b>hide, its fat, its sinews, and its horns.</b>
<b>Rava said: From where do I say</b> that the meat of an animal tithe offering belonging to an adult may be sold by inclusion? <b>As it is written</b> with regard to the animal tithe offering: <b>“Then both it and that for which it is substituted shall be holy; it shall not be redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:33). This indicates that a non-sacred animal designated as a substitute for an animal tithe offering assumes sacred status, while the animal tithe offering retains its sacred status as well. As stated earlier, the phrase “it shall not be redeemed” is interpreted as referring to the prohibition against selling the animal tithe offering. The verse’s juxtaposition of substitution and the prohibition against selling an animal tithe offering indicates a similarity between the two.
Rava explains: <b>When</b> does an animal tithe offering <b>render</b> consecrated as <b>a substitute</b> a non-sacred animal for which it is exchanged? Only <b>when</b> the animal tithe offering is <b>alive,</b> as substitution is invalid after its death. Similarly, <b>when may</b> the animal tithe offering <b>not be redeemed,</b> i.e., sold? <b>When</b> it is <b>alive.</b> It may be inferred from here that <b>it may be redeemed,</b> i.e., sold, <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter.</b> This teaches that by Torah law, the meat of an animal tithe offering may be sold once the animal has been slaughtered. <b>The Sages decreed</b> that an animal tithe offering may not be sold <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter, due to</b> the concern that one might sell it <b>before</b> its <b>slaughter.</b>
Rava continues: It was only with regard to <b>an item that is appraised when</b> the animal is <b>alive,</b> i.e., its meat, which gives the animal its primary value, that <b>the Sages decreed</b> that it may not be sold even <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter, due to</b> the concern that one might sell the animal <b>before</b> its <b>slaughter.</b>

Daf 32a

But with regard to <b>an item that is not appraised</b> when an animal is sold <b>when alive,</b> e.g., the hide and sinews, as these are not primary contributing factors to the animal’s value, <b>the Sages did not decree</b> that one may not sell such items after the animal’s slaughter. Consequently, the meat of an animal tithe offering may be sold by means of inclusion in the animal’s hide, fat, sinews, and horns. <b>And with regard to</b> a case of young <b>orphans, the Sages established</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>as</b> if <b>by Torah law,</b> and therefore the meat may be sold in its usual manner.
The Gemara notes: <b>And even Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak holds</b> in accordance with <b>that</b> opinion <b>of Rava,</b> that by Torah law, the meat of a blemished animal-tithe offering may be sold in the normal manner. <b>As Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one may sell</b> the meat of a blemished <b>animal-tithe</b> offering <b>of</b> young <b>orphans in its</b> usual <b>manner,</b> without having to resort to the method of inclusion?
It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated</b> in a verse discussing consecrated animals that became blemished: <b>“Notwithstanding, after all the desire of your soul, you may slaughter and eat flesh,</b> according to the blessing of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:15). Now <b>which is the item that has no blessing when</b> it is <b>alive,</b> i.e., it is prohibited to derive benefit from it, <b>but</b> it does have a blessing <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter,</b> as indicated by the verse “You may slaughter…according to the blessing of the Lord your God”? <b>You must say</b> that <b>this is</b> the meat of the <b>animal tithe</b> offering.
§ The <i>baraita</i> cited earlier teaches that the Sages permitted the inclusion of the value of a blemished animal-tithe offering’s meat in the cost of its hide, fat, sinews, and horns. In this regard, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to including</b> the value of the meat <b>in</b> the cost of <b>the</b> animal’s <b>bones? Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, disputed this matter. <b>One says</b> that one may <b>include</b> the value in the cost of the bones, <b>and one says</b> one may <b>not include</b> it.
The Gemara notes: <b>And they do not disagree. This</b> one, who maintains that one may not include the value in the cost of the bones, is referring <b>to a small, domesticated animal,</b> whose bones are incapable of being fashioned into utensils and are therefore never sold. <b>That</b> one, who holds that one may include the value in the cost of the bones, is referring <b>to a large, domesticated animal,</b> whose bones can be used and are therefore sold.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that both <b>this</b> one <b>and that</b> one are referring even <b>to a large, domesticated animal, and</b> still they <b>do not disagree.</b> This <b>Sage</b> rules <b>in accordance with</b> the custom of <b>his locale, and</b> that <b>Sage</b> rules <b>in accordance with</b> the custom of <b>his locale.</b> In other words, in certain places the custom is to use the bones and sell them, while elsewhere they do not.
§ The Gemara returns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself,</b> stated in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to a firstborn</b> male animal offering the verse <b>states: “You shall not redeem”</b> (Numbers 18:17), <b>but it may be sold</b> while alive, by the priest to whom it belongs. By contrast, <b>with regard to</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>it is stated: “It shall not be redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:33), indicating that its sanctity can never be removed from it, <b>and it cannot be sold, not</b> when <b>alive and not</b> when <b>slaughtered, not</b> when <b>unblemished and not</b> when <b>blemished.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived, that the phrase “it shall not be redeemed” is referring to the prohibition against selling the animal tithe offering?
<b>Rav Ḥinnana says</b> that <b>Rav says, and similarly, Rav Dimi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: It is stated: “It shall not be redeemed,” with regard to</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>and it is stated: “And it shall not be redeemed,” with regard to dedications [<i>baḥaramim</i>],</b> i.e., property that one consecrated by means of the expression: <i>Ḥerem</i>. With regard to dedications, the verse states: “Notwithstanding, any dedicated item…may neither be sold nor redeemed” (Leviticus 27:28). This is a verbal analogy: <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to dedications, the prohibition against <b>selling is</b> mentioned together <b>with</b> the prohibition against redeeming, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the animal tithe offering, the prohibition against <b>selling is</b> mentioned together <b>with</b> the prohibition against redeeming.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua:</b> It must be that at least one of the phrases “It shall not be redeemed” is <b>free,</b> i.e., at least one of these terms is superfluous in its context, which means that it is included for the specific purpose of the verbal analogy. In such a case the verbal analogy cannot be refuted by logic, whereas if neither phrase is free one can refute the analogy if there is a significant difference between the two cases. <b>As, if</b> these terms are <b>not free,</b> the verbal analogy <b>can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about dedications,</b> in contrast to the animal tithe offering? They are notable in <b>that</b> they <b>apply to all</b> items one wishes to dedicate, whereas an animal tithe offering applies only to kosher animals.
The Gemara notes: This is <b>not so [<i>la’ai</i>], as</b> at least one of the phrases: “It shall not be redeemed,” is certainly <b>free.</b> How so? <b>Let</b> the verse <b>not state: “It shall not be redeemed,” with regard to dedications, and</b> instead one could <b>derive</b> the prohibition <b>from</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering: <b>Just as</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>is sacred and may not be redeemed, so too, dedications are</b> also <b>sacred and may not be redeemed. Why</b> then <b>do I</b> need the phrase <b>“It shall not be redeemed” that the Merciful One writes,</b> in the case of dedications? It is evidently <b>to</b> be considered <b>free</b> to enable the verbal analogy.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion. It is still possible that the phrase “It shall not be redeemed,” written with regard to dedications, is not free, as the suggested derivation stated above <b>can be refuted: What is</b> notable <b>about</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering? It is notable <b>in that</b> there is <b>sanctity before it and after it.</b> If, instead of proclaiming as the tithe the tenth animal that one counted, one inadvertently proclaimed either the ninth animal or the eleventh animal as the tithe, the mistakenly proclaimed animal assumes the sacred status of the animal tithe offering. By contrast, one cannot inadvertently dedicate property to the Temple. Since the case of the animal tithe offering includes a stringency not shared by dedications, the phrase “It shall not be redeemed” is required to teach that dedications may not be redeemed, and is therefore not free for the verbal analogy.
The Gemara cites an alternative suggestion. <b>Rather, let</b> the verse <b>not state: “It shall not be redeemed,” with regard to dedications, and</b> instead one can <b>derive</b> the prohibition <b>from</b> the <b>firstborn</b> offering: <b>Just as</b> the <b>firstborn</b> offering <b>is sacred and may not be redeemed,</b> as the verse states: “You shall not redeem it” (Numbers 18:17), <b>so too, dedications are</b> also <b>sacred and may not be redeemed. Why do I</b> need the phrase <b>“It shall not be redeemed” that the Merciful One writes</b> in the case of dedications? It is evidently <b>to</b> be considered <b>free</b> to enable the verbal analogy to the animal tithe.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion as well: It is possible that the phrase “It shall not be redeemed” is not free, as the above derivation <b>can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the <b>firstborn</b> offering? It is notable <b>in that its sanctity is from the womb,</b> whereas dedications require an act of consecration.
<b>Rather, let</b> the verse <b>not say: “It shall not be redeemed,” with regard to</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>and</b> instead one can <b>derive</b> the prohibition <b>from a verbal analogy</b> from the term of <b>passing stated there</b> and the term of <b>passing</b> stated in the case of a firstborn. With regard to an animal tithe offering the verse states: “Whatsoever passes under the rod” (Leviticus 27:32), and in the case of the firstborn offering it is stated: “And you shall cause to pass all that opens the womb, to the Lord” (Exodus 13:12). <b>Just as</b> the <b>firstborn</b> offering <b>is sacred and may not be redeemed, so too,</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>is</b> also <b>sacred and may not be redeemed. Why do I</b> need the phrase <b>“It shall not be redeemed” that the Merciful One writes</b> with regard to animal tithe offerings? It is evidently <b>to</b> be considered <b>free</b> to enable the verbal analogy to dedications.
The Gemara asks: <b>But still,</b> the phrase “It shall not be redeemed,” written <b>with regard to</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, is itself <b>not free, as</b> the analogy between the animal tithe offering and the firstborn offering <b>can be refuted as we refuted</b> the analogy between the firstborn offering and dedications, since the firstborn offering is notable in that it is sanctified from the womb.
The Gemara answers: The term <b>“And you shall cause to pass,”</b> written in the context of the firstborn, <b>is a superfluous verse,</b> as it could have simply stated: All that opens the womb is to be for the Lord. Consequently, it is free to enable the verbal analogy. In sum, the Gemara is suggesting that due to the term “And you shall cause to pass,” there is a verbal analogy between the animal tithe offering and the firstborn offering, from which it is derived that the animal tithe offering may not be redeemed. This means that the phrase “It shall not be redeemed,” written with regard to the animal tithe offering, is free to enable the verbal analogy with dedications, from which the prohibition against selling the meat of the animal tithe offering is derived.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: With regard to <b>a firstborn</b> offering <b>as well, let us derive</b> that one may not sell its meat from a verbal analogy between the expression of <b>redemption</b> written there and the expression of <b>redemption</b> written in the context <b>of dedications.</b> This would contradict the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> that a firstborn offering can be sold after it enters the possession of the priest. The Gemara answers: The expression of redemption in the context <b>of</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering is <b>free</b> to enable the verbal analogy to dedications, but the expression of redemption in the context <b>of a firstborn</b> offering <b>is not free,</b> as it is required in its own context to teach that the firstborn offering may not be redeemed and as the source for the <i>halakha</i> of the animal tithe offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see that</b> you said that the phrase <b>“you shall not redeem”</b> written in the context <b>of a firstborn</b> offering is not free, but is necessary <b>for itself,</b> i.e., to teach that it may not be redeemed, <b>and</b> yet the expression of redemption written <b>with regard to</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>is free</b> to enable the verbal analogy, as the <i>halakha</i> of its redemption is derived from the firstborn? <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> the reverse, <b>that</b> the expression of redemption written in the context <b>of</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering is <b>for itself,</b> whereas <b>that</b> written <b>with regard to a firstborn</b> offering is <b>free.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>We derive</b> the expression of <b>redemption [<i>geula</i>]</b> written in the context of the animal tithe offering <b>from</b> the expression of <b>redemption [<i>geula</i>]</b> written in the context of dedications, <b>but we do not derive</b> the expression of <b>redemption [<i>pediya</i>]</b> written in the context of a firstborn offering <b>from</b> the different expression of <b>redemption [<i>geula</i>]</b> written in the context of the dedications.
The Gemara asks: <b>What difference</b> is there whether or not an identical expression is used for a verbal analogy? <b>Didn’t the school of Rabbi Yishmael teach</b> a verbal analogy with regard to leprosy of houses? The verse states: <b>“And the priest shall return [<i>veshav</i>]</b> on the seventh day” (Leviticus 14:39), and another verse with regard to the priest’s visit seven days later states: <b>“And the priest shall come [<i>uva</i>]</b> and look” (Leviticus 14:44). <b>This returning</b> and <b>this coming</b> have the same meaning and one can therefore derive by verbal analogy that the same <i>halakha</i> that applies if the leprosy had spread at the conclusion of the first week also applies if it had spread again by the end of the following week. Here too, the different terms of <i>pediya</i> and <i>geula</i> should not prevent the application of a verbal analogy.
The Gemara answers: <b>This statement,</b> that the phrases used for a verbal analogy do not have to be identical, applies only <b>where there are no terms</b> that are <b>equivalent to it. But where there are terms that</b> are <b>equivalent to it, we derive</b> the verbal analogy <b>from</b> the terms <b>that</b> are <b>equivalent to it,</b> rather than from the terms that are not equivalent.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But let one derive</b> that it is prohibited to sell the meat of a blemished <b>firstborn</b> offering from the verbal analogy between the expression of <b>passing</b> and the expression of <b>passing, from</b> the case of the animal <b>tithe</b> offering. This should be possible, <b>as</b> the sale of the meat of a blemished animal-<b>tithe</b> offering is <b>also</b> prohibited, as <b>derived</b> by a verbal analogy between the expression of <b>redemption</b> written in its context and the expression of <b>redemption</b> written <b>with regard to dedications,</b> as explained earlier.
The Gemara answers: <b>The Merciful One limits</b> the extension of the prohibition against selling <b>with regard to dedications</b> by adding the term <b>“it”</b> in the verse: “It is most holy to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:28). The term <b>“it”</b> teaches that the prohibition against selling applies only to it, i.e., dedications, <b>but not</b> to <b>a firstborn</b> offering. The Gemara raises a difficulty: But one can <b>say</b> instead that the term <b>“it”</b> teaches that the prohibition against selling applies to dedications, <b>but not</b> to the animal <b>tithe</b> offering. The Gemara answers: The prohibition against selling applies to the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, with regard to which the expression of <b>redemption</b> is written, <b>just like</b> dedications, while the term “it” limits the prohibition to the firstborn offering.
§ <b>Rava says</b> that there is an alternative explanation for the prohibition against selling the animal tithe. The phrase <b>“It may not be redeemed,”</b> written <b>with regard to dedications, is unnecessary</b> and is therefore free to enable a verbal analogy with the animal tithe offering. Rava explains: <b>As where are</b> the items of dedication, designated for the priests, located? <b>If</b> they are <b>in the owner’s possession, they are</b> considered <b>consecrated</b> and may not be redeemed. <b>And if they are in the priest’s possession, they are</b> considered <b>non-sacred</b> and the priest may sell them.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Dedications, as long as they are in the owner’s possession, are like consecrated</b> property <b>in all respects, as it is stated: “Every dedicated item is most holy to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 27:28). Once the owner <b>gave them to the priest, they are like non-sacred property in all respects, as it is stated: “Every dedicated item in Israel shall be for You”</b> (Numbers 18:14). Rava continues: Accordingly, concerning the phrase <b>“It may not</b>

Daf 32b

<b>be redeemed” that the Merciful One writes, why do I</b> need it? <b>If it is not</b> referring <b>to</b> the <b>matter of dedications,</b> as can be inferred from the <i>baraita</i>, <b>apply it to the matter of</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, teaching that it may not be sold. The Gemara raises a difficulty: One can <b>say</b> that instead of applying it to the animal tithe offering, <b>apply it to the matter of a firstborn</b> offering. The Gemara rejects this possibility: The prohibition against selling extends to the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, concerning which the expression of <b>redemption</b> is written, <b>just like</b> dedications, which is not so concerning the firstborn offering.
§ <b>Rav Ashi says</b> that the prohibition against selling the animal tithe offering is not derived from dedications, but rather from the case of the animal tithe offering itself. The phrase <b>“It may not be redeemed,”</b> written <b>with regard to</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, is to be understood as meaning: <b>It may not be sold. Rav Ashi</b> further <b>says: From where do I say this? As it is written: “Then both it and that for which it is substituted shall be holy; it shall not be redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:33).
Rav Ashi elaborates: <b>When</b> does the animal tithe offering <b>render</b> a non-sacred animal for which it is exchanged consecrated as <b>a substitute?</b> Only <b>when</b> the animal tithe offering is <b>alive.</b> Similarly, <b>when may</b> the animal tithe offering <b>not be redeemed</b> by its owner? Only <b>when</b> it is <b>alive,</b> which indicates that <b>it may be redeemed after</b> its <b>slaughter.</b> But when redeeming a sanctified animal, <b>it requires standing and valuation,</b> i.e., it has to be set standing before a priest for him to evaluate it and only then is it redeemed (see Leviticus 27:11–12). How, then, can the animal tithe offering be redeemed after having been slaughtered?
Rav Ashi continues: <b>Rather, conclude from</b> this verse that the phrase <b>“it may not be redeemed”</b> is not referring to redemption. Rather, it <b>is</b> actually to be understood as: <b>It may not be sold.</b> Accordingly, the prohibition against selling the animal tithe offering is in effect only while it is alive, as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a substitute; but once it is slaughtered, it may be sold.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that animals <b>consecrated</b> to be sacrificed on the <b>altar</b> that were disqualified due to a blemish <b>were included in</b> the requirement of <b>standing and valuation. But according to the one who says</b> that animals <b>consecrated to</b> be sacrificed on the <b>altar</b> that were disqualified due to a blemish <b>were not included in</b> the requirement of <b>standing and valuation, what is there to say?</b> According to this opinion, the phrase “It may not be redeemed” can be interpreted literally, in contrast to Rav Ashi’s claim.
The Gemara explains: <b>This is what we said,</b> i.e., this is what we meant. The phrase “It may not be redeemed” cannot be understood literally, as <b>is there</b> ever an instance <b>where</b> an animal <b>may not be redeemed when alive, and</b> yet it <b>may be redeemed after</b> its <b>slaughter?</b> Since such a scenario is impossible, the verse must be referring to the prohibition against selling. The Gemara asks: But <b>why</b> can it <b>not</b> be said that an animal may be redeemed only after its slaughter? One can claim that <b>when</b> the animal is <b>alive, since its sanctity is strong,</b> it is logical to say that it <b>may not be redeemed.</b> Conversely, <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter, when its sanctity is weak,</b> it is logical to claim that <b>it may be redeemed.</b> If so, the phrase can be understood literally.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>But isn’t</b> the opposite claim, that a slaughtered animal tithe offering may not be redeemed, based on <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If, when</b> the animal tithe offering is <b>alive and</b> its sanctity <b>is strong</b> enough <b>to transfer</b> that sanctity to <b>its redemption</b> money, just as it renders a non-sacred animal consecrated as a substitute, nevertheless <b>it may not be redeemed,</b> then <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter, when</b> its sanctity <b>is not strong</b> enough <b>to transfer</b> that sanctity to <b>its redemption</b> money, as at this stage it cannot render a non-sacred animal consecrated as a substitute, should it be able to <b>be redeemed?</b> In other words, the fact that substitution can be effected only with a living animal indicates that a strong sanctity is more easily transferable to another item than a weak sanctity. <b>Rather, conclude from this</b> that the phrase <b>“It may not be redeemed” is</b> actually to be understood as meaning that <b>it may not be sold.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let the Merciful One write</b> explicitly: <b>It may not be sold.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Had the Merciful One written: It may not be sold, I would say</b> that the animal tithe offering only <b>may not be sold, as one</b> who does so <b>performs an act</b> of <b>a non-sacred</b> item, by treating the consecrated animal in the same manner as a non-sacred animal and transferring its value to non-sacred money. <b>But</b> I would say that <b>it may be redeemed, as</b> in this manner <b>its value becomes consecrated. Therefore,</b> in order to counter this notion, <b>the Merciful One writes: “It may not be redeemed,”</b> which teaches both <b>that</b> the animal tithe offering <b>may not be sold and</b> that it <b>may not be redeemed.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Beit Shammai say: An Israelite cannot be counted with the priest to</b> partake of a blemished <b>firstborn. And Beit Hillel deem</b> it <b>permitted</b> for him to partake of it, <b>and</b> they deem it permitted <b>even</b> for <b>a gentile</b> to partake of a blemished firstborn.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that Beit Hillel deem it permitted even for a gentile to partake of a blemished firstborn offering. The Gemara says: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna? It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a blemished <b>firstborn</b> offering, <b>only a group</b> constituted <b>entirely of priests may be counted to</b> partake of <b>it;</b> this is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai. And Beit Hillel say:</b> The group may <b>even</b> be constituted of <b>non-priests. Rabbi Akiva</b> says that Beit Hillel <b>deem</b> it <b>permitted even</b> for <b>a gentile</b> to partake of a blemished firstborn. Evidently, Beit Hillel’s opinion in the mishna is in accordance with Rabbi Akiva’s explanation in this <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason of Beit Shammai? As it is written</b> in a verse discussing the firstborn offering, addressed to Aaron and his sons: “But the firstling of an ox, or the firstling of a sheep, or the firstling of a goat you shall not redeem; they are holy …<b>and their flesh shall be yours,</b> as the wave breast and as the right thigh, it shall be yours” (Numbers 18:17–18). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the breast and the thigh, <b>priests may</b> partake of it but <b>an Israelite,</b> i.e., a non-priest, may <b>not,</b> as the verse states: “You shall eat in a pure place; you, and your sons, and your daughters with you” (Leviticus 10:14), <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the firstborn offering, only <b>priests may</b> partake of it, but <b>an Israelite</b> may <b>not.</b>

Daf 33a

<b>And Beit Hillel</b> would respond to that claim: <b>This statement</b> applies only to an <b>unblemished</b> firstborn offering, which is sacrificed upon the altar. <b>But</b> concerning <b>a blemished</b> firstborn <b>it is written:</b> “You shall eat it within your gates; <b>the impure and the pure may eat it alike”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:22; see Deuteronomy 15:22). Beit Hillel derive an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>And if a ritually impure</b> priest, <b>who may not eat</b> the meat <b>of offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> nevertheless <b>may eat</b> the meat <b>of</b> a blemished <b>firstborn</b> offering, then with regard to <b>a non-priest, who may eat</b> the meat of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> e.g., peace offerings and animal tithe offerings, <b>is it not logical that he may eat</b> the meat <b>of</b> a blemished <b>firstborn</b> offering?
The Gemara raises a difficulty: This <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the case of <b>a ritually impure</b> priest? It is notable in <b>that its general</b> prohibition <b>was permitted</b> in certain circumstances, specifically <b>with regard to the communal service.</b> If there are no ritually pure priests, the sacrificial service may be performed by ritually impure priests. By contrast, it is never permitted for a non-priest to perform the sacrificial service. Accordingly, one cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> concerning a non-priest via an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from an impure priest.
<b>And Beit Hillel</b> would respond: <b>Is that to say</b> that the <i>a fortiori</i> inference was <b>stated with regard to</b> the sacrificial <b>service,</b> which was the subject of that refutation? Not so; rather, <b>we state</b> it <b>with regard to</b> the <b>eating</b> of sacrificial meat, and the <b>eating of a non-priest is superior</b> to that of a ritually impure priest. Accordingly, the refutation of the <i>a fortiori</i> inference is inapplicable.
§ The <i>baraita</i> stated that according to <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> Beit Hillel <b>deems</b> it <b>permitted</b> for non-priests, <b>and even gentiles,</b> to partake of blemished firstborn offerings. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Akiva?</b> The verse states: <b>“Like the gazelle and like the deer”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:22). <b>Just as a gazelle and a deer</b> are <b>permitted to</b> be eaten by <b>a gentile, so too, disqualified</b> blemished firstborn offerings are <b>permitted to</b> be eaten by <b>a gentile.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other one,</b> i.e., the <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi Akiva’s version of the opinion of Beit Hillel, who does not deem it permitted for a gentile to partake of a blemished firstborn offering, what is his reason? The Gemara answers that the terms <b>“gazelle” and “hart” are written three</b> times in the context of disqualified consecrated animals, in Deuteronomy 12:15, 12:22, and 15:22. <b>One</b> is required <b>for</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yitzḥak and Rabbi Oshaya, and one</b> is needed <b>for</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Elazar HaKappar.</b>
<b>And the other</b> verse teaches that <b>just as a gazelle and a deer are exempt from</b> the first of their offspring being counted <b>a firstborn,</b> as the verse states: “All the firstling males that are born of your herd and of your flock” (Deuteronomy 15:19), referring specifically to domesticated animals but not undomesticated animals such as a gazelle and a deer; <b>so too, disqualified consecrated</b> animals <b>are exempt from</b> the first of their offspring being counted <b>a firstborn</b> (see 14a).
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not give</b> a blemished <b>firstborn</b> offering <b>to menstruating women to eat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai. And Beit Hillel say: One may give it to menstruating women to eat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Beit Shammai? It is written</b> with regard to the firstborn offering: <b>“And their flesh shall be yours,</b> as the wave breast and the right thigh” (Numbers 18:18). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the wave breast and the right thigh, <b>menstruating women</b> may <b>not</b> eat them, as these consecrated meats may not be eaten by a ritually impure individual, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the firstborn offering, <b>menstruating women</b> may <b>not</b> eat its meat, as it too is consecrated.
<b>And Beit Hillel</b> would respond: <b>This statement,</b> i.e., this verse, is referring only to the meat of <b>an unblemished</b> firstborn offering. Only such meat is compared to the wave breast and the right thigh. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a blemished</b> firstborn offering, the verse explicitly states that <b>the impure and the pure may eat it</b> (see Deuteronomy 15:22).
<b>And Beit Shammai</b> would claim: <b>This statement,</b> that the ritually impure may eat the meat of a blemished firstborn offering, applies only <b>where the impurity does not issue upon him from his</b> own <b>body</b> but is contracted from an external source, e.g., from a corpse or the carcass of a creeping animal. <b>But where the impurity issues upon him from his</b> own <b>body,</b> such as in the case of a <i>zav</i> or a menstruating woman, that individual may <b>not</b> eat the meat of a blemished firstborn offering.
Beit Shammai continue: This is a valid distinction, <b>as we find that the Merciful One distinguishes between</b> a case where the <b>impurity issues upon</b> an individual <b>from his</b> own <b>body</b> and <b>between</b> a case where the <b>impurity does not issue upon him from his</b> own <b>body. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 95b): When <b>the Paschal offering is sacrificed in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> due to the fact that the majority of the Jewish people are ritually impure, then <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers and <i>zavot</i> and menstruating women and women after childbirth may not eat from it.</b> The sacrificing of the Paschal offering overrides only ritual impurity imparted by a corpse; it does not override other forms of ritual impurity.
<b>And Beit Hillel</b> would respond: <b>It is</b> only <b>there,</b> in the case of the Paschal offering, that a difference of that kind applies, <b>as the Merciful One revealed</b> that only an individual whose impurity did not issue from his own body is permitted to eat the Paschal offering, as the verse states: <b>“Impure</b> by reason of <b>a dead body”</b> (Numbers 9:10). <b>But here,</b> with regard to the firstborn offering, the term <b>“impure” is written unspecified:</b> “The impure and the pure may eat it alike.” Therefore, in this case there <b>is no difference</b> between the two types of impurity.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not skin an animal from its feet [<i>margilin</i>] on a Festival.</b> Although it is permitted to slaughter and skin an animal on a Festival, one may not skin it in such a manner that he will retain the hide intact to function as a vessel. <b>Similarly, one may not skin a firstborn</b> offering <b>from its feet,</b> even on a weekday and even if it is blemished, <b>nor</b> is skinning by way of the feet permitted <b>in</b> the case of <b>disqualified consecrated</b> animals. Such an act is considered degrading to the animal, even if the animal has been redeemed and slaughtered.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> one may not skin an animal from its feet on <b>a Festival, as one is</b> thereby <b>performing an effort whose</b> outcome <b>is not needed for</b> use on the Festival. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a firstborn</b> offering, <b>who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> that skinning it from its feet is prohibited? <b>Rav Ḥisda says: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, who say</b> that <b>one may not feed</b> the meat of a firstborn offering <b>to menstruating women.</b> According to Beit Shammai, a blemished firstborn retains its sanctity as though it were unblemished, and must be treated in the manner of sacrificial meat. Skinning an animal from its feet is considered an act inappropriate for such meat and is therefore prohibited.
The Gemara analyzes the next clause of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Nor</b> is skinning by way of the feet permitted <b>in</b> the case of <b>disqualified consecrated</b> animals. The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> this? <b>Rav Ḥisda says: It is Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>had before him two sin offerings</b> that he consecrated to achieve atonement for his sin so that in the event that one of them was lost or died the other would effect atonement. <b>One</b> of them was <b>unblemished and</b> the other <b>one</b> became <b>blemished</b> after having been consecrated. The <i>halakha</i> is that the <b>unblemished</b> offering <b>should be sacrificed,</b> whereas the <b>blemished</b> one <b>should be redeemed.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If</b> the <b>blemished</b> animal <b>was</b> redeemed and <b>slaughtered before the blood of</b> the <b>unblemished</b> one <b>was sprinkled</b> on the altar to effect the atonement, the blemished animal is <b>permitted</b> to be eaten. But <b>if</b> the blemished one was slaughtered after <b>the blood of the unblemished</b> animal <b>was already sprinkled</b> upon the altar, the blemished animal is <b>prohibited</b> both in consumption and benefit. Since its owner’s atonement is effected by the sprinkling of the blood of the unblemished offering on the altar, at this stage the blemished animal must be put to death, in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> that a sin offering whose owner achieved atonement with another sin offering must die.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: Even</b> if the blemished animal was slaughtered and its <b>meat</b> is being cooked <b>in the pot, and</b> only then was the <b>blood of the unblemished</b> animal <b>sprinkled</b> on the altar, the meat of the blemished animal is still <b>prohibited.</b> Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, maintains that disqualified blemished offerings retain a measure of their sanctity even after being slaughtered. Since the blemished sin offering was not yet eaten when the blood of the unblemished one was sprinkled, it is considered a sin offering whose owner has achieved atonement, and therefore it is prohibited for one to derive benefit from it. The opinion of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, accords with the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> with regard to skinning a disqualified consecrated animal from its feet.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But let Rav Ḥisda establish the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Perhaps Beit Shammai say</b> that the sanctity of a blemished offering is retained <b>only in</b> the case of <b>a firstborn</b> offering, <b>as its sanctity is from the womb. But</b> with regard to <b>a disqualified consecrated</b> animal, <b>whose sanctity is not from the womb,</b> perhaps they do <b>not</b> maintain that its sanctity remains even after it has been slaughtered. It is therefore necessary to attribute the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i> to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon.

Daf 33b

The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>establish the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says</b> that the sanctity of a slaughtered blemished offering is retained <b>only there,</b> with regard to other <b>disqualified consecrated</b> animals, <b>because</b> their level of sanctity is <b>strong</b> enough <b>to transfer</b> their sanctity to their <b>redemption</b> money. <b>But</b> with regard to a blemished <b>firstborn</b> offering, <b>whose</b> level of sanctity is <b>not strong</b> enough <b>to transfer</b> it to <b>its redemption</b> money, perhaps its sanctity is <b>not</b> retained, and therefore one may skin the hide from its feet.
The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> agree with the ruling of the mishna (31a) that <b>all disqualified consecrated</b> animals <b>are sold in the butchers’ market and weighed</b> and sold <b>by the <i>litra</i>,</b> in the manner of non-sacred meat? Certainly he agrees with that <i>halakha</i>. <b>Evidently, since there is a benefit</b> that accrues <b>to</b> the <b>Temple</b> treasury, the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>deems this permitted.</b> As it was taught (31b), the meat of disqualified consecrated animals may be treated in this manner despite the fact that it retains a measure of sanctity. The reason is that if the owner knows that it is permitted for him to perform this more lucrative action, he is likely to spend more money to redeem the animal in the first place, which benefits the Temple treasury. By the same logic, why doesn’t Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, permit the more lucrative action of skinning the animal from its feet?
The Gemara cites several resolutions. <b>Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said</b> that <b>the benefit gained to the hide</b> by skinning it whole is offset by the <b>detriment</b> caused <b>to the flesh.</b> Part of the animal’s flesh is severed from the carcass during the skinning process, thereby lowering its value. <b>In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they say in the name of Ravina</b> that skinning a disqualified consecrated animal from its feet is prohibited <b>because it appears as though</b> he is <b>performing work with sacrificial</b> animals, which is prohibited.
<b>Rabbi Yosei bar Avin says</b> that this prohibition is a rabbinic <b>decree, lest one</b> retain the disqualified consecrated animals in his possession while waiting for a consumer to purchase the hides, and in the meantime <b>raise many herds</b> of disqualified animals <b>from them.</b> In such a case, he might shear or work the animals in a prohibited manner.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>that was congested with</b> excess <b>blood, even</b> if the animal will <b>die</b> if one does not let the excess blood, <b>one may not let its blood,</b> as this might cause a blemish, and it is prohibited to cause a blemish on consecrated animals. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.
