And the Rabbis say: One may let</b> the blood <b>provided that he will not cause a blemish</b> while doing so, <b>and if he caused a blemish, the animal may not be slaughtered on</b> account of <b>that</b> blemish. Since he was the cause of the blemish, he may not slaughter the animal until it develops a different, unrelated blemish. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: One may let</b> the blood <b>even if he</b> thereby <b>causes a blemish</b> in the animal.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>that was congested with</b> excess <b>blood,</b> and which can be healed only through bloodletting, <b>one may let</b> the animal’s <b>blood</b> by cutting it <b>in a place where</b> the incision <b>does not cause</b> a permanent <b>blemish. But one may not let</b> the animal’s <b>blood</b> by cutting it <b>in a place where</b> the incision <b>causes</b> a permanent <b>blemish,</b> as it is prohibited to intentionally cause a blemish in a firstborn animal; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: One may even let</b> the animal’s blood by cutting it <b>in a place where</b> the incision <b>causes</b> a permanent <b>blemish, provided that he does not slaughter</b> the animal <b>on</b> the basis <b>of that blemish,</b> even though in general, a firstborn animal may be slaughtered once it develops any permanent blemish. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The animal <b>may even be slaughtered on</b> the basis <b>of that blemish. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> if the firstborn would <b>die</b> if its blood is not let, <b>one may not let its blood</b> at all.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Elazar taught his son, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> who taught <b>his son:</b> Just <b>as</b> there is <b>a dispute here</b> in this <i>baraita</i> with regard to bloodletting, <b>so</b> there is <b>a dispute</b> in a mishna <b>with regard to a barrel of <i>teruma</i>. As we learned</b> (<i>Terumot</i> 8:8): In the case of <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> oil <b>with regard to which uncertainty developed</b> concerning its status of <b>ritual impurity,</b> and which therefore may not be eaten, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that one must nevertheless safeguard the <i>teruma</i> from impurity. Therefore, <b>if</b> the barrel <b>was resting in a vulnerable location,</b> where it might come into contact with impurity, one <b>should place it in a concealed location, and if it was exposed, he should cover it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> That is not necessary. Rather, <b>if it was placed in a concealed location,</b> one <b>may place it in a vulnerable location. If it was covered he may expose it,</b> as he need no longer safeguard this <i>teruma</i> from impurity. <b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> One <b>should do nothing new with it,</b> i.e., he should leave the barrel as it is.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who deems it permitted to let the firstborn offering’s blood provided that one does not cause a blemish, holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who deems it prohibited to place the barrel in an exposed location lest it become ritually impure, which is equivalent to a blemish. <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who deem bloodletting permitted even if it will cause a blemish, hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who rules that the contents of the barrel may be exposed to ritual impurity. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who says that bloodletting is not permitted under any circumstance, holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel,</b> who rules that the barrel should be left as is and not be handled at all.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>From where</b> can one prove that these comparisons are accurate? <b>Perhaps Rabbi Meir states</b> his opinion, that one may not let blood in a place that will cause a blemish, <b>only there, as</b> the individual is <b>causing</b> the blemish <b>by</b> direct <b>action. But here,</b> in the case of the barrel, <b>where</b> the ritual impurity results <b>from an indirect</b> action, perhaps <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
<b>And</b> furthermore, perhaps <b>Rabbi Eliezer states</b> his opinion that the barrel should be protected <b>only here,</b> because <b>perhaps Elijah will come and deem it ritually pure. But there,</b> with regard to the firstborn offering, <b>where if one leaves</b> the animal <b>it will</b> certainly <b>die,</b> perhaps <b>he holds in accordance with the</b> opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that bloodletting is permitted in order to prevent the animal’s death.
<b>And</b> likewise, <b>perhaps the Rabbis state</b> their opinion <b>only here,</b> with regard to the firstborn offering, <b>as if one leaves it,</b> the animal <b>will</b> certainly <b>die. But there,</b> in the case of the barrel of <i>teruma</i>, perhaps they accept the claim that one must safeguard the <i>teruma</i>, because <b>perhaps Elijah will come and deem it ritually pure,</b> which would mean that <b>they hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b> It can also be suggested that <b>Rabbi Yehuda states</b> his opinion, that bloodletting is prohibited in all circumstances, <b>only here,</b> with regard to the firstborn offering, <b>as</b> the individual is <b>causing</b> the blemish <b>by</b> direct <b>action. But there,</b> in the case of the barrel, <b>where</b> the ritual impurity results from an <b>indirect</b> action, perhaps <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
<b>And</b> perhaps <b>Rabban Gamliel states</b> his opinion, that the barrel should not be moved at all, <b>only there,</b> because <b>perhaps Elijah will come and deem it ritually pure. But here,</b> with regard to the firstborn offering, <b>where if one leaves it, it will</b> certainly <b>die,</b> it is possible that <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
<b>And furthermore,</b> one cannot draw parallels between the opinions of the two sources, as <b>here</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> the exposition of certain <b>verses, and there they disagree with regard to</b> the exposition of certain other <b>verses. As Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: All</b> of the Sages who disagree as to whether one may let the blood of the firstborn animal <b>concede that one who leavens</b> a meal offering <b>after</b> another had already <b>leavened</b> it is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes for the additional leavening, <b>as it is written: “It shall not be baked with leaven”</b> (Leviticus 6:10), <b>and</b> it is also stated: “No meal offering that you sacrifice to God <b>shall be made</b> with leaven” (Leviticus 2:11). This indicates that one is liable for every act of leavening performed on a meal offering.
Similarly, everyone agrees <b>that one who castrates</b> an animal <b>after one who has</b> already <b>castrated</b> it <b>is liable, as it is written: “Those whose testicles are bruised or crushed or detached or cut</b> shall not be offered to the Lord, and you shall not do this in your land” (Leviticus 22:24). <b>If one is liable</b> when the seminal vesicles <b>are cut,</b> then when the testicles <b>are detached</b> altogether, is he <b>not all the more so</b> liable? <b>Rather,</b> this verse serves to <b>include</b> one who <b>detaches</b> the testicles <b>after</b> one who <b>cuts</b> the seminal vesicles, to indicate <b>that he is liable.</b> Apparently, one is liable for castrating an animal that is already sterilized.
These Sages <b>disagree only with regard to one who causes a blemish in</b> an already <b>blemished</b> animal, such as one whose blood circulation is constricted. <b>As Rabbi Meir maintains</b> that as the verse states: “It shall be perfect to be accepted; <b>there shall be no blemish in it”</b> (Leviticus 22:21), this categorical statement includes even the causing of a blemish in an offering that is already blemished. <b>And the Rabbis maintain</b> that the phrase <b>“It shall be perfect to be accepted”</b> indicates that the prohibition against causing a blemish applies only to an animal that is currently perfect, i.e., unblemished, and can therefore be accepted, i.e., it is fit to be sacrificed upon the altar. If the animal is already blemished, there is no prohibition against causing an additional blemish in it.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Meir, what does he do with this</b> verse: <b>“It shall be perfect to be accepted”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse serves <b>to exclude</b> only an animal that was <b>blemished from the outset,</b> i.e., an animal that was born with a blemish. In such a case, there is no prohibition against causing an additional blemish in it. But if the animal was initially unblemished and later developed a blemish, it is prohibited to cause another blemish in it.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: There is no need to exclude an animal that was <b>blemished from the outset,</b> as <b>it is merely like a palm tree,</b> i.e., it can never attain the status of an animal consecrated as an offering. Therefore, it is obvious that the prohibition against causing a blemish does not apply to this animal.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Meir maintains that the phrase “It shall be perfect to be accepted” serves <b>to exclude disqualified consecrated</b> animals, to teach that <b>after their redemption,</b> when they become non-sacred, the prohibition against causing a blemish does not apply to them any longer. This exclusion is necessary, as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> even after they have been redeemed and are non-sacred, just as it is <b>prohibited</b> to <b>shear</b> these animals <b>or</b> use them for <b>labor,</b> perhaps <b>let</b> it <b>also be prohibited</b> to cause <b>a blemish upon them.</b> Consequently, this verse <b>teaches us</b> that there is no prohibition against causing a blemish in these animals.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the Rabbis as well,</b> who derive their opinion from the verse: “It shall be perfect to be accepted,” <b>isn’t it written: “There shall not be any blemish in it,”</b> which indicates an expansion of the prohibition against causing a blemish upon an offering? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>comes</b> to teach <b>that</b> the prohibition against causing a blemish extends also to a blemish caused as the result of <b>an indirect</b> action. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“There shall not be</b> any <b>blemish in it”</b> (Leviticus 22:21); from here <b>I have</b> derived

Daf 34a

<b>only</b> the prohibition <b>that one may not</b> directly <b>cause a blemish. From where</b> is it derived <b>that one may not bring</b> pressed <b>figs or dough and place it on the</b> animal’s <b>ear so that a dog will come and eat it,</b> thereby biting off part of the animal’s ear and leaving it blemished? <b>The verse states:</b> “There shall not be <b>any blemish</b> in it” (Leviticus 22:21), indicating that the same prohibition applies <b>both</b> when the <b>blemish</b> is caused directly <b>and</b> when it is <b>any blemish,</b> even one caused indirectly.
After demonstrating that the <i>tanna’im</i> in the <i>baraita</i> discussing the firstborn offering disagree with regard to the exposition of certain verses, the Gemara clarifies that the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> discussing <i>teruma</i> whose status concerning impurity is uncertain, also <b>disagree with regard to</b> the exposition of <b>verses. As Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says, and Reish Lakish likewise says, and Rav Naḥman likewise says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> It is stated in a verse addressed to Aaron and his sons: <b>“And I, behold, I have given you the charge of My <i>terumot</i> [<i>terumotai</i>]”</b> (Numbers 18:8), with “<i>terumotai</i>” written in plural.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who holds that the barrel of <i>teruma</i> must be safeguarded from ritual impurity, <b>holds that the verse is speaking of two <i>terumot</i>: Both <i>teruma</i> that is</b> definitely <b>ritually pure and <i>teruma</i> that is in abeyance,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> whose status with regard to impurity is uncertain. <b>And</b> based on the plural “My <i>terumot</i>,” it is understood that <b>the Merciful One states: Make a protection for it,</b> i.e., safeguard even <i>teruma</i> whose status concerning impurity is uncertain. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who holds that one may expose to ritual impurity the <i>teruma</i> contents in the barrel, holds that the term <i>terumotai</i> is <b>written</b> so that it can be read as <b><i>terumati</i>,</b> meaning: My <i>teruma</i>, in the singular. Therefore, the requirement to safeguard <i>teruma</i> applies only to that <i>teruma</i> whose status is definitely pure.
The Gemara asks: Is this <b>to say that Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that <b>the vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative,</b> i.e., one derives <i>halakhot</i> based on the pronunciation of the words, although it diverges from the spelling? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i> discussing a Hebrew maidservant’s return to her father’s house. The verse states, with regard to her master: “He shall have no power to sell her to a foreign people, <b>seeing that he has dealt deceitfully with her [<i>bevigdo bah</i>]”</b> (Exodus 21:8). The term “<i>bevigdo</i>” shares a root with a word for garment, <i>beged</i>. Therefore, the verse indicates that <b>once</b> the master <b>has spread his garment over her,</b> thereby designating her as his wife, if the maidservant is subsequently divorced or widowed, her father <b>may no longer sell her.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva,</b> who maintains that the vocalization of the Torah is authoritative, and he interprets <i>bevigdo</i> as related to <i>bigdo</i>, his garment.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The word <i>bevigdo</i> is written without a <i>yod</i> and therefore is written in a manner that it can be read: <i>Bevagdo</i>. Accordingly, <i>bevigdo bah</i> means that <b>since</b> the father <b>dealt deceitfully [<i>bagad</i>] with her</b> by selling her once, <b>he may not sell her again.</b> Evidently, Rabbi Eliezer maintains that the manner in which the verses in the Torah are written is authoritative, and one derives <i>halakhot</i> based on the spelling of the words. This contradicts his derivation with regard to <i>teruma</i>, which is based on the pronunciation of the words.
<b>Rather, here,</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to this:</b> The verse states: “And I, behold, I have given you the charge of My <i>terumot</i>” (Numbers 18:8). <b>Rabbi Yehoshua holds</b> that the term “you” teaches that only <i>teruma</i> <b>that is fit for you</b> to eat, i.e., <i>teruma</i> that is definitely ritually pure, you must <b>safeguard. But</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>that is not fit for you,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> whose status with regard to impurity is uncertain, <b>you</b> do <b>not</b> need to <b>safeguard. And Rabbi Eliezer</b> holds that <b>this</b> <i>teruma</i>, whose status with regard to impurity is uncertain, is <b>also</b> considered <b>fit</b> for you, because <b>perhaps Elijah will come and deem it ritually pure.</b>
§ The Gemara again discusses letting the blood of a firstborn offering. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak objects to this:</b> To <b>which</b> opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> is Shmuel referring? <b>If we say</b> he is referring to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon in the mishna,</b> that the blood may be let despite the resulting blemish, because the purpose of the treatment is solely medical, that cannot be correct. After all, <b>hasn’t Shmuel taught us until now</b> that <b>an unintentional act,</b> i.e., a permitted action from which a prohibited result inadvertently ensues, is <b>permitted?</b>
<b>But doesn’t Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi say</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that an unintentional act is prohibited, <b>and Rav Ḥanin bar Ashi says</b> that <b>Shmuel</b> says: The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> that an unintentional act is permitted. <b>And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin teaches</b> these rulings directly, <b>without</b> citing additional <b>men</b> in their transmission. He simply states that <b>Rav says</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and Shmuel says</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> Evidently, Shmuel could not be referring to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon in the mishna, as if so, he would be repeating himself.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> Shmuel is referring to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon in the <i>baraita</i></b> (33b), that not only may one let the blood of the dying firstborn animal despite the resulting blemish, but it is even permitted to eat the animal’s meat on account of the blemish. <b>And</b> the Gemara notes that <b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, teaches this explicitly: Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> as stated <b>in the <i>baraita</i>.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slits [<i>hatzorem</i>] the ear of a firstborn</b> offering, <b>that</b> person <b>may never slaughter</b> that animal. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say:</b> If <b>another blemish</b> later <b>develops in</b> the firstborn, <b>he may slaughter</b> the animal <b>on</b> account of that second blemish.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Eliezer penalize</b> for a transgression <b>forever? And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 7:5): In the case of <b>one who had a snow-white leprous mark [<i>baheret</i>]</b> on his body,

Daf 34b

<b>and it</b> inadvertently <b>got excised,</b> that individual is <b>ritually pure.</b> If <b>he excised it intentionally,</b> in an attempt to render himself ritually pure, the Sages impose a punitive impurity upon him. The <i>tanna’im</i> disagree with regard to the extent of the penalty: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: When he will develop another leprous mark,</b> his status of ritual purity is assessed based on this new mark. When that mark is ruled ritually pure, <b>he will become ritually pure from</b> the ritual impurity generated by the mark he excised.
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The development of a new leprous mark is insufficient. Rather, he must wait either <b>until</b> the leprosy of the new mark <b>spreads over his entire</b> body, a sign of ritual purity (see Leviticus 13:12), <b>or unless his</b> old <b><i>baheret</i></b> had <b>shrunk</b> to a size <b>smaller than</b> that <b>of a split bean</b>before he excised it. Otherwise, he remains ritually impure. In any event, it is clear from this mishna that Rabbi Eliezer does not impose an indefinite penalty on one who transgresses. If so, why does he impose an indefinite penalty in the mishna discussing one who causes a blemish on the ear of a firstborn offering?
<b>Rabba and Rav Yosef both say,</b> in answer to this question, that <b>when Rabbi Eliezer penalizes</b> one who transgresses, that is only <b>in</b> a case which involves <b>his property,</b> e.g., a firstborn offering. But <b>in</b> a case which affects <b>his body,</b> e.g., leprosy, <b>he does not penalize</b> him to such an extent.
The Gemara elaborates: With regard to <b>his property,</b> i.e., the firstborn offering, if he would not be penalized indefinitely, <b>there is</b> reason <b>to say that he might come to perform</b> an action which would cause a blemish. Since the firstborn offering is anyway prohibited for personal use until it is blemished, he suffers no risk in blemishing it. A greater deterrent than usual is therefore needed to prevent such action. By contrast, in the case of leprosy on <b>his body, is there</b> a basis <b>to say that he will come to perform</b> an action and remove the white spot? In this case, the limited penalty of having to wait for purification from another leprous mark serves as a sufficient deterrent, as there is no guarantee that another mark will ever appear.
<b>Rava said:</b> Is this to say that the statement <b>of Rabbi Eliezer</b> in the mishna here is <b>difficult in light of</b> the other statement <b>of Rabbi Eliezer</b> in the mishna in <i>Nega’im</i>, whereas the statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> in the mishna is <b>not difficult in light of</b> the other statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> in <i>Nega’im</i>? In the mishna here, the Rabbis impose a limited penalty on the transgressor, whereas in the mishna in <i>Nega’im</i> they impose an indefinite one. This contradiction also requires resolution.
<b>Rather,</b> say: The statement <b>of Rabbi Eliezer</b> in the mishna here is <b>not difficult in light of</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Eliezer</b> in <i>Nega’im</i>, <b>as we answered.</b> Likewise, the statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> in the mishna is <b>not difficult in light of</b> the statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> in <i>Nega’im</i>, as both rulings follow the same logic. <b>Here,</b> the Rabbis <b>penalized him for what he did, and there,</b> the Rabbis <b>penalized him for what he did.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: In the case of causing a blemish in a firstborn offering, <b>by what</b> means <b>did he intend to permit it? By means of this blemish.</b> Therefore, <b>the Rabbis penalized him</b> only <b>with regard to this blemish,</b> i.e., <b>that</b> the animal <b>will not become permitted to him by means of this blemish</b> that he himself caused. The firstborn offering retains its status as unblemished and will become permitted only if it develops another blemish. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>here,</b> with regard to the removal of the leprous mark, the Rabbis <b>penalize him for what he did. He intended to render himself ritually pure by means of this</b> act of <b>excising</b> the mark. Therefore, <b>the Rabbis penalized him with regard to this</b> act of <b>excision.</b> It is considered as though he did not excise the mark, and as a result, he remains impure permanently.
§ The Gemara analyzes Rabbi Eliezer’s statement: When he will develop another leprous mark, he will become ritually pure [<i>yit’har</i>] from the first. <b>Rav Pappa asks:</b> What is the correct version of Rabbi Eliezer’s statement? <b>Did we learn: <i>Yit’har</i>, or did we learn: <i>Veyit’har</i>,</b> and he will become ritually pure? <i>Yit’har</i> indicates that he will immediately be rendered ritually pure from the first leprous mark upon the appearance of the second mark. <i>Veyit’har</i>, by contrast, indicates that the punitive ritual impurity by rabbinic law imparted by the first mark remains until the second mark is deemed ritually pure.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> between the two versions? After all, he is in any case ritually impure due to the second mark until that mark is deemed pure. The Gemara explains that there is a difference in the case <b>of a bridegroom</b> who had removed a leprous mark <b>upon whom</b> a new <b>leprous mark appeared</b> during the seven days of his wedding celebrations.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 3:2): In the case of <b>a bridegroom upon whom a leprous mark appeared,</b> the court <b>grants him seven days</b> of his wedding celebrations before the mark is examined by a priest. This grace period is granted to him whether the mark appeared <b>on him,</b> i.e., his body, <b>or on his cloak, or on</b> any other <b>garment of his. And similarly,</b> with regard to any individual upon whom a leprous mark appeared <b>during a pilgrimage Festival,</b> the court <b>grants him all the days of the pilgrimage Festival</b> as a grace period, during which the mark is not examined by a priest.
The Gemara continues: <b>If you say</b> that <b>we learned</b> that the correct reading of Rabbi Eliezer’s statement is <b><i>yit’har</i>,</b> i.e., the individual is rendered ritually pure upon the development of the new mark, this means that he is ritually pure during the seven-day period, as <b>he has</b> already <b>become ritually pure</b> of the punitive impurity <b>from the first</b> mark. As <b>for the latter</b> mark, <b>we wait the seven days of feasting for him,</b> before the mark is examined by a priest. He is therefore ritually pure in all regards.
<b>But if you say</b> that <b>we learned</b> that the correct reading of Rabbi Eliezer’s statement is <b><i>veyit’har</i>,</b> and the punitive impurity of the first mark remains intact until the ritual purity of the second mark has been confirmed, the grace period has no effect. The reason is that <b>ultimately,</b> even if the individual <b>does not</b> yet <b>contract ritual impurity from the latter</b> mark, <b>he remains ritually impure on</b> account of <b>the first</b> mark until the purification of the latter mark. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the resolution to Rav Pappa’s query? Since there is no clear resolution, the Gemara concludes that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that one who slits the ear of a firstborn offering is prohibited indefinitely from slaughtering the animal on account of that blemish. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma before Rabbi Zeira:</b> In the case of <b>one who slits the ear of a firstborn</b> offering <b>and</b> subsequently <b>dies, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to penalizing his son after</b> the father’s death? Does the penalty prohibiting consumption of the firstborn offering extend to the son?
The Gemara compares this dilemma to two similar cases. <b>If you say</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be derived from the case of <b>one who sells his</b> Canaanite <b>slave to gentiles and</b> the seller subsequently <b>dies,</b> where the Sages <b>penalized his son after</b> the father’s death and required him to redeem the slave, this is not a direct parallel. The Gemara explains: It is possible that the penalty is extended to the son only there, <b>as each day</b> that the slave is in the servitude of the gentile master, that master <b>prevents</b> the slave <b>from</b> performing <b>mitzvot.</b> A Canaanite slave is obligated to perform the same mitzvot as a Jewish woman, and he is unable to fulfill the mitzvot when in the possession of a gentile. Since this reason does not apply in a case of a firstborn offering, the case of the Canaanite slave cannot be cited as a source to resolve this dilemma.
And <b>if you say</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be derived from the case of <b>one who planned</b> from the outset to perform <b>his labor on the</b> intermediate days of <b>a Festival,</b> by placing himself in a situation in which the labor should in theory be permitted, i.e., that a significant monetary loss would otherwise be incurred, that comparison is also inaccurate. The Gemara elaborates: In such a case the Sages penalized him by deeming it prohibited for him to perform the labor and by removing his rights to any of the finished products, but if <b>he died</b> before the start of the Festival, <b>they did not penalize his son after</b> the father’s death. This case is not a direct parallel either, as it is possible that it is only there that the penalty is not extended to the son, <b>since</b> the father <b>did not</b> yet <b>perform a prohibited act,</b> as he did not carry out any action on the Festival before he died.
If so, <b>here,</b> in the case of mutilating the ear of a firstborn offering, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Should one say that <b>the Sages penalized</b> only <b>him,</b> i.e., the father, <b>and he is no longer</b> alive? <b>Or perhaps the Sages imposed</b> the <b>penalty upon his property,</b> i.e., that no benefit may be derived from the animal, <b>and that</b> animal still <b>exists</b> in the possession of his heirs.
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>You learned</b> the resolution to your dilemma in a mishna (<i>Shevi’it</i> 4:2). <b>A field whose thorns were removed during the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>may be sown at the conclusion of the Sabbatical</b> Year, as removing thorns is not full-fledged labor that renders the field prohibited. But if <b>it had been improved</b> with fertilizer, or if <b>it had been enclosed</b> so that the animals inside would fertilize it with their manure, <b>it may not be sown at the conclusion of the Sabbatical</b> Year, as both these acts cause significant improvements to the field. The Sages imposed a penalty that one may not derive benefit from prohibited labor. <b>And Rav Asi, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: We have a tradition</b> that if one <b>improved</b> his field in a prohibited manner <b>and</b> then <b>died, his son may sow it. Apparently, the Sages penalized</b> only <b>him,</b> i.e., the father, but <b>the Sages did not penalize his son.</b>
<b>Abaye says: We have a tradition</b>

Daf 35a

that if <b>one rendered impure</b> the <b>ritually pure items</b> of another <b>and died</b> before paying, the Sages <b>did not penalize his son after his</b> death and require him to pay for the damage. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The reason is that <b>damage that is not evident,</b> i.e., which does not involve any visible change, <b>is not considered damage</b> by Torah law. There is <b>a penalty</b> imposed <b>by rabbinic law,</b> as the injured party suffered a loss, but <b>the Sages penalized</b> only <b>him; the Sages did not penalize his son.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There was <b>an incident involving an old ram whose hair was</b> long and <b>dangling,</b> because it was a firstborn offering. <b>And one</b> Roman <b>quaestor [<i>kastor</i>] saw it and said</b> to its owner: <b>What is the status [<i>tivo</i>] of this</b> animal that you allowed it to grow old and you did not slaughter it? <b>They said to him:</b> It <b>is a firstborn</b> offering, <b>and</b> therefore <b>it may be slaughtered only if it has a blemish.</b> The quaestor <b>took a dagger [<i>pigom</i>] and slit its ear. And the incident came before</b> the <b>Sages</b> for a ruling, <b>and they deemed</b> its slaughter <b>permitted. And after</b> the Sages <b>deemed</b> its slaughter <b>permitted,</b> the quaestor <b>went and slit the ears of other firstborn</b> offerings, <b>but</b> in these cases the Sages <b>deemed</b> their slaughter <b>prohibited,</b> despite the fact that they were now blemished.
<b>One time children were playing in the field and they tied the tails of lambs to each other, and the tail of one of them was severed, and it was a firstborn</b> offering. <b>And the incident came before the Sages</b> for a ruling <b>and they deemed</b> its slaughter <b>permitted.</b> The people who <b>saw that they deemed</b> its slaughter <b>permitted went and tied the tails of other firstborn</b> offerings, <b>and</b> the Sages <b>deemed</b> their slaughter <b>prohibited. This</b> is <b>the principle:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> blemish <b>that is</b> caused <b>intentionally,</b> the animal’s slaughter is <b>prohibited;</b> if the blemish is caused <b>unintentionally,</b> the animal’s slaughter is <b>permitted.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna mentions that <b>one time</b> children <b>were</b> involved in a case in which they unintentionally blemished a firstborn offering whose subsequent slaughter the Sages deemed permitted. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> although the first clause of the mishna mentions a similar occurrence, the incident involving the children is <b>necessary. As, had</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the incident involving the <b>gentile,</b> it might have been thought that the Sages permitted the slaughter of the firstborn offering only there, <b>as</b> it is <b>not</b> a problem if the gentile <b>will acquire the habit</b> of causing blemishes, because that prohibition does not apply to gentiles. <b>But</b> with regard to a Jewish <b>minor,</b> it is a concern <b>that he</b> is likely <b>to acquire the habit</b> of causing blemishes in firstborn offerings, and therefore one might <b>say</b> that even the first, unintentional time should <b>not</b> be permitted.
<b>And had</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the incident involving <b>a minor,</b> it might have been thought that the Sages deemed the firstborn offering permitted only there, <b>since</b> there is <b>no</b> concern that people <b>will come to confuse</b> a minor <b>with an adult.</b> People would not erroneously conclude that it is permitted to cause a blemish on a firstborn offering intentionally merely due to an incident involving a minor. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>a gentile</b> adult, where this is a concern <b>that</b> people would <b>come to confuse</b> him <b>with</b> a Jewish <b>adult,</b> one might <b>say</b> that even the first, unintentional time should <b>not</b> be permitted. It is therefore <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach both cases.
§ The Gemara analyzes the incident involving the Roman quaestor. <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Rav Ketina says: They taught</b> that the firstborn offering is permitted <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the bystanders <b>said to</b> the quaestor: A firstborn offering may not be slaughtered <b>unless it has a blemish,</b> as this is referring to a blemish that develops naturally. <b>But if they said to him</b> that a firstborn offering may be slaughtered only <b>if a blemish was caused</b> to form <b>upon it,</b> which indicates human intervention, <b>it is considered as though they</b> explicitly <b>told him: Go and cause a blemish on it,</b> in which case the animal is prohibited.
The Gemara cites a dissenting opinion. <b>Rava said: Now</b> consider, both expressions in fact indicate that the blemish occurred <b>by itself,</b> as both statements are in the passive. Accordingly, <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> whether the bystanders used the expression: If it <b>had</b> a blemish, or the expression: A blemish <b>was caused</b> in it? <b>Rather,</b> the expression: <b>Was caused, also</b> indicates that it occurred <b>by itself, and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> between the expressions. In both instances the firstborn offering would be permitted.
The mishna teaches that <b>this</b> is <b>the principle:</b> In the case of <b>any</b> blemish <b>that is</b> caused <b>with</b> his <b>intent,</b> the animal’s slaughter is <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> does this principle serve <b>to add?</b> It serves <b>to add an indirect</b> action, i.e., a blemish caused in this manner is also considered an intentional act and the animal may not be slaughtered on its account.
The Gemara further inquires: What is added by the phrase in the second part of the principle: If the blemish was caused <b>without</b> his <b>intent,</b> the animal’s slaughter is permitted? This serves <b>to add</b> an instance where a gentile did not inquire about the nature of the firstborn offering, but rather discovered it from one who <b>speaks offhandedly.</b> Although the gentile intentionally caused a blemish in the animal, since the Jew did not intentionally prompt him to cause it, the animal is permitted.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one’s <b>firstborn</b> offering <b>was pursuing him,</b> and <b>he kicked</b> the animal <b>and caused a blemish in it, he may slaughter</b> the animal <b>on</b> account of <b>that</b> blemish.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Pappa says: They taught</b> that the firstborn offering may be slaughtered <b>only</b> in an instance <b>where he kicked it at the time of its pursuit. But</b> if the individual kicked the animal <b>after</b> its <b>pursuit,</b> it may <b>not</b> be slaughtered, as he intended to cause a blemish in order to render it permitted to be slaughtered. The Gemara raises a difficulty: It is <b>obvious</b> that it is not permitted to slaughter the animal in such a case.
The Gemara explains: Rav Pappa’s statement is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that it is in fact permitted to slaughter the firstborn offering since he kicked it after its pursuit only out of anger, as <b>he recalls his distress</b> caused by its pursuit of him, and not in order to render the animal permitted to be slaughtered. Rav Pappa therefore <b>teaches us</b> that it is assumed that he kicked the animal with the express intention of causing a blemish in it, not merely out of anger, and therefore it may not be slaughtered.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> the opposite version of this discussion. <b>Rav Pappa says: Do not say</b> that if the individual kicked the firstborn offering <b>at the time of</b> the <b>pursuit,</b> then <b>yes,</b> it is permitted to slaughter it, <b>but</b> if he kicked it <b>not at the time of</b> the <b>pursuit,</b> it is <b>not</b> permitted to slaughter it. <b>Rather, even</b> if he kicked it <b>after</b> its <b>pursuit</b> of him, it is <b>also</b> permitted. <b>What is the reason?</b> It is assumed that he kicked it after the pursuit not with the intention of causing a blemish, but because <b>he recalls his distress</b> caused by its pursuit of him.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says: It is permitted to cause a blemish in a firstborn</b> fetus <b>before it emerges into the air of the world,</b> as it obtains its sacred status only when it is born. Applying this ruling, <b>Rava said:</b> In the case of <b>a kid,</b> it is practical to cause a blemish <b>on its ear.</b> Since a kid’s ears are long they emerge from the birth canal prior to the head. With regard to <b>a lamb,</b> whose ears are short and do not appear before the head, it is practical to cause a blemish only <b>on its lip. There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that there is a different version of this statement: In the case of <b>a lamb as well,</b> it is practical to cause a blemish <b>on its ear,</b> as one can <b>say</b> that <b>it emerges</b> from the birth canal <b>through its temples,</b> in which case its ears are visible first.
<b>Rava says:</b> In a case where a firstborn has a blemish in its mouth, if, when it <b>eats,</b> the blemish <b>is not visible,</b> but when it opens its mouth wide and <b>cries out, it is visible,</b> this <b>is</b> considered <b>a blemish,</b> rendering the animal fit for slaughter. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this <b>teaching us? We learn</b> this in the mishna (39a) with regard to blemishes that render a firstborn offering fit for slaughter: <b>The external gums that were damaged</b> and lacking or <b>that were scratched,</b> and likewise, <b>the internal</b> gums <b>that were</b> entirely <b>extracted,</b> are considered blemished. <b>What is the reason</b> that if the internal gums were extracted it is considered a blemish? Is it <b>not because when</b> the animal opens its mouth wide and <b>cries out, it is visible?</b> If so, what is the novelty of Rava’s statement?
<b>Rav Pappa says</b> in response: <b>Rava</b> is not in fact teaching a novel <i>halakha</i>. Rather, he <b>is explaining the reason</b> for the ruling <b>of the mishna: What is the reason</b> that if the internal gums <b>were extracted it is</b> considered <b>a blemish?</b> It is <b>that when</b> the animal opens its mouth wide and <b>cries out,</b> the blemish <b>is visible.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>all the blemishes that are capable of being brought about by a person, Israelite shepherds are deemed credible</b> to testify that the blemishes were not caused intentionally. But <b>priest-shepherds are not deemed credible,</b> as they are the beneficiaries if the firstborn is blemished. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> A priest is <b>deemed credible</b> to testify <b>about</b> the firstborn <b>of another, but is not deemed credible</b> to testify <b>about</b> the firstborn belonging <b>to him. Rabbi Meir says:</b> A priest <b>who is suspect about the matter</b> of causing a blemish may <b>neither adjudicate nor testify</b> in cases involving that matter, even on behalf of another.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar</b> disagree with regard to the meaning of the mishna. <b>One</b> of them <b>says</b> that the case of <b>Israelite shepherds</b> is where the shepherds are in <b>the house of priests,</b> i.e., in the employ of a priest. These shepherds are <b>deemed credible</b> to testify that the blemishes were not caused intentionally, as <b>we are not concerned</b> they are lying <b>for a swallow [<i>lilegima</i>]</b> of the firstborn that their priest employer might give them in exchange.
And the case of <b>priest-shepherds</b> is where the shepherds are in <b>the house of an Israelite,</b> i.e., in the latter’s employ. In such a case, the priest-shepherds <b>are not deemed credible</b> to testify that the blemishes were not caused intentionally, as the priest-shepherd <b>can say: Since I have toiled with</b> this firstborn offering, my Israelite employer <b>will not forsake me and give</b> it <b>to another</b> priest. The priest is assumed to be lying, as he has a motive to cause a blemish in the animal.
<b>And the same is true</b> in the case of <b>a priest</b> who testifies <b>for</b> the sake of another <b>priest.</b> Although the first priest would not derive benefit from his testimony immediately, he is nevertheless not deemed credible to testify, <b>as we are concerned about reciprocal</b> behavior, i.e., the other priest might later repay the favor and lie on his behalf.
<b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel comes to say</b> that the testimony of a priest in such a case, when he testifies <b>about</b> the firstborn <b>of another</b> priest, <b>is deemed credible,</b> as there is no concern about reciprocal behavior. But <b>he is not deemed</b> credible <b>with regard to his own</b> firstborn. <b>And Rabbi Meir comes to say</b> that a priest, <b>who is suspect about the matter</b> of causing a blemish, may <b>neither adjudicate nor testify</b> in cases involving that matter, even on behalf of another. The difference between the opinion of Rabbi Meir and that of the first <i>tanna</i> will be discussed further on.
The Gemara cites the other explanation of the mishna: <b>And</b> the other <b>one</b> of the two <i>amora’im</i> <b>says:</b> The case of <b>Israelite shepherds</b> is where the shepherds <b>are priests</b> in the employ of an Israelite. The mishna is teaching that these shepherds <b>are deemed credible</b> to testify that the blemishes on their employer’s firstborn offering were not caused intentionally, as they are not suspected of lying in order to obtain its meat.

Daf 35b

The reason is that it is assumed that the priest-shepherd would <b>say:</b> My Israelite employer <b>will not forsake</b> a priest who is <b>a Torah scholar and give</b> the blemished animal <b>to me,</b> an unlearned shepherd. The case of <b>priest-shepherds</b> is where the shepherds <b>are Israelites</b> in the employ of a priest. These shepherds are <b>not deemed credible</b> to testify, <b>as we are concerned</b> that they might be lying <b>for a swallow</b> of the firstborn that their priest employer would give them in exchange.
<b>And all the more so</b> the testimony of <b>a priest for</b> the sake of another <b>priest</b> is not deemed credible, <b>as we are concerned that</b> the two might engage in <b>reciprocal</b> behavior, <b>and we are concerned</b> that the priest-shepherd might be lying <b>for a swallow</b> of the firstborn offering. <b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel comes to say</b> that the priest-shepherd <b>is deemed credible</b> to testify <b>with regard to</b> the firstborn offering <b>of another</b> priest, <b>but is not deemed credible</b> to testify <b>with regard to</b> a firstborn belonging to <b>himself. And Rabbi Meir comes to say</b> that a priest <b>who is suspect about the matter</b> of causing a blemish may <b>neither adjudicate nor testify</b> in cases involving that matter, even on behalf of another.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Granted, according to</b> the second opinion, i.e., <b>the one who says</b> the first <i>tanna</i> maintains that the case of <b>Israelite shepherds</b> is where the shepherds <b>are priests</b> in the employ of an Israelite, and they <b>are deemed credible</b> to testify, <b>this is</b> the reason <b>that Rabbi Meir comes to</b> disagree and <b>say</b> that a priest <b>who is suspect about the matter</b> of causing a blemish may <b>neither adjudicate nor testify</b> even for the sake of an Israelite employer.
<b>But according to</b> the first opinion, i.e., <b>the one who says</b> that the first <i>tanna</i> maintains that the case of <b>priest-shepherds</b> is where the shepherds are in <b>an Israelite’s house,</b> and they <b>are not deemed credible</b> to testify, <b>what is Rabbi Meir coming to teach us? This is</b> the same opinion as that of the <b>first <i>tanna</i></b> himself.
The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between</b> the opinions of the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Meir <b>with regard to</b> a statement <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Kefusai. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Kefusai says:</b> If <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>in the house of a priest</b> developed a blemish, <b>two</b> people <b>from the marketplace,</b> i.e., not from the priest’s household, are <b>required to testify about it</b> that the blemish was not caused deliberately. This unqualified statement indicates that the two people can even be priests, provided that they are not household members.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even</b> the priest’s <b>son</b> and <b>even his daughter</b> may testify about it. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even</b> in a case where there are <b>ten</b> people, if <b>they are members of his household, they may not testify about it.</b> The first <i>tanna</i> of the mishna maintains that only a priest who is a shepherd of the animal in question is not deemed credible to testify, but the testimony of an independent priest is credible. This accords with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Kefusai, who allows the testimony of any two independent people, including a priest. Conversely, Rabbi Meir does not deem credible even the testimony of an independent priest, as indicated by his general statement about suspect priests.
The Gemara discusses a related statement: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Rav Ketina says:</b> In the case of an animal whose status as a <b>firstborn</b> is <b>uncertain that was born</b> in the <b>house,</b> i.e., in the possession, <b>of an Israelite,</b> e.g., it was uncertain whether the mother had previously given birth, in which case the animal remains in the possession of the Israelite and may be eaten upon developing a blemish, <b>two</b> people <b>from the marketplace</b> are <b>required to testify about it?</b>
<b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this statement? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Kefusai.</b> Just as he requires two independent people to testify about a firstborn offering in the possession of a priest, as he is suspected of intentionally causing the blemish, so too, he requires two independent people to testify in the case of an uncertain status of a firstborn offering born in the possession of an Israelite.
<b>Rav Naḥman</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> The Israelite <b>owners</b> themselves <b>may testify about it. As, if you do not say so,</b> but instead maintain that any involved person is suspected of deliberately causing a blemish in his firstborn animal, this poses a difficulty with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, which may also be eaten if it developed a blemish. <b>According to Rabbi Meir, who can testify about it?</b> Rabbi Meir maintains that anyone who is suspect about the matter of causing a blemish on his own behalf may neither adjudicate nor testify in cases involving that matter even on behalf of another. If so, how can anyone, even an Israelite, testify about any blemished animal-tithe offering? It must be that an Israelite is not suspected of deliberately causing blemishes.
The Gemara rejects this claim: With regard to the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, the owner is <b>certainly deemed credible</b> to testify that its blemish occurred naturally, <b>because if he wants,</b> he could legitimately <b>cause a blemish in his entire flock</b> before the obligation to separate tithes came into effect. <b>Rather,</b> this is what Rav Naḥman stated: If an Israelite is not deemed credible to testify about a blemish found on an animal whose status as a <b>firstborn</b> is <b>uncertain,</b> then <b>according to Rabbi Meir, who can testify about it?</b> Both Israelites and priests stand to gain if their animal whose status as a firstborn is uncertain develops a blemish, and therefore no one should be deemed credible to testify about it.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>indeed,</b> according to Rabbi Meir, an animal whose status as a firstborn is uncertain <b>has no remedy</b> that can render it fit for slaughter, as no one is deemed credible to testify about its blemish, this cannot be correct. <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (18b) <b>that Rabbi Yosei would say: Any</b> animal <b>whose replacements</b> are <b>in the possession of a priest is exempt from,</b> i.e., not subject to, the mitzva of giving <b>the</b> priestly <b>gifts, and Rabbi Meir deems</b> him <b>obligated</b> to give the gifts? Since Rabbi Meir permits the consumption of an animal whose status as a firstborn is uncertain, evidently he allows testimony about its blemish in such a case.
<b>Rather, learn from this</b> that the Israelite <b>owners may testify about</b> their animals whose status as a firstborn are uncertain, despite the fact that priests may not. The reason is that <b>it is</b> only <b>priests who are suspected of</b> causing <b>blemishes; Israelites are not suspected of</b> causing <b>blemishes.</b>
§ It <b>was stated: Rav Naḥman says</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> that a priest is deemed credible to testify about the blemished firstborn animal of another priest, even if he is a household member. <b>Rava says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> that one’s household members are not deemed credible to testify.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rava</b> actually <b>say this? But doesn’t Rava say:</b> If the priestly <b>owner</b> of a firstborn animal was <b>standing outside with us,</b> and the animal <b>entered</b> the house <b>whole and emerged injured,</b> the household members <b>may testify about it</b> that the blemish was not caused by a person. Evidently, Rava maintains that the members of the priest’s household are deemed credible to testify about the priest’s firstborn. The Gemara answers: One can <b>say</b> that Rava is referring to a case where <b>all the owners,</b> i.e., the household members, <b>are standing outside,</b> while the shepherd alone remains inside. When the firstborn animal emerges injured, the shepherd is deemed credible to testify about the blemish <b>and we are not concerned</b> that he is lying.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that all of the household members were outside, <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> that the shepherd is deemed credible? This ruling is obvious. The Gemara answers: This ruling is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>we should entertain a suspicion</b> that the shepherd himself caused the blemish. Rava therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so, and the shepherd is deemed credible. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> that a priest’s household members may testify about his blemished firstborn offering. <b>And</b> this applies <b>specifically</b> to <b>his son and daughter, but his wife</b> may <b>not</b> testify. <b>What is the reason? One’s wife is as oneself.</b>
§ <b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: According to Rabbi Meir, who says that</b> a priest <b>who is suspect about the matter</b> of causing a blemish may <b>neither adjudicate nor testify</b> in cases involving that matter even on behalf of another, <b>and</b> in addition <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that <b>one who is suspected of</b> transgressing <b>one matter,</b> i.e., who is known to have committed one transgression, <b>is suspected of</b> transgressing <b>the entire Torah,</b> it should follow that <b>priests</b> should <b>also not</b> be allowed to <b>administer judgment</b> at all. <b>But isn’t it written</b> with regard to the priests: <b>“And according to their word shall every controversy and every stroke be”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:5)?

Daf 36a

The Gemara answers: One can <b>say that Rabbi Meir says</b> that priests are suspect with regard to causing blemishes only to the extent <b>that</b> there is <b>a concern</b> that they might have caused a blemish. But <b>did he say</b> this ruling <b>to establish them</b> as those who definitely cause blemishes? Certainly not.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>testimony</b> based on <b>hearsay,</b> where one repeats the testimony of another witness, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>in</b> a case of such <b>testimony</b> about a blemished <b>firstborn</b> animal? <b>Rav Asi deems prohibited</b> the slaughter of the animal based on such testimony, <b>and Rav Ashi deems</b> it <b>permitted. Rav Asi said to Rav Ashi: But isn’t it taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i> in the <b>school of Menashe</b> that <b>hearsay testimony is valid only for</b> the <b>testimony of a woman,</b> where one testifies that her husband is dead? This indicates that such testimony is not accepted in all other instances.
Rav Ashi responded: Emend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>teach</b> it like this: Testimony based on hearsay is valid <b>only for</b> that <b>testimony for which</b> the testimony of <b>a woman is valid.</b> According to Rav Ashi, the <i>baraita</i> is teaching that any case where the testimony of a woman is valid, hearsay testimony is valid as well, and this includes testimony concerning a blemished firstborn animal.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Yeimar deemed fit testimony</b> based on <b>hearsay with regard to</b> a blemished <b>firstborn</b> animal. <b>Mareimar</b> condescendingly <b>called him: Yeimar</b> who <b>permits firstborn</b> animals. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>testimony</b> based on <b>hearsay is valid</b> in the case <b>of a firstborn</b> animal.
§ The Gemara discusses a related matter. <b>Rabbi Ile’a says:</b> In a case where a blemished animal <b>was not established as being a firstborn, and one</b> priest <b>came</b> to an expert <b>and said that it is a firstborn</b> animal <b>and</b> yet <b>its blemish is with it,</b> i.e., it was unintentionally blemished, <b>he is deemed credible,</b> and the expert may deem the animal fit for slaughter based on the priest’s testimony.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rabbi Ile’a <b>teaching us?</b> Is he teaching us the principle <b>that the mouth that prohibited</b> it <b>is the mouth that permitted</b> it, i.e., when the only source that an item was prohibited is the statement of one who says that it is now permitted, his claim is accepted? But <b>we learn</b> this in a mishna (<i>Ketubot</i> 22a): With regard to <b>a woman who said: I was a married woman and</b> now <b>I am a divorcée, she is deemed credible</b> and permitted to remarry, <b>as the mouth that prohibited</b> her by establishing that she was married <b>is the mouth that permitted</b> her by establishing that she was divorced.
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Ile’a’s statement is necessary, <b>lest you say it is</b> only <b>there,</b> in the case of the mishna, that the woman’s testimony is accepted, <b>as, if she wants</b> to remarry illegally, <b>she</b> does <b>not</b> need to <b>say</b> anything at all about previously being married. <b>But here,</b> with regard to the firstborn animal, it is different, <b>as,</b> if the priest wishes to eat the meat of the animal, <b>it not sufficient</b> for him <b>not to</b> bring the animal to an expert, i.e., he has no recourse other than to <b>say</b> that it is a firstborn animal which has a blemish requiring examination, <b>as</b> he cannot determine on his own whether this blemish permanently disqualifies the firstborn animal from sacrifice, and <b>he would not eat sacrificial</b> meat <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, which is punishable by <i>karet</i>.
Since the priest must admit that this is a firstborn animal, <b>I</b> might <b>say</b> that <b>this is not</b> a case of: <b>The mouth that prohibited</b> it is the mouth that permitted it, and therefore the priest is not deemed credible. To dispel this possibility, Rabbi Ile’a <b>teaches us</b> that he is deemed credible, <b>because if it due to that</b> reason, that the priest is suspected of causing the blemish, <b>he would have caused a blemish that</b> is <b>obvious to all.</b> In such a case, he would violate a mere prohibition, not one that is punishable by <i>karet</i>, since he would not be eating sacrificial meat outside the Temple courtyard, as the animal is blemished.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi objects to this: What is different</b> between this case and <b>that</b> incident involving <b>a certain man who rented a donkey to another?</b> The owner <b>said to</b> the renter: <b>Look, do not go on the path of Nehar Pekod, where there is water</b> and the donkey is likely to drown. Instead, <b>go on the path of Neresh, where there is no water.</b> The renter <b>went on the path of Nehar Pekod and the donkey died. When he came</b> back, <b>he said:</b> Yes, <b>I went on the path of Nehar Pekod, but there was no water</b> there, and therefore the donkey’s death was caused by other factors.
<b>And Rava said:</b> The renter’s claim is accepted, due to the reasoning of: <b>Why would he lie</b> and state this claim? In other words, <b>if</b> this man <b>wanted</b> to lie, <b>he</b> could have <b>told</b> the donkey’s owner: <b>I went on the path of Neresh,</b> as the owner instructed. <b>And Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>We do not say</b> the principle of: <b>Why would he lie, in a place</b> where there are <b>witnesses.</b> Since witnesses can be summoned to establish conclusively whether there was water along the path of Nehar Pekod, the reasoning that the renter could have stated a different claim is not employed. Similarly, the priest’s contention that the blemish occurred inadvertently should not be deemed credible, as it is known that priests are suspected of causing blemishes.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> with regard to the path of Nehar Pekod, <b>there is certainly water there, but</b> here, the possibility <b>that</b> the priest <b>caused a blemish in</b> the firstborn animal <b>is</b> only <b>a concern, and in a place of</b> mere <b>concern we</b> do <b>say</b> the reasoning of: <b>Why would he lie?</b> The Gemara relates that <b>Ravina was sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i></b> of Rabbi Ile’a <b>anonymously. Rava Zuti said to Ravina: We learned this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>in the name of Rabbi Ile’a.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Tzadok,</b> an erudite priest, <b>had a firstborn</b> animal. <b>He placed barley in</b> wicker <b>baskets for it,</b> and <b>while it was eating, its lip split,</b> rendering the animal blemished. Rabbi Tzadok <b>came before Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> to ask whether or not he is suspected of intentionally causing a blemish in his firstborn animal offering. Rabbi Tzadok <b>said to him: Didn’t we differentiate between</b> a priest who is <b>a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> i.e., learned, <b>and</b> a priest who is <b>an ignoramus,</b> with regard to their credibility about blemishes found on a firstborn animal? <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: Yes,</b> we did. Since you are a learned priest, you are deemed credible to testify that this blemish was caused inadvertently.
Rabbi Tzadok then <b>came before Rabban Gamliel,</b> the <i>Nasi</i> and head of the academy of Yavne at the time. Rabbi Tzadok <b>said to him:</b> Didn’t <b>we differentiate between</b> a priest who is <b>a <i>ḥaver</i> and</b> a priest who is <b>an ignoramus</b> with regard to credibility about blemishes found on a firstborn animal? <b>Rabban Gamliel said to him: No,</b> we did not. Rabbi Tzadok <b>said to him: But Rabbi Yehoshua said to me</b> that <b>yes,</b> we did differentiate in this manner. Rabban Gamliel <b>said to</b> Rabbi Tzadok: <b>Wait until the masters of the shields [<i>ba’alei terisin</i>],</b> a reference to the Torah scholars who battle in the war of Torah, <b>enter the study hall,</b> at which point we will discuss this issue.
<b>When</b> the Torah scholars <b>entered the study hall, the questioner stood</b> before everyone present <b>and asked:</b> With regard to blemishes found on a firstborn animal, <b>didn’t we differentiate between</b> a priest who is <b>a <i>ḥaver</i> and</b> a priest who is <b>an ignoramus? Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: No,</b> we did not. <b>Rabban Gamliel said to him: But they said to me in your name</b> that <b>yes,</b> we did differentiate.
Rabban Gamliel continued: <b>Yehoshua, stand on your feet and they will testify against you</b> that you did, in fact, say that we differentiated in such a case. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua stood on his feet and said: How should I act</b> in this situation? <b>If I were alive and</b> Rabbi Tzadok <b>were dead, the living can contradict the dead,</b> and I could deny issuing that ruling. <b>Now that I am alive and he is alive, how can the living contradict the living?</b> I have no choice but to admit that I said it.
In the meantime, <b>Rabban Gamliel was standing and lecturing, and Rabbi Yehoshua</b> all the while <b>was standing on his feet,</b> as Rabban Gamliel did not instruct him to sit. He remained standing in deference to the <i>Nasi</i>. This continued for some time, <b>until</b> it aroused great resentment against Rabban Gamliel, and <b>all of the people</b> assembled began <b>murmuring and said to Ḥutzpit the disseminator: Stop</b> conveying Rabban Gamliel’s lecture, <b>and he stopped.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A priest is deemed credible to say: I showed this firstborn</b> animal to an expert <b>and</b> he ruled that <b>it is blemished.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: A priest is deemed credible to say: An Israelite gave me this firstborn</b> animal <b>with its blemish</b> already inflicted upon it. <b>What is the reason?</b> With regard to <b>any matter that is likely to be revealed, people do not lie about it.</b> Since the Israelite can be questioned with regard to the veracity of the priest’s claim, it is assumed that the priest will not risk lying. <b>Rav Ashi said: We learn</b> a similar principle in the mishna <b>as well: A priest is deemed credible to say: I showed this firstborn</b> animal to an expert <b>and</b> he ruled that <b>it is blemished. What is the reason</b> the priest’s claim is deemed credible? <b>Is it not because we say</b> that with regard to <b>any matter that is likely to be revealed, people do not lie about it?</b>
The Gemara rejects the claim that the mishna’s ruling is based on the principle that people do not lie about a matter that is likely to be revealed: Perhaps <b>there,</b> in the case of the mishna, the reason the priest’s claim is accepted is that <b>he</b> would <b>not eat sacrificial</b> meat <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard. If an expert had not permitted the meat, the priest would not eat it. <b>But here,</b> in Rav’s case, where the priest claims an Israelite gave him an already blemished animal, <b>since</b> priests <b>are suspected</b> of causing blemishes and claiming that it was inadvertent, <b>they are</b> also <b>suspected</b> of causing a blemish and claiming it was given to them in that state by an Israelite.
<b>Rav Sheizevi raises an objection</b> to Rav’s ruling from a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 4:5): In the case of <b>one who says to someone who is not trusted with regard to tithe: Purchase</b> produce <b>for me from someone who is trusted</b> with regard to tithes, i.e., one who does not purchase produce from an ignoramus, who generally does not separate tithes; <b>or</b> if he says: Purchase produce for me <b>from someone who tithes,</b> i.e., even from one who purchases produce from an ignoramus but is careful to set aside tithes upon purchasing the produce, the agent <b>is not deemed credible</b> to claim that he fulfilled the condition of the one who appointed him. According to Rav, <b>why</b> isn’t the agent deemed credible? <b>Say</b> the principle that with regard to <b>any matter that is likely to be revealed, people do not lie about it.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there,</b>

Daf 36b

<b>as he has</b> the easy option <b>of extricating himself</b> from the accusation that he did not fulfill the condition of the one who appointed him, by claiming that in his opinion the individual from whom he purchased the produce was to be trusted. Since the issue of the third party’s trustworthiness is subjective, the agent is not afraid to lie.
The Gemara suggests: The <b>latter clause</b> of this mishna <b>certainly supports</b> the ruling of Rav, that people do not lie with regard to any matter that will be revealed. How so? The latter clause states that if the one instructed the agent to purchase produce specifically <b>from so-and-so,</b> who is reliable with regard to tithes, then <b>this</b> agent <b>is deemed credible</b> to claim that he adhered to the instructions. Since the one who appointed him mentioned a specific individual, the agent is not suspected of lying, as that individual can be subsequently questioned.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>There,</b> in the mishna, <b>since</b> the agent <b>has a claimant, he is afraid</b> to lie. In other words, since the one who appointed him specified an individual, the agent presumes that he intends to verify the matter, and therefore he will not risk lying. By contrast, in Rav’s case, since it was the priest who volunteered the information that a specific Israelite gave him an already blemished firstborn animal, he is not concerned that the examiner might seek out the Israelite to confirm the actual facts.
Upon hearing Rav Yehuda’s statement in the name of Rav, <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said: From where does Yehuda</b> know <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? Actually, <b>I taught this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>to Giddul</b> in Rav’s name <b>and Giddul,</b> in turn, <b>taught it to</b> Rabbi Yehuda. <b>But</b> Giddul corrupted my statement, as <b>this is how I said it to him: An Israelite is deemed credible to say: I gave this firstborn</b> animal <b>to a priest with its blemish</b> already inflicted upon it, and it may be slaughtered and eaten.
The Gemara asks: <b>An Israelite?</b> It is <b>obvious</b> that he is deemed credible to issue this claim, as he has no use for the firstborn animal. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this ruling is <b>necessary,</b> as it is referring <b>to</b> an animal that was <b>young</b> when the Israelite gave it to the priest <b>and it grew older</b> by the time of his testimony. This ruling is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that as the animal grew older in the interim, perhaps the Israelite <b>does not recognize it</b> and mistakenly assumes that it was the animal he gave the priest, when in fact it is a different firstborn animal upon which the priest intentionally caused a blemish. Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the Israelite is trusted to recognize the animal he gave the priest.
The Gemara notes: <b>In Sura, they teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the latter version,</b> as stated by Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba, that an Israelite is deemed credible to testify. <b>In Pumbedita,</b> they teach the <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the first version,</b> as taught by Rav Yehuda, citing Rav, that even a priest is deemed credible if he claims that an Israelite gave him an already blemished firstborn animal. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with even the first version.</b>
In this regard, the Gemara relates that <b>Rafram,</b> who resided <b>in Pumbedita, had a firstborn</b> animal <b>and he gave it to a priest</b> in <b>an unblemished</b> state. The priest <b>went and caused a blemish in it. One day,</b> Rafram <b>had an affliction in his eyes,</b> which rendered it difficult for him to open them. The priest to whom Rafram had given the firstborn animal <b>brought it before him,</b> as an expert examiner, for him to deem the animal permitted. The priest <b>said to him: An Israelite gave me this firstborn</b> animal <b>with its blemish</b> upon it. Rafram <b>forced his eyes open</b> and <b>saw</b> the animal and <b>recognized it [<i>bashkerei</i>]</b> as the one he himself had given the priest. Rafram <b>said to</b> the priest: <b>Is it not I who gave this</b> firstborn animal <b>to you?</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And even so,</b> Rafram <b>was unconcerned by the matter</b> of the priest’s attempted chicanery, as he maintained that it is only <b>this</b> priest <b>who is impudent,</b> but <b>all other</b> priests <b>are not impudent.</b> This scenario did not cause Rafram to discredit any other priest’s claim that he received a blemished firstborn animal from an Israelite, as this was an exceptional case. This priest demonstrated extreme impudence by bringing it to be examined by Rafram himself, and therefore one cannot draw conclusions about the behavior of other priests from this incident.
§ The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain</b> firstborn animal, <b>one</b> of whose eyes <b>was larger than the other, whose</b> owner <b>came before Rav Ashi</b> to have it deemed fit for slaughter on account of its blemish. Uncertain as to who brought the animal for examination, Rav Ashi <b>said: For what should we be concerned with regard to this</b> animal? In a case of such a blemish, <b>whether it is a priest</b> who brought it for examination, or <b>whether it is an Israelite,</b> there is no concern that the blemish might have been intentionally caused, as <b>this is</b> clearly <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>whose blemish</b> was already <b>with it</b> naturally.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: But perhaps it is an Israelite</b> who brought the firstborn animal, <b>and Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>one may not examine the firstborn</b> animal <b>of an Israelite unless a priest is</b> present <b>with him</b> in order to receive the animal if it is established as fit for slaughter. Rav Yehuda is concerned that if the Israelite’s firstborn animal is deemed fit for slaughter when no priest is present, the Israelite might improperly use the animal for his own purposes. If so, how can you, Rav Ashi, say that there is no problem if this animal was brought by an Israelite?
Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Ravina in response: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> where the presence of a priest is required, it is referring to a case where the halakhic status of the blemish has yet to be determined. Now, <b>granted</b> an Israelite <b>will not</b> risk <b>eating sacrificial</b> meat <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, as that incurs a penalty of <i>karet</i>, and he therefore would have the blemish’s status determined by an expert. But <b>he is suspected with regard to the property of a priest.</b> Although the Israelite will have the status of the animal confirmed before risking a prohibition that entails <i>karet</i>, he might steal the firstborn offering if it is established as fit for consumption.
Conversely, <b>here,</b> in the case of the animal that had one eye larger than the other, <b>since</b> even an Israelite <b>knows that this is a clear-cut blemish</b> and the animal is clearly fit for slaughter, <b>what is the reason he brought</b> the animal <b>before the Sages</b> for examination? He brought it <b>out of respect for the Sage.</b> Now, if this Israelite <b>does not neglect the respect due a Sage,</b> would <b>he commit a transgression</b> and steal the possession of the priest? Certainly not. Therefore, in our case an Israelite would be trustworthy, and the presence of a priest is unnecessary.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Everyone is deemed credible</b> to testify <b>about the blemishes of</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, even the owner who is the beneficiary of a ruling that it is blemished.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is the reason</b> that even the owner is deemed credible to testify? The reason is <b>that had he wanted, he could have caused a blemish in it initially,</b> in a permitted manner, before tithing his animals. The Gemara raises a difficulty: But when he leads his animals out of the gate in order to tithe them, <b>does he know which</b> of them <b>will emerge</b> as the tenth, that you say he could have initially blemished that specific animal before it assumed the tithe status?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>he</b> intentionally <b>leads</b> an animal <b>out as the head of the ten,</b> i.e., so that it is the last of ten to emerge, one may not do so, as <b>the Merciful One states: “He shall not search whether it be good or bad”</b> (Leviticus 27:33), which teaches that the animal tithe may not be led out intentionally but must exit of its own accord. <b>Rather,</b> this is the meaning of the Gemara’s initial answer: The reason is <b>that had he wanted, he could have caused a blemish in his entire flock,</b> in a permitted manner, before leading them through the gate in order to tithe them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>whose eye was blinded or whose foreleg was severed or whose hind leg was broken,</b> all of which obviously render the animal permanently blemished, that animal <b>may be slaughtered on the basis of</b> the ruling of <b>three</b> regular Jews <b>who attend the synagogue,</b> and it does not require a ruling by one of the Sages. <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> disagrees and <b>says: Even if there is</b> a court of <b>twenty-three</b> Sages <b>there, it may be slaughtered only on the basis of</b> the ruling of <b>an expert</b> in judging blemishes.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Simlai and Rabbi Yehuda Nesia both say in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Simlai and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi both say in the name of Rabbi Yehuda Nesia: The permitting of</b> the slaughter of <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>outside</b> of <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael, where a firstborn offering is unfit for sacrifice even when the Temple is standing, may be performed <b>on the basis of</b> the ruling of <b>three</b> regular Jews <b>who attend the synagogue. Rava said: And</b> this ruling applies specifically in a case <b>of clear-cut blemishes,</b> i.e., those blemishes which clearly permit the slaughter of the firstborn animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rava <b>teaching us</b> by this statement? <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> this in the mishna: With regard to <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>whose eye was blinded or whose foreleg was severed or whose hind leg was broken,</b> that animal <b>may be slaughtered on the basis of</b> the ruling of <b>three</b> regular Jews <b>who attend the synagogue.</b> The mishna is referring to clear-cut blemishes in contemporary times, in the absence of the Temple, when a firstborn animal is unfit to be brought as an offering. What, then, is the novelty of Rava’s statement?
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> that three regular Jews may permit the slaughter of a firstborn animal is learned <b>from the mishna</b> alone, <b>I would say</b> that according to the mishna, the power invested in three regular Jews to permit the slaughter of a firstborn animal in the absence of the Temple nowadays, or <b>outside</b> of <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael during Temple times, applies <b>even</b> to a firstborn animal that has <b>blemishes that are not clear-cut. And</b> the reason <b>that</b> the mishna specifically <b>teaches</b> a case of <b>clear-cut</b> blemishes is <b>to convey the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei,</b> who requires the examination of an expert even in such a case. Rava therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so; rather, the mishna’s ruling is referring specifically to a case of clear-cut blemishes.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says</b> the following <i>halakha</i>, but he was <b>uncertain</b> whether Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said it <b>in the name of Rav</b> and <b>uncertain</b> whether he said it <b>in the name of Shmuel: Three</b> regular Jews <b>may permit a firstborn</b> animal with clear-cut blemishes <b>in a place where there is no expert.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rav Yehuda <b>teaching us</b> by this statement? <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> this in the mishna: That animal <b>may be slaughtered on the basis of</b> the ruling <b>of three</b> regular Jews <b>who attend the synagogue.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> is learned <b>from the mishna</b> alone, <b>I would say</b> that three laymen may permit a firstborn animal with clear-cut blemishes even <b>in a place</b> where there is <b>an expert.</b> Rav Yehuda therefore <b>teaches us</b> that <b>in a place where there is no expert, yes,</b> three laymen may permit it. But <b>in a place where there is an expert,</b> three laymen are <b>not</b> invested with this power.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Amram says:</b> A group of <b>three</b> laymen may <b>permit</b> a blemished <b>firstborn</b> animal <b>in a place where there is no expert</b> to consult, and likewise a group of <b>three</b> laymen may <b>dissolve a vow in a place where there is no Sage.</b> The Gemara explains: The ruling that a group of <b>three</b> laymen may <b>permit</b> a blemished <b>firstborn</b> animal <b>in a place where there is no expert</b> to consult

Daf 37a

is <b>to the exclusion of</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei</b> in the mishna, who prohibits any number of laymen to deem a firstborn animal permitted. The ruling that a group of <b>three</b> laymen may <b>dissolve a vow in a place where there is no Sage</b> is <b>to the exclusion of</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Dissolution of vows</b> requires a court of <b>three. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> only if at least <b>one of them</b> is <b>a Sage.</b> If no Sage is available, laymen may not dissolve a vow.
Rav Ḥiyya bar Amram stated above that a group of three may dissolve a vow <b>in a place where there is no Sage.</b> This indicates that if there is a Sage, he alone may dissolve a vow.
