The Gemara asks: <b>Who, for example,</b> is considered such a Sage? <b>Rav Naḥman said: For example,</b> one such as <b>me.</b> The <i>baraita</i> further stated that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> At least <b>one of</b> the three laymen must be <b>a Sage.</b> The Gemara asks: Should one conclude <b>by inference that those</b> other two members can be <b>anyone,</b> even complete ignoramuses? <b>Ravina said</b> in explanation: Each member of the group must be one <b>to whom</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of vows <b>is explained and he</b> is able to <b>comprehend</b> them.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even if there is</b> a court of <b>twenty-three</b> Sages <b>there,</b> it may be slaughtered only on the basis of the ruling of an expert. <b>Rav Ḥananel says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> The Gemara challenges: This is <b>obvious,</b> as there is a principle that in a dispute between <b>an individual</b> Sage <b>and many</b> Sages, the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of the <b>many</b> Sages. The Gemara answers: Rav’s statement is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that Rabbi Yosei is an exception to the principle, as <b>his reasoning [<i>nimmuko</i>] is with him,</b> i.e., his logic is sound. Rav Ḥananel therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so, and the <i>halakha</i> does not follow his opinion.
Earlier (36b), the Gemara cited a ruling, which was issued either by Rav or Shmuel, that three regular Jews may deem a firstborn animal permitted in a place where there is no expert, in contrast to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. The Gemara suggests: <b>Resolve</b> that dilemma <b>from this</b> statement in the name of Rav, that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. It can be inferred from here <b>that that first,</b> uncertain ruling <b>was stated in the name of Shmuel. As, if</b> it was stated <b>in the name of Rav, why do I</b> need <b>two</b> identical rulings?
The Gemara answers: This is insufficient proof, as it is possible that Rav did not issue two identical rulings. Rather, <b>one</b> ruling <b>was stated from the other, by inference.</b> Rav issued only one of these statements explicitly; the other was reported by his students in his name based on an inference from what he had said.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughters a firstborn</b> animal and sells its meat, <b>and it was discovered that he did not</b> initially <b>show it</b> to one of the Sages, the <i>halakha</i> is that it was actually prohibited to derive any benefit from the meat. In that case, <b>what</b> the buyers <b>ate, they ate, and</b> the Sages penalized the seller in that <b>he must return the money to them,</b> which they paid for the meat that they ate. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which they did not eat,</b> that <b>meat must be buried, and he must return the money</b> that they paid for the meat that they did not eat.
<b>And likewise,</b> in the case of <b>one who slaughters a cow and sells it, and it was discovered that it is a <i>tereifa</i>, what</b> the buyers <b>ate, they ate, and what they did not eat, they must return the meat to</b> the seller, who may sell it to a gentile or feed it to the dogs, <b>and he must return the money to</b> the buyers. If the buyers <b>sold it to gentiles or cast it to the dogs, they pay</b> the seller <b>the value of a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> which is less than the value of kosher meat, and the seller refunds the balance to the buyers.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>one sells meat to another and it was discovered</b> that it is the <b>meat</b> of <b>a firstborn</b> animal, which was not deemed permitted for consumption by an expert, or if one sells <b>produce</b> to another <b>and it was discovered</b> that it is <b>untithed produce,</b> or if one sells <b>wine</b> to another <b>and it turns out</b> that it is <b>wine</b> that was used for <b>a libation</b> in idol worship, the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>what</b> the purchasers <b>ate, they ate, and</b> the seller <b>reimburses them</b> all their <b>money.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says,</b> qualifying this ruling: If he sold them <b>items from which one is</b> generally <b>repulsed, he must reimburse them</b> all their <b>money,</b> as they are presumed to not have derived benefit from the consumption of such items. <b>But</b> if he sold them <b>items from which one is not</b> generally <b>repulsed, he deducts for them the value</b> of the benefit from those items and reimburses them the balance. <b>And the following are items from which one is</b> generally <b>repulsed: Carcasses and <i>tereifot</i>, repugnant creatures, and creeping animals. And the following are items from which one is</b> generally <b>not repulsed: Firstborn</b> animals, <b>untithed produce, and wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> in idol worship.
The Gemara asks: Why does the seller deduct the value of the meat of <b>a firstborn</b> animal eaten by the purchaser and reimburse him the difference? <b>Let</b> the purchaser <b>say to</b> the seller: <b>What loss have I caused you</b> by eating the meat? Had you not sold it to me, you would have had no rights to partake of it, as this is an unblemished firstborn animal from which deriving benefit is prohibited.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this ruling is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where he sold him</b> a cut of meat <b>from an area</b> on the animal that contained <b>a blemish,</b> but the seller had not yet brought the animal to be examined and deemed permitted by a Sage. In <b>that</b> instance, the seller can <b>say to</b> the purchaser: <b>Had you not eaten</b> the meat, <b>I would have shown</b> the animal to a Sage <b>and he</b> would have <b>deemed it permitted</b> to me. The Gemara notes that this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> (28a), who permits a firstborn animal to be examined and deemed permitted even after it has been slaughtered.
The Gemara adds that with regard to <b>untithed produce,</b> although one could claim that the purchaser did not cause a loss to the seller, as untithed produce is prohibited for consumption, the seller can say to the purchaser: Had you not eaten my produce, <b>I would have remedied it,</b> i.e., separated its tithes, <b>and eaten it.</b> Similarly, with regard to <b>wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> in idol worship, which is also prohibited to be consumed, this is referring to a seller who sold it <b>in a mixture</b> of permitted wine. In this case, had the purchaser not consumed the wine mixture, the seller could have derived benefit from it, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Avoda Zara</i> 74a): In the case of <b>wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> in idol worship <b>that fell into</b> a wine <b>cistern,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> to <b>derive benefit</b> from <b>all</b> the wine in the cistern, even if the volume of the wine used for a libation was small in comparison to the volume of the rest of the wine in the cistern. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: All of the</b> wine in the cistern <b>may be sold to a gentile,</b> and the money paid for it is permitted, <b>except for the value of the wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> that is <b>in it.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>For these blemishes, one may slaughter the firstborn</b> animal outside the Temple: If the firstborn’s <b>ear was damaged</b> and lacking <b>from the cartilage [<i>haḥasḥus</i>], but not</b> if <b>the skin</b> was damaged; and likewise, if the ear <b>was split, although it is not lacking;</b> or if the ear <b>was pierced</b> with a hole <b>the size of a bitter vetch,</b> which is a type of legume; <b>or</b> if it was an ear <b>that</b> is <b>desiccated. What is a desiccated</b> ear that is considered a blemish? It is <b>any</b> ear <b>that</b> if <b>it is pierced it does not discharge a drop of blood. Rabbi Yosei ben HaMeshullam says: Desiccated</b> means that the ear is so dry <b>that it will crumble</b> if one touches it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the blemishes mentioned in this mishna and in the subsequent <i>mishnayot</i>, the Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is it permitted to slaughter and eat a firstborn that sustained these blemishes? Only <b>a lame</b> animal <b>and a blind</b> animal are <b>written</b> in the verse that discusses this <i>halakha</i>. That verse states: “And if there be any blemish therein, lameness, or blindness, any ill blemish whatsoever, you shall not sacrifice it to the Lord your God. You shall eat it within your gates” (Deuteronomy 15:21–22).
The Gemara answers: <b>It is also written</b> in the beginning of the verse: <b>“If there be any blemish therein,”</b> which indicates that other blemishes are also included. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that the phrase <b>“if there be any blemish therein”</b> is <b>a generalization,</b> while <b>“lameness, or blindness”</b> is <b>a detail.</b> According to the principles of midrashic exegesis, if <b>a generalization and a detail</b> are mentioned, <b>the generalization includes only that which is</b> specified <b>in the detail.</b> Therefore, it should be concluded that in the event of <b>lameness and blindness, yes,</b> one may slaughter the firstborn, but in the event of <b>another matter,</b> one may <b>not</b> slaughter it.
The Gemara answers: By subsequently stating: <b>“Any ill blemish,” it then generalized</b> again. Consequently, it is <b>a generalization and a detail and a generalization,</b> represented in the phrases “any blemish,” “lameness or blindness,” and “any ill blemish,” and according to the principles of midrashic exegesis, <b>you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail. Just as</b> the items mentioned in <b>the detail,</b> i.e., in the phrase “lameness or blindness,” are clearly <b>defined as blemishes that are exposed and do not regenerate, so too, all blemishes that are exposed and do not regenerate</b> are considered blemishes with regard to a firstborn.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But say</b> instead that <b>just as</b> the items mentioned in <b>the detail,</b> i.e., in the phrase “lameness or blindness,” are clearly <b>defined as blemishes that are exposed and</b> that cause an animal to <b>desist from its</b> normal <b>labor, and</b> they are blemishes that <b>do not regenerate, so too, all blemishes that are exposed and</b> that cause an animal to <b>desist from its labor and do not regenerate</b> are included in this <i>halakha</i>. If so, a blemish that does not fit these criteria would not render the firstborn permitted to be slaughtered. <b>Why</b> then <b>did we learn</b> in the mishna that if the firstborn’s <b>ear was damaged</b> and lacking <b>from the cartilage, but not</b> if it is lacking <b>from the skin,</b> it is considered a blemish, despite the fact that this does not cause the animal to desist from its labor?
The Gemara answers: The word “any” in <b>“any ill blemish” is an amplification,</b> and it includes even blemishes that are different from those defined by the detail. The Gemara challenges: <b>If so, blemishes that are hidden</b> should <b>also</b> be included. <b>Why</b> then <b>did we learn</b> in the mishna (39a) that animals with <b>external gums that were damaged</b> and lacking <b>or that were scratched [<i>veshenigmemu</i>] and</b> likewise animals with <b>internal</b> gums <b>that were</b> entirely <b>extracted</b> are considered blemished?

Daf 37b

It can be inferred that if the internal gums <b>were extracted</b> then <b>yes,</b> one may slaughter the firstborn, but if they <b>were</b> merely <b>damaged or</b> they <b>were scratched,</b> one may <b>not,</b> since it is a hidden blemish. The Gemara answers: <b>I require</b> that it be <b>an “ill blemish,”</b> which must be exposed and degrading, <b>and</b> a hidden blemish <b>is not</b> considered such an “ill blemish.” The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that all blemishes are included by the words: “Any ill blemish,” aside from hidden blemishes, <b>a temporary blemish</b> should <b>also</b> render it permitted for the firstborn to be slaughtered. <b>Why</b> then <b>did we learn</b> in the mishna: If the firstborn’s ear was damaged and lacking from the cartilage it may be slaughtered, <b>but not</b> if it is damaged and lacking <b>from the skin,</b> since it is a temporary blemish?
The Gemara answers: <b>A temporary blemish</b> is not excluded by the exegesis but <b>is</b> based on <b>logical reasoning: Now,</b> if <b>we do not</b> even <b>redeem</b> an offering <b>due to</b> a temporary blemish, <b>will we slaughter</b> a firstborn outside the Temple, for which redemption is not performed, <b>due to</b> a temporary blemish? The Gemara explains the source for this assertion that an offering is not redeemed because of a temporary blemish. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And if it be any impure animal, of which they may not bring an offering to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 27:11). <b>The verse is speaking of</b> ritually pure animals with <b>blemishes.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Do you say that the verse is speaking of</b> animals with <b>blemishes that were redeemed, or</b> is it referring <b>only</b> to <b>an actual impure animal,</b> such as a donkey or a horse that was consecrated; but with regard to a kosher animal, perhaps its consecrated status cannot be removed by redemption even if it was blemished? <b>When</b> the verse <b>states: “And if it be of an impure animal”</b> (Leviticus 27:27), <b>a non-kosher animal is mentioned. So how do I realize</b> the meaning of: <b>“Of which they may not bring an offering”? You must say</b> that <b>this</b> is referring to <b>blemished</b> animals <b>that were redeemed,</b> indicating that redemption is permitted.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: One <b>might</b> have thought that offerings <b>may be redeemed due to a temporary blemish</b> that they sustained. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Of which they may not bring an offering to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 27:11). This teaches that an animal <b>that is not sacrificed at all</b> is redeemed, which <b>excludes this</b> animal that has a temporary blemish, <b>which is not sacrificed today,</b> but <b>rather</b> may be sacrificed <b>tomorrow.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>If you wish, say</b> a different explanation as to why a temporary blemish is not included in the amplification of the verse: “Any ill blemish”: <b>If so,</b> that even a temporary blemish permits its slaughter, <b>why do I</b> need the verse to mention <b>a lame</b> animal <b>and a blind</b> animal? It would have sufficed to state: “Any ill blemish.” Rather, the verse excludes a temporary blemish that is unlike these two blemishes, which are permanent.
§ The mishna teaches: If the ear of the firstborn animal <b>was split, although it is not lacking,</b> one may slaughter the animal outside the Temple. With regard to this, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The split</b> that permits the animal to be slaughtered is one of <b>any size.</b> With regard to <b>the damage, whether</b> it was done <b>by the hand of a person or by the hand of God,</b> it may be slaughtered. The Gemara asks: Should it be derived <b>by inference that</b> with regard to <b>a split,</b> if it was caused <b>by the hand of God</b> it is <b>not</b> considered a blemish? That also should be considered an obvious blemish and render the animal permitted for slaughter.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should be interpreted as follows: The animal may be slaughtered for a split of any size, and with regard to <b>a split and damage, whether</b> it was done <b>by the hand of God or by the hand of a person,</b> the animal may be slaughtered. <b>And what is the measure of the damage</b> that is considered a blemish? It must be large enough <b>that a fingernail will be retained [<i>shetaḥgor</i>] on it,</b> i.e., if one passes his fingernail over the ear of the animal it can enter the area of the damage.
§ The mishna stated that if the ear of a firstborn animal <b>was pierced</b> with a hole <b>the size of</b> a bitter vetch, the animal is slaughtered because of it. With regard to this, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How large</b> must <b>the piercing of the ear</b> be? It must be <b>the size of a <i>karshina</i>. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: Like</b> the size of <b>a lentil,</b> which is slightly smaller. <b>And what is a desiccated</b> ear that is considered a blemish? It is an ear <b>that if it is pierced, it does not discharge a drop of blood. Rabbi Yosei ben HaMeshullam says: Desiccated</b> means that the ear is <b>so</b> dry <b>that it will crumble</b> if one touches it.
A Sage <b>taught: Their statements are close to being identical</b> in practice. The Gemara asks: <b>The statements of whom</b> are close to being identical? <b>If we say</b> that he is referring to the statements <b>of the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yosei ben HaMeshullam</b> with regard to a desiccated ear, <b>there is a significant</b> difference between these two opinions. One says it is determined by whether blood emerges, while the other holds it is based on whether it crumbles. <b>Rather,</b> he is referring to the statement <b>of the first <i>tanna</i> and</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as a <i>karshina</i> and a lentil are almost identical in size.
The Gemara asks with regard to the statement of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda: If the ear was pierced with a hole <b>like</b> the size of <b>a lentil,</b> then <b>yes,</b> it is considered a blemish, but if it was pierced with a hole <b>less than</b> the size <b>of a lentil,</b> then is it <b>not</b> considered a blemish? <b>And</b> one can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah provides a description of the process by which a Hebrew slave who has already completed his six years of servitude may continue on as a slave of his master: “And you shall take the <b>awl</b> and put it through his ear and in the door” (Deuteronomy 15:17). From this verse, <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>an awl</b> can be used. <b>From where</b> do I know <b>to include the palm thorn [<i>hassol</i>], a thorn, a needle, and a gimlet, and a stylus</b> for writing on wax as valid tools for piercing his ear?
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And you shall take,”</b> which indicates that <b>anything that can be taken by hand</b> is a valid tool. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> Not all these items can be used. Rather, since the verse specifies <b>an “awl,”</b> only items similar to an awl can be used; <b>just as an awl is distinct</b> in that it is fashioned <b>of metal, so too, anything</b> fashioned <b>of metal</b> can be used.
<b>And the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Rabbi</b> Elazar <b>said that Yudan the Distinguished would teach</b> as follows: <b>When they pierce</b> the ear of the slave, <b>they pierce only in the earlobe.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The piercing is not performed on that part of the ear, since there is a tradition that the ear of <b>a Hebrew slave</b> who is <b>a priest is not pierced, because</b> the piercing <b>renders him blemished</b> and unfit to serve in the Temple. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>they pierced</b> the slave <b>in the earlobe, how does a Hebrew slave</b> who is <b>a priest become blemished</b> through piercing? A wound on this part of the ear heals. <b>This</b> indicates that <b>they pierce only on the upper part of the ear,</b> through the cartilage.
In any event, it is clear from the statement of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, that the piercing of a needle is considered a blemish, despite the fact that it is definitely smaller than the size of a lentil. The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Ḥana bar Ketina said:</b> It is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>here,</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said that the hole must be the size of a lentil <b>with regard to slaughtering</b> an animal outside the Temple due to the blemish. <b>There, with regard to disqualifying</b> the animal from being sacrificed, even a tiny hole is considered a blemish, just as it renders the priest blemished.
§ According to the first opinion cited in the <i>baraita</i>, the size of the hole that is considered a blemish in the ear of the firstborn animal is like that of a <i>karshina</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>What is a <i>karshina</i>? Rav Sherevya says:</b> It is a bitter vetch, called <b><i>hinda</i></b> in Aramaic.
With regard to this <i>halakha</i>, <b>Rav Hoshaya asked Rav Huna the Great:</b> Is this measure referring to <b>a bitter vetch that</b> can <b>enter and exit</b> the hole in the ear, which means that the hole is slightly larger than the bitter vetch? <b>Or</b> is it referring to <b>a bitter vetch that is stationary</b> in the hole, meaning that the hole is precisely the size of a bitter vetch? Rav Huna the Great <b>said to him: I did not hear this</b> <i>halakha</i> specifically, but <b>I heard a similar</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>to it,</b> that the expression: The size of a bitter vetch [<i>melo karshina</i>], means that the bitter vetch can enter and exit the hole.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 2:3): <b>The spine and the skull</b> of a corpse <b>that</b> are <b>incomplete</b> do not impart ritual impurity in a tent. This <i>halakha</i> was unanimously accepted, but the details were subject to dispute: <b>How much</b> is considered <b>a deficiency in the spine so that it will not impart impurity in a tent? Beit Shammai say:</b> If it is missing <b>two vertebrae, and Beit Hillel say:</b> Even if it is missing only <b>one vertebra,</b> it will not impart impurity. <b>And</b> likewise, they disagree concerning the deficiency <b>in the skull: Beit Shammai say</b> that it must be missing a piece <b>like the size of a drilled hole, and Beit Hillel say:</b> It must be missing <b>an amount that if removed from a living</b> person, <b>he would die.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>And Rav Ḥisda was sitting, and he raised a dilemma:</b> That which was stated: <b>An amount that if removed from a living</b> person, <b>how much</b> is that? <b>Rav Taḥlifa bar Avudimi said to him: This is what Shmuel says:</b> It is <b>like</b> the size of <b>a <i>sela</i></b> coin.
The Gemara notes: <b>And it was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to whom Rabbi Taḥlifa cited when relating this <i>halakha</i> to Rav Ḥisda. <b>Rav Safra says</b> that <b>he told him a <i>halakha</i></b> of the <i>amora’im</i> citing Shmuel. <b>And Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda says</b> that <b>he told him a <i>baraita</i></b> that stipulated that the measure is like the size of a <i>sela</i> coin. <b>And your mnemonic</b> to remember what each one said is the common talmudic phrase: <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda teaches [<i>tanei</i>],</b> generally indicating a source from a <i>tanna</i>, which hints that according to Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda, Rav Taḥlifa cited a <i>baraita</i> to Rav Ḥisda, while according to Rav Safra, he related a tradition from Shmuel.
<b>And</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rav Taḥlifa: <b>If so,</b> that the measure of the deficiency according to the opinion of Beit Hillel is the size of a <i>sela</i> coin, <b>you have made the statement of Beit Shammai and the statement of Beit Hillel one</b> and the same, since the size of a <i>sela</i> coin and a drilled hole is identical. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 17:12): With regard to <b>a window that was not fashioned by the hands of a person,</b> such as where a stone fell out of the wall by itself, <b>its measure</b> for which ritual impurity is transmitted from room to room is like <b>the size of a large fist. And this is</b> the size of <b>the fist of Ben Avatiaḥ,</b> who was known to be an exceptionally large man. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: And</b> the size of this fist <b>is like</b> the size of <b>a large human head.</b>
The mishna continues: But if the window <b>was made by the hand of a person, its measure</b> for which ritual impurity is transmitted is <b>like the size of the drilled hole</b> of the <b>large</b> drill <b>of the chamber</b> in the Temple, <b>which is like</b> the size of <b>the Italian <i>pundeyon</i> and like</b> the size of <b>a <i>sela</i> of</b> the emperor <b>Nero. And its</b> size <b>is</b>

Daf 38a

<b>like the size of the hole of a yoke</b> of an animal. Evidently, the measure of the drilled hole stipulated by Beit Shammai with regard to a deficient skull equals the size of a <i>sela</i> coin stipulated by Beit Hillel according to the statement of Rav Taḥlifa. The Gemara relates: Rav Taḥlifa <b>was silent. And Rav Ḥisda said to him: Perhaps we learned</b> that Beit Shammai did not mean the size of a drilled hole alone, but rather the size of <b>a drilled</b> hole <b>and its obstruction,</b> i.e., a hole that allows for the drill to be inserted and removed. This is slightly larger than the <i>sela</i> mentioned by Beit Hillel.
<b>And Rav Taḥlifa said to him: Do not say: Perhaps. Rather,</b> say: Beit Shammai <b>definitely</b> was referring to the size of <b>a drilled</b> hole <b>and its obstruction,</b> and you <b>can rely on this</b> explanation since it is certainly correct, as certain <b>as</b> the testimony of <b>Ḥizkiyya, the father of Ikkesh,</b> which is uncontested. It can be derived from here that just as the phrase: Size of a drilled hole, is referring to the size of a hole into which the drill can be inserted and removed, so too, the size of a bitter vetch mentioned in the mishna is referring to a hole into which the bitter vetch can be inserted and removed.
§ The Gemara explains the reference to the testimony of Ḥizkiyya the father of Ikkesh. <b>As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥizkiyya, the father of Ikkesh, testified this testimony before Rabban Gamliel in Yavne, which he said in the name of Rabban Gamliel the Elder: With regard to earthenware vessels, any</b> vessel <b>that does not have a receptacle has no distinction with regard to</b> the halakhic status of <b>its sides.</b> This is in contrast to the earthenware vessels mentioned in the Torah, where only the inside, and not the outside, is susceptible to ritual impurity. Rather, if <b>its inside,</b> i.e., the sides that are used, <b>became impure, its outside</b> also <b>becomes impure.</b> Likewise, if <b>its outside became impure, its inside</b> also <b>becomes impure.</b>
The Gemara challenges: With regard to <b>an earthenware vessel, the Merciful One rendered</b> its susceptibility to impurity <b>dependent on</b> the presence of <b>a receptacle,</b> as it states: “And every earthen vessel into whose interior any of them falls” (Leviticus 11:33). Consequently, <b>if there is a receptacle, it will become impure,</b> but if <b>there is no receptacle, it</b> should <b>not become impure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Avin said</b> in response: The testimony is not referring to earthenware vessels, but to vessels that are purified through immersion in a ritual bath, such as wooden vessels, which are susceptible to ritual impurity even if they lack a receptacle. Accordingly, <b>this</b> is what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: With regard to earthenware vessels, any</b> vessel <b>that does not have a receptacle</b> never becomes impure. The <i>halakha</i> in the <b>corresponding</b> case <b>with regard to a vessel</b> that is purified though <b>rinsing,</b> i.e., immersion in a ritual bath, where it lacks a receptacle, is that <b>there is no distinction with regard to the</b> halakhic status of <b>its sides.</b> Therefore, if <b>its inside,</b> i.e., the side that is used, <b>became impure, its outside</b> also <b>becomes impure.</b> Likewise, <b>if its outside became impure, its inside</b> also <b>becomes impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>to render</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>dependent on an earthenware vessel? Let us</b> simply <b>say: With regard to a vessel</b> that is purified though <b>rinsing, any</b> vessel <b>that does not have a receptacle has no distinction</b> with regard <b>to the</b> halakhic status of <b>its sides.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> association <b>teaches us that</b> if the vessel that is purified through rinsing <b>has a receptacle, it is like an earthenware vessel.</b> Therefore, <b>just as</b> in the case of <b>an earthenware vessel,</b> if <b>its inside became impure, its outside</b> also <b>becomes impure,</b> but if <b>its inside did not become impure, its outside does not become impure, so too,</b> with regard to <b>a vessel</b> that is purified through <b>rinsing,</b> if <b>its inside became impure, its outside becomes impure.</b> But <b>if its inside did not become impure, its outside does not become impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted</b> that with regard to <b>an earthenware vessel, the Merciful One revealed</b> that <b>it</b> is rendered ritually impure only if the impure item fell into its <b>“inside”</b> (see Leviticus 11:33). <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a vessel</b> that is purified though <b>rinsing, did the Merciful One reveal with regard to it</b> that it becomes impure only through its <b>inside?</b> Therefore, even if the impure item touched the outside, it should become entirely impure.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> it is referring <b>to ritual impurity</b> that is <b>by Torah law,</b> then <b>indeed</b> a vessel that is purified through rinsing can be become impure even through its outside. But <b>here we are dealing with</b> the <b>ritual impurity of liquids,</b> i.e., liquids that became impure and subsequently touched the vessel, which becomes impure only <b>by rabbinic law. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 25:6): With regard to <b>a vessel whose outside became ritually impure by</b> contact with impure <b>liquids,</b> only <b>its outside is impure,</b> but <b>its inside, its rim, its ear-shaped handle, and its</b> straight <b>handle are pure.</b> If <b>its inside became impure,</b> it becomes <b>impure</b> in <b>its entirety.</b>
The Gemara explains the reason: <b>By Torah law, food does not transmit impurity</b> to <b>a vessel, and a liquid does not transmit impurity</b> to <b>a vessel. And it was the Sages who decreed</b> that an impure liquid transmits impurity to a vessel, <b>because</b> of the concern that people will be lenient with regard to <b>the liquid of a <i>zav</i> and a <i>zava</i>,</b> such as their urine or saliva, which are a primary source of impurity and impart impurity to vessels.
<b>Therefore, the Sages deemed</b> the impurity of a vessel that is purified though rinsing whose outside became impure through liquid to be <b>like the impurity of an earthenware vessel,</b> and if its exterior became impure, its interior remains pure. <b>But the Sages did not deem</b> its impurity <b>like the impurity of itself,</b> i.e., a vessel that is purified through rinsing, <b>by Torah law,</b> that if its exterior became impure, the vessel becomes impure in its entirety.
The reason for this is that through this ruling <b>the Sages employed an indicator</b> that it is impure only by rabbinic law <b>so that</b> people <b>will not burn <i>teruma</i> and consecrated</b> items <b>due to</b> having come into contact with <b>those</b> vessels, as by Torah law they are ritually pure and it is prohibited to burn them. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that this is the case under discussion, then with regard to a vessel that is purified through rinsing that <b>has no receptacle as well,</b> the Sages <b>should employ an indicator.</b> They should rule that the inside remains pure so that <i>teruma</i> and consecrated items will not be burned after coming in contact with it. Why then did Ḥizkiyya, the father of Ikkesh, testify that if its outside became impure, its inside becomes impure as well?
The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the Sages <b>employed an indicator with regard to</b> vessels that are purified through rinsing that <b>have a receptacle,</b> it is thereby <b>known</b> that the impurity of a vessel <b>that does not have a receptacle</b> that comes in contact with an impure liquid is <b>by rabbinic law.</b> Therefore, no one will burn <i>teruma</i> and consecrated items that came in contact with it.
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to a vessel</b> that is purified through <b>rinsing, is it susceptible to ritual impurity by Torah law,</b> so that the Sages found it necessary to decree that the exterior is susceptible to impurity of liquids? After all, in order for a vessel to be susceptible to impurity <b>it is required</b> to be <b>similar to a sack,</b> which is mentioned with regard to ritual impurity (see Leviticus 11:32): <b>Just as a sack is carried</b> both <b>full and empty, so too, any</b> object must be capable of being <b>carried</b> both <b>full and empty</b> in order to become ritually impure. This excludes a vessel that has no receptacle and cannot be carried full.
The Gemara answers that it is referring <b>to these</b> vessels <b>that are suited for</b> sitting and are susceptible to ritual impurity imparted by <b>treading,</b> i.e., the ritual impurity imparted by a <i>zav</i>, <i>zava</i>, or a menstruating woman who sits or lies down on an item, even though it lacks a receptacle. The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> with regard to <b>an earthenware</b> vessel that has no inside, the Rabbis should <b>also</b> decree that it is susceptible to the impurity of liquids if it is fit for sitting. The Gemara answers: <b>There is no</b> ritual impurity imparted by <b>treading with regard to earthenware vessels.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to the matter of an incomplete skull. According to the opinion of Beit Shammai, if the skull is missing a piece of bone the size of a drilled hole, it does not impart impurity. According to Shmuel, Beit Hillel holds that it must be missing a piece the size of a <i>sela</i> coin. If so, there would be no disagreement between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, as it was taught with regard to a window that imparts ritual impurity that a drilled hole is the same size as a <i>sela</i> coin. The Gemara now offers an additional answer: <b>Rav Pappa says</b> that it was with regard to <b>a large drill</b> that <b>we learned</b> that the minimum size of a window that imparts impurity equals the size of a <i>sela</i> coin.
The Gemara comments that <b>by inference, the unspecified drill</b> mentioned in the statement of Beit Shammai with regard to an incomplete skull is <b>also smaller than the size of a <i>sela</i></b> coin mentioned by Beit Hillel. The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> for the opinion of Beit Shammai. <b>But according to the</b> opinion of <b>the Rabbis, what is there to say?</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 2:3): <b>With regard to which drill did</b> Beit Shammai <b>state</b> their opinion concerning an incomplete skull? It was <b>with regard to a small</b> drill <b>of doctors,</b> used for drilling bones. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> It was <b>with regard to a large</b> drill, such as that used <b>in the</b> Temple <b>chamber.</b> According to the mishna concerning a window that imparts impurity, the size of this drill is like that of a <i>sela</i> coin, and the opinions of Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel would still be identical.
The Gemara asks further: <b>And</b> even <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, does it work out well?</b> If the unspecified drill mentioned by Beit Shammai is smaller than a <i>sela</i> coin, then <b>this is</b> an instance <b>of the leniencies of Beit Shammai and of the stringencies of Beit Hillel,</b> as with regard to a skull that was missing a piece only the size of a drilled hole, Beit Shammai are lenient and hold that it does not impart impurity in a tent, while Beit Hillel do consider it impure. <b>And we</b> have a principle: <b>That which we learned</b> in the mishna in tractate <i>Eduyyot</i> pertaining to the leniencies of Beit Shammai and the stringencies of Beit Hillel, <b>we learned,</b> and <b>that which we did not learn</b> there, <b>we did not learn.</b> Therefore, in all other cases, Beit Shammai are stringent and Beit Hillel are lenient.
<b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> It is specifically with regard to <b>a <i>sela</i> of</b> the emperor <b>Nero that we learned</b> in the mishna concerning a window that imparts impurity that it is <b>like</b> the size of <b>a large drilled</b> hole. But with regard to <b>the unspecified <i>sela</i></b> coin mentioned by Beit Hillel as the measure, it is even <b>smaller than an unspecified drilled</b> hole. Therefore, Beit Shammai are stringent even according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> For these blemishes of the eye, one may slaughter the firstborn animal outside the Temple: <b>The eyelid that was pierced,</b> an eyelid <b>that was damaged</b> and is lacking, or an eyelid <b>that was split;</b> and likewise, one may slaughter a firstborn animal outside the Temple <b>if</b> there was <b>in his eye a cataract, a <i>tevallul</i>,</b> or a growth in the shape of <b>a snail, a snake,</b> or <b>a berry</b> that covers the pupil. <b>What is a <i>tevallul</i>?</b> It is <b>a white</b> thread <b>that bisects the iris and enters the black</b> pupil. If it is <b>a black</b> thread that bisects the iris and <b>enters the white</b> of the eye it <b>is not a blemish.</b>

Daf 38b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna’s list of blemishes of the eye included an eyelid [<i>ris</i>] that was pierced, damaged, or split. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>The <i>ris</i>? Rav Pappa says:</b> It means <b>the outer line,</b> or barrier, <b>of the eye,</b> i.e., the eyelid. The mishna further stated: <b>A cataract, a <i>tevallul</i>.</b> With regard to a cataract, <b>the Sages taught: A sunken cataract,</b> i.e., one that is in the eye itself, <b>is a blemish,</b> but <b>a floating</b> cataract, i.e., one that is floating above the eye, <b>is not a blemish.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t the opposite taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that a sunken cataract is not a blemish whereas a floating one is a blemish? The Gemara answers: That is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> first <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a cataract in <b>the black</b> portion of the eye, whereas <b>that</b> second <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> one in <b>the white</b> portion of the eye. The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> it was taught that <b>there are no blemishes in the white</b> portion of the eye. <b>Rather,</b> both <i>baraitot</i> are referring to the black portion of the eye, and <b>this</b> second <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a white cataract,</b> whereas <b>that</b> first <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a black cataract.</b>
This is <b>as Rabba bar bar Ḥana says: Yoshiya from Usha told me</b> that with regard to <b>a black cataract,</b> if it is <b>sunken it is a blemish,</b> but if it is <b>floating it is not a blemish.</b> Conversely, with regard to <b>a white cataract,</b> if it is <b>sunken it is not a blemish,</b> whereas if it is <b>floating it is a blemish. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this is <b><i>barka</i>,</b> which is a disease in which white patches float above the eye, and it is considered a blemish.
§ The mishna included in its list of blemishes of the eye a growth in the shape of <b>a snail, a snake, or a berry</b> that covers the pupil. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Is the snail</b> mentioned in the mishna the same as <b>the snake, or perhaps</b> they are two distinct blemishes, and the mishna means <b>a snail or a snake?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana says: Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Elazar told me: There was a certain elder in our neighborhood, and Rabbi Shimon ben Yosei Lakonya</b> was <b>his name, and in</b> all <b>my days I did not pass before him.</b> But <b>once I did pass before him,</b> and <b>he said to me: Sit, my son, sit,</b> and I will teach you one matter: <b>This snail</b> that you see in the eye of a firstborn is <b>a permanent blemish,</b> and it is permitted <b>to slaughter</b> the animal <b>on its account. And this is</b> also <b>the snake mentioned by the Sages</b> as a blemish.
Rabbi Shimon ben Yosei Lakonya adds: <b>And even though</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>a person cannot see blemishes for himself,</b> and therefore I cannot permit this firstborn to myself, <b>even so</b> a halakhic authority <b>may issue a halakhic ruling to</b> his <b>students, and the students may</b> then <b>issue</b> a halakhic <b>ruling for him</b> based on what he taught them. Consequently, once I have taught you this <i>halakha</i>, you may permit my firstborn to me due to this blemish.
The Gemara asks: How could Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Elazar permit the firstborn in this manner? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Abba say</b> that <b>Rav Huna says:</b> With regard to <b>any Torah scholar who is engaged in issuing</b> a ruling of <b><i>halakha</i></b> in a situation relevant to himself, <b>if he</b> already <b>stated</b> the ruling <b>before the incident,</b> i.e., before it was relevant to him, <b>one listens to him; and if not,</b> i.e., the ruling followed the incident, one <b>does not listen to him?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>he too,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Yosei Lakonya, <b>was engaged in issuing</b> this ruling of <i>halakha</i> <b>at the outset,</b> before it became relevant to him.
§ The mishna further stated: <b>What is a <i>tevallul</i>?</b> It is <b>a white</b> thread <b>that bisects the iris</b> and enters the black pupil. The Gemara asks: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna? It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If there is either <b>a white</b> thread that <b>enters the black,</b> or <b>a black</b> thread that <b>enters the white,</b> it <b>is a blemish;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> If it is <b>a white</b> thread that <b>enters the black, it is a blemish,</b> but if it is <b>a black</b> thread that <b>enters the white, it is not a blemish, as there are no blemishes in the white</b> of the eye.
<b>Rav says: What is the reason of Rabbi Yosei? As it is written: “Their eyes stand forth from fatness”</b> (Psalms 73:7), which is interpreted to mean that the wicked embark on an evil path due to the fatness in the eyes, which is in the white portion. This indicates that the white portion <b>is called the fat of the eye,</b> but <b>it is not called simply: Their eyes.</b> Conversely, a <i>tevallul</i> is considered a blemish only if it is in the eye itself, as it states: “Or <i>tevallul</i> in his eye” (Leviticus 21:20). The Gemara further asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>Rabbi Meir, what is his reason?</b> The Gemara answers that Rabbi Meir would explain as follows: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the <b>expression <i>tevallul</i>?</b> It is <b>a substance that mixes [<i>hamevalbel</i>]</b> within <b>the eyes,</b> i.e., which passes through the white and the black in any fashion.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Pale spots</b> on the eye <b>and tears</b> streaming from the eye <b>that are constant</b> are blemishes that enable the slaughter of the firstborn. <b>Which are the pale spots that are constant?</b> They are <b>any</b> spots <b>that persisted</b> for <b>eighty days. Rabbi Ḥananya ben Antigonus said: One examines it three times within eighty days.</b> Only if the spots are found during all three examinations are they considered constant.
<b>And these are the constant tears,</b> i.e., this is how it is known whether the blemish is temporary or permanent: In a case where the animal <b>ate,</b> for medicinal purposes, <b>moist</b> fodder <b>and dry</b> fodder <b>from</b> a field watered exclusively with <b>rain,</b> or if the animal ate <b>moist</b> fodder <b>and dry</b> fodder <b>from</b> an <b>irrigated</b> field, <b>or</b> even if the animal did not eat them together but <b>ate the dry</b> fodder <b>and thereafter</b> ate <b>the moist</b> fodder, and the condition of constant tears was not healed, <b>it is not a blemish.</b> It is not a blemish <b>unless</b> the animal <b>eats the moist</b> fodder <b>and thereafter</b> eats <b>the dry</b> fodder and is not thereby healed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna? It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A blemish of <b>constant pale spots</b> is a condition that persisted for <b>forty days, and constant tears</b> is a condition that persisted for <b>eighty days;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> A blemish of constant <b>pale spots</b> is a condition that persisted for <b>eighty days.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And these are the constant tears,</b> according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda: In a case where the animal <b>ate moist</b> fodder <b>and dry</b> fodder <b>from</b> an <b>irrigated</b> field, <b>or ate the dry</b> fodder <b>and thereafter ate the moist</b> fodder, and the animal was not healed, its status as <b>a blemish is not</b> certain. It is not a blemish <b>unless</b> the animal <b>eats the dry</b> fodder <b>after</b> eating <b>the moist</b> fodder and is not thereby healed. <b>And the duration of</b> this period of eating moist and then dry fodder extends for <b>three months.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how can the mishna be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda? <b>We learned</b> about <b>two</b> types of fields in the mishna: A case where the animal <b>ate moist</b> fodder <b>and dry</b> fodder <b>from</b> a field watered exclusively with <b>rain</b> and a case where the animal ate <b>moist</b> fodder <b>and dry</b> fodder <b>from</b> an <b>irrigated</b> field and was not healed. In either case, it is not a blemish. By contrast, Rabbi Yehuda mentioned only moist fodder and dry fodder from a field that requires irrigation, from which it can be inferred that if the animal was fed moist fodder and dry fodder from a field watered exclusively with rain and it was not healed, its condition is a blemish.
The Gemara answers that the mishna <b>is incomplete and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching,</b> in accordance with the ruling of Rabbi Yehuda in the <i>baraita</i>: If the animal <b>ate moist</b> fodder <b>and dry</b> fodder <b>from</b> a field watered exclusively with <b>rain, it is a blemish.</b> If it ate moist fodder and dry fodder from an <b>irrigated</b> field, <b>it is not a blemish. And</b> with regard to a field watered exclusively with <b>rain as well,</b> if it <b>ate the dry</b> fodder <b>and thereafter ate the moist</b> fodder <b>it is not a blemish.</b> It is a not blemish <b>until</b> the animal <b>eats the dry</b> fodder <b>after the moist</b> fodder.
With regard to the statement of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And the duration of</b> this period of eating moist and then dry fodder lasts for <b>three months,</b> the Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But isn’t it taught that Rav Idi bar Avin says</b> that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashiyan</b> says: The months of <b>Adar and Nisan</b> are the <b>moist</b> period mentioned in the mishna, as the fodder is still moist at that time of year; and the months of <b>Elul and Tishrei</b> are the <b>dry</b> period, as this is the end of summer? In total, there are four months, not three. The Gemara answers that one should <b>say</b> as follows: The months of <b>Adar and half of Nisan</b> are the <b>moist</b> period, and the months of <b>Elul and half of Tishrei</b> are the <b>dry</b> period, for a total of three months.
With regard to the ruling of the mishna that the animal must be given moist fodder and then dry fodder, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Does this mean it must be fed <b>moist</b> fodder <b>at the time of moist</b> fodder, i.e., at the end of the rainy season, <b>and dry</b> fodder <b>at the time of dry</b> fodder, at the conclusion of summer? <b>Or perhaps</b> it is fed <b>moist</b> fodder <b>and</b> then <b>dry</b> fodder leftover from the previous summer, both <b>at the time of moist</b> fodder.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rav Idi bar Avin says</b> that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashiyan said:</b> The months of <b>Adar and Nisan</b> are the period of <b>moist</b> fodder; <b>Elul and Tishrei</b> are the period of <b>dry</b> fodder. This indicates that the animal is given the fodder that is available at that time. The Gemara refutes this proof: That statement is not necessarily referring to the time when it is fed, as <b>perhaps one feeds it the produce of Elul and Tishrei in Adar and Nisan.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And how much does one feed it? Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Pineḥas ben Arova:</b> One feeds it the amount <b>of a fig-bulk. Rava says: They raise a dilemma in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: Does this mean that it is fed the amount <b>of a fig-bulk at</b> its <b>first meal</b> each day,

Daf 39a

<b>or perhaps</b> does it mean it is fed the amount of a fig-bulk <b>at each and every meal? If you say</b> that it is fed a fig-bulk only <b>at the first meal,</b> is it fed this fodder <b>before</b> its regularly scheduled <b>eating or after eating?</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Before eating,</b> it is <b>certainly effective for it like a medicine,</b> which people imbibe before their meals. With regard to <b>after eating, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is this an effective manner of examining the animal? The Gemara further inquires: Is the animal fed this fodder as a medicine <b>before drinking or after drinking? Before drinking it is certainly effective for it, like barley,</b> which is fed to an animal before it drinks. With regard to <b>after drinking, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara continues to inquire: Is the animal given the fodder when it is <b>tied or untied?</b> The Gemara explains: When it is <b>untied,</b> the fodder is <b>certainly effective for this</b> animal. When it is <b>tied, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Furthermore, is it fed the fodder when it is <b>by itself, or with another</b> animal? When it is <b>with another</b> animal, the fodder <b>is certainly effective for</b> this animal, as it is comfortable. When it is <b>by itself, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?
Likewise, is the animal fed it <b>in the city or in the field?</b> When it is <b>in the field,</b> the fodder <b>is certainly effective for</b> this animal, as it is calm. When it is <b>in the city, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Ashi raises</b> a further <b>dilemma: If you say</b> that this treatment is effective only when it is <b>in the field,</b> not when it is the city, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a garden adjacent to the city?</b> No resolution is found for any of these inquiries, and with regard to each of them the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to constant pale spots that <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Antigonus says:</b> One examines the animal three times within eighty days. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>provided that they are divided into</b> equal <b>thirds,</b> i.e., there must be an even gap between each of these examinations.
With regard to the statement of the mishna that constant tears are examined by feeding the animal moist and then dry fodder for a period of three months, <b>Pineḥas, the brother of Mar Shmuel, raises a dilemma before Shmuel:</b> If the animal <b>ate</b> the fodder in the required manner <b>and was not healed,</b> which means that it is blemished, <b>is it a retroactive blemish</b> from the day it was discovered, <b>or is it a blemish from that point forward?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>with regard to</b> whether one has violated the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property <b>concerning its redemption</b> money in a case where a consecrated animal was redeemed before the end of the three months of examination and someone derived benefit from the money paid for its redemption. <b>If you say</b> that <b>it is a retroactive blemish,</b> he thereby <b>misuses</b> consecrated property, as the redemption was effective and the money belongs to the Temple treasury.
<b>But if it is a blemish from that point forward,</b> then one who derived benefit from money paid before that point has <b>not misused</b> consecrated property, as an unblemished animal cannot be redeemed, and the money remains non-sacred. <b>What,</b> then, is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Shmuel read</b> this verse <b>with regard to his</b> brother: <b>“The lame take the prey”</b> (Isaiah 33:23), i.e., one who is not learned in Torah has managed to ask a question for which I have no answer.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> For these additional blemishes, one may slaughter a firstborn animal outside the Temple: <b>Its nose that was pierced, or that was damaged</b> and is lacking, <b>or that was split.</b> Likewise, <b>its lip that was pierced,</b> or <b>that was damaged,</b> or <b>that was split</b> is considered a blemish.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the case of the nose that was pierced, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>its nostrils were pierced one into the other,</b> if the perforation is visible <b>on the outside</b> of the nostril, <b>this is a blemish;</b> if it is visible only <b>on the inside</b> of the nostril, <b>it is not a blemish.</b> With regard to the case of: <b>Its lip that was pierced or that was damaged or that was split, Rav Pappa says:</b> This is referring to <b>the outer row,</b> i.e., the front, protruding part <b>of its lip.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna lists additional blemishes that permit the slaughter of the firstborn: <b>The external gums that were damaged</b> and lacking <b>or that were scratched,</b> and likewise, <b>the internal</b> gums <b>that were extracted. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says: One does not examine from the double teeth,</b> i.e., the large molars that appear like two teeth, <b>and inward, and</b> one does <b>not</b> examine <b>even the</b> place of the <b>double teeth</b> themselves. This is because even if they were extracted, it is a concealed blemish, and it does not permit the slaughter of the firstborn.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: When the mishna is referring to <b>the double teeth, what are the double teeth?</b> The area <b>from the double teeth and inward, and the double teeth themselves, are</b> considered <b>like the inward</b> part, i.e., the location of a concealed blemish, for which one may not slaughter the animal. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Kefutzai says: One slaughters</b> the firstborn <b>only for</b> a blemish of <b>the outer</b> teeth <b>alone. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says: One does not consider the double teeth at all.</b>
The Gemara notes that the <i>baraita</i> asks about the double teeth but does not answer the question: <b>What is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>saying? And furthermore,</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Kefutzai is</b> the same as that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> as they both maintain that a blemish to the double teeth is considered a concealed blemish.
The Gemara answers that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching: What</b> are <b>the inner</b> gums, for which a firstborn is not slaughtered if a blemish was found there? The inner gums are located <b>from</b> the place of <b>the double teeth and inward, and the double teeth themselves are</b> considered <b>like the inward</b> part. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that one does not slaughter the animal, <b>said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where</b> the inner gums <b>were damaged or were scratched. But</b> if <b>they were extracted, one does slaughter</b> the firstborn for this blemish.
The Gemara continues its interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Kefutzai says: One slaughters</b> the firstborn <b>only for</b> a blemish of <b>the outer</b> teeth. <b>But</b> with regard to the <b>inner</b> gums <b>that were extracted, one does not slaughter</b> the animal <b>for them, but it is disqualified</b> as an offering. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says: One does not pay attention to the double teeth at all, and</b> a blemish there <b>does not even disqualify</b> the firstborn from sacrifice.
§ <b>Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami raises a dilemma:</b> Is <b>there</b> halakhic significance to <b>the lack of a limb</b> that is <b>internal, or is there no</b> halakhic significance to <b>the lack of a limb</b> that is <b>internal?</b> The Gemara inquires: <b>With regard to what</b> issue did he raise this dilemma? <b>If</b> it was <b>with regard to</b> whether such a blemish renders permitted the slaughter of <b>a firstborn</b> outside the Temple, <b>it is written: “Lameness or blindness”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:21), which indicates that the blemish must be exposed.
<b>If</b> the dilemma was raised <b>with regard to</b> whether other <b>sacrificial</b> animals with such a blemish are thereby disqualified from being sacrificed and may be redeemed, <b>it is written: “Blind or broken”</b> (Leviticus 22:22), which are also types of exposed blemishes. The Gemara explains that <b>we do not raise</b> this <b>dilemma with regard to slaughtering</b> the firstborn <b>or redeeming</b> other sacrificial animals, as it is clearly not considered a blemish to that extent. Rather, <b>we raise the dilemma with regard to disqualifying</b> the animal from sacrifice. <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara clarifies the dilemma. <b>The Merciful One states: “It shall be complete to be accepted”</b> (Leviticus 22:21), which indicates that <b>a complete</b> animal, <b>yes,</b> is fit as a sacrifice, but if it is <b>lacking</b> in any manner, even on the inside, it is <b>not</b> fit. <b>Or perhaps</b> one should interpret this phrase: <b>“It shall be complete to be accepted,”</b> in light of what is stated immediately afterward: <b>“There shall be no blemish therein.” Just as a blemish is on the outside,</b> as taught by the next verse, which says: “Blind or broken,” <b>so too,</b> the status of <b>lacking</b> a limb applies only if it is lacking <b>on the outside.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that this matter is subject to a dispute. It is taught in one <i>baraita</i>: When it states with regard to the burning of the sacrificial portions of a peace offering: <b>“And the two kidneys”</b> (Leviticus 3:4), this teaches that one sacrifices only an animal that has two kidneys, <b>but not</b> an animal that <b>has one kidney, nor</b> one that <b>has three kidneys. And</b> it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that when that verse states: “And the two kidneys…<b>he shall take it away,”</b> the singular form serves <b>to include</b> an animal that <b>has one kidney,</b> which may be sacrificed. Evidently, these <i>tanna’im</i> disagree as to whether an animal lacking a kidney is fit to be sacrificed.
The Sages initially <b>assumed that everyone</b> agrees that there is <b>no entity</b> born <b>with one</b> kidney, and only one kidney is found <b>because</b> this offering <b>became lacking</b> a kidney only after birth. If so, <b>let us say</b> that <b>they disagree about this: That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the first <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>a lack</b> of <b>an internal</b> limb <b>is considered a lack, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the second <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>a lack</b> of <b>an internal</b> limb <b>is not considered a lack.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef says:</b> There is no dispute here, <b>as everyone agrees</b> that <b>there is</b> such <b>an entity</b> born <b>with one</b> kidney, <b>and</b> everyone also agrees that the <b>lack of an internal</b> limb <b>is considered a lack</b> that disqualifies the animal. <b>And</b> the contradiction between the two <i>baraitot</i> is <b>not difficult: Here,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, <b>where it was created with two</b> kidneys <b>and</b> one <b>is lacking,</b> the animal is disqualified. Whereas <b>there, where it was created with one</b> kidney <b>from the outset,</b> it is not lacking and therefore it is fit.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the first <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> the case of an animal that has one kidney as <b>similar</b> to that <b>of</b> an animal that <b>has three kidneys.</b> One can therefore infer: <b>Just as</b> these <b>three</b> kidneys were present <b>from the outset,</b> as an animal does not grow new limbs, <b>so too,</b> the animal with <b>one</b> kidney alone was like that <b>from the outset.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> everyone agrees that a lack of an internal limb is considered a lack, and <b>here</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> the matter of whether <b>there is an entity</b> created with one kidney <b>from the outset.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the second <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>there is an entity</b> created <b>with one</b> kidney, and it may be assumed that this is such an animal, and it is not lacking a limb. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the first <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>there is no entity</b> created <b>with one</b> kidney, and this animal is lacking a limb and is disqualified for sacrifice.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Everyone agrees</b> that there is <b>no entity</b> born <b>with one</b> kidney, <b>and</b> that <b>a lack of an internal</b> limb <b>is considered a lack, and</b> yet it is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, it is referring to a case <b>where it lacked</b> a kidney <b>before</b> its <b>slaughter.</b> Whereas <b>there,</b> the second <i>baraita</i> is dealing with a case <b>where it lacked</b> a kidney only <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter,</b> and therefore it is fit. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the animal lacked a kidney <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter</b> but <b>before</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood in a vessel for sprinkling, <b>is it permitted</b> to sacrifice it?

Daf 39b

<b>But doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> In the case of <b>one who slits the ear of the bull</b> with the knife after slaughter, creating a blemish, <b>and thereafter collects its blood</b> from the neck, the offering is <b>disqualified, as it is stated: “And</b> the anointed priest <b>shall take from the blood of the bull”</b> (Leviticus 4:5). By using the term “the bull,” the verse indicates that the <b>bull</b> must be at the time of collection of the blood as <b>it already was</b> before slaughter, without a blemish. <b>Rather, here,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, it is referring to a case <b>where it lacked</b> a kidney <b>before the collection</b> of the blood, whereas <b>there,</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, it is dealing with a case <b>where it lacked</b> a kidney only <b>after the collection</b> of the blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the animal lacked a kidney <b>after</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood but <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>is it permitted</b> to be sacrificed upon the altar? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse states with regard to the Paschal offering: <b>“Your lamb shall be without blemish, a male in its year”</b> (Exodus 12:5), indicating <b>that it shall be unblemished</b> and <b>in its</b> first <b>year at the time of slaughter?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And from where</b> is it derived that it must also be unblemished at the time <b>of</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood, <b>and</b> at the time of <b>conveying</b> its blood to the altar, <b>and</b> at the time of the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood? <b>The verse states: “Shall be,”</b> emphasizing <b>that all</b> actions that <b>are</b> performed upon <b>it shall be</b> performed only when it is <b>unblemished and in its</b> first <b>year.</b> This teaches that the offering must be unblemished even at the time of the sprinkling of its blood.
The Gemara answers: <b>Interpret</b> this <i>baraita</i> as teaching that only the requirement that the animal must be <b>in its</b> first <b>year</b> is necessary at the time of sprinkling. Nevertheless, it need not be unblemished at this stage. The Gemara adds: <b>So, too, it is reasonable</b> that this is the correct interpretation, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> With regard to <b>all offerings in the Torah</b> that were slaughtered and their blood was collected, <b>from which there remains</b> either <b>an olive-bulk of flesh or an olive-bulk of fat,</b> the priest <b>sprinkles the blood</b> of that offering. <b>Learn from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that even if most of the offering is lacking, it is not disqualified after the collection of the blood.
The Gemara asks with regard to the interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But is there anything where at the time of</b> its <b>slaughter</b> the animal <b>is in its</b> first <b>year but at the time of</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>and conveying</b> it to the altar it <b>is in its second year? Rava says: That is to say</b> that <b>hours disqualify</b> in the case <b>of sacrificial</b> animals, i.e., one measures the age of the offering from the exact time of its birth. Therefore, if the animal reaches its second year between the time when it is slaughtered and the collection of its blood it is disqualified.
§ The Gemara returns to the previous discussion of whether the lack of an internal organ disqualifies an offering from being sacrificed. <b>Let us say</b> that this matter is <b>the subject of</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i> discussing the verse that provides a list of animals disqualified from the altar: <b>“And that whose stones are bruised, or crushed, or torn, or cut</b> you shall not sacrifice to the Lord” (Leviticus 22:24). <b>All</b> of these blemishes <b>are</b> found <b>in the</b> animal’s <b>testicles;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara asks: Does Rabbi Yehuda mean that these blemishes are only <b>in the testicles and not in the penis?</b> There too these should be considered blemishes, as the penis is more exposed and visible than the testicles. Rather, <b>say</b> that all of them <b>also</b> apply <b>to the testicles;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: All of them are</b> considered blemishes only when found <b>on the penis. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The blemishes of <b>“bruised, or crushed”</b> apply <b>also to the testicles, while</b> with regard to the blemishes of <b>“torn or cut,” on the penis, yes,</b> these are considered a blemish, but <b>on the testicles</b> they are <b>not</b> considered a blemish.
The Gemara explains the relevance of the dispute to the matter at hand: <b>What, is it not</b> that these <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree about this: That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>the lack of</b> an <b>internal</b> limb <b>is called a lack.</b> Therefore, in cases where the testicles are damaged they are considered lacking, disqualifying the animal, despite the fact that the blemish is not exposed. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, <b>holds</b> that the lack of an internal limb <b>is not called a lack.</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>And can you understand</b> the <i>baraita</i> in this manner? If so, <b>what does Rabbi Yosei hold? If he holds</b> that <b>the lack</b> of <b>an internal</b> limb <b>is called a lack,</b> then <b>even “torn or cut”</b> should be considered a lack, despite the fact that these blemishes are not visible. <b>And if he holds</b> that a lack of an internal limb <b>is not called a lack,</b> then <b>even “bruised, or crushed,”</b> should <b>not</b> be considered a lack, as they are not exposed.
<b>Rather, here they disagree with regard to exposed blemishes. Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>“bruised or crushed”</b> testicles <b>are</b> considered <b>blemished, as</b> the testicles noticeably <b>shrink</b> due to the crushing. Likewise, testicles that are <b>“torn or cut” are</b> considered <b>blemished, as</b> the testicles appear to be <b>hanging,</b> i.e., dangling, to such an extent that they do not appear to be attached in the usual manner. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov holds</b> that testicles that are <b>“bruised or crushed” are not</b> considered noticeable <b>blemishes, as initially,</b> before they become damaged, <b>there are times that</b> the testicles <b>also shrink.</b> Furthermore, testicles that are <b>“torn or cut” are not</b> considered <b>blemished</b> either, <b>as initially,</b> prior to being torn or cut, <b>there are times that</b> the testicles <b>also hang.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>“bruised or crushed”</b> testicles <b>are</b> considered <b>blemished, as they are no</b> longer <b>present</b> in their normal state, but are entirely broken. But he maintains that <b>“torn or cut”</b> testicles <b>are not</b> considered <b>blemished, as they are</b> still <b>present</b> in the pouch, despite the fact that they no longer function.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna details additional blemishes that enable the slaughter of firstborn animals: If <b>the pouch [<i>hazoven</i>]</b> in which the genitals of the firstborn are concealed, or if <b>the genitalia of a female sacrificial</b> animal, <b>were damaged</b> and lacking; if <b>the tail was damaged from the tailbone, but not</b> if it was damaged <b>from the joint,</b> i.e., one of the joints between the vertebrae, because it heals; <b>or</b> in a case <b>where the end of the tail is split,</b> i.e., <b>the skin and the flesh were removed and the bone remained</b> exposed; <b>or</b> in a case <b>where there is a full fingerbreadth of flesh between one joint and another joint;</b> these are all blemishes.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the case where the pouch in which the genitals of the firstborn are concealed was damaged, <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> This applies only if the pouch <b>was damaged, but not</b> in a case where it <b>was removed.</b> Furthermore, it is a blemish only if <b>the pouch</b> was damaged, <b>but not</b> if <b>the male</b> sex organ was damaged. The Gemara notes that <b>this</b> opinion <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is a blemish only if the pouch <b>was damaged, but not</b> if it <b>was removed,</b> and only if <b>the pouch</b> was damaged, <b>but not the male</b> sex organ. <b>Rabbi Yosei ben HaMeshullam says: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving one</b> animal <b>in Inbal, where a wolf removed</b> its pouch <b>and it</b> later <b>returned to its strength,</b> i.e., it grew again.
§ The mishna stated: If <b>the tail was damaged from the tailbone…</b>or in a case where there is a full fingerbreadth of flesh between one joint and another joint. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught:</b> The <b>fingerbreadth</b> of <b>which</b> the Sages <b>spoke</b> is <b>one-fourth of a handbreadth of any</b> average <b>person.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this stated? <b>Rabba says:</b> It is stated <b>with regard to <i>tekhelet</i>,</b> i.e., ritual fringes. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How many strings does one place</b> on a garment?<b>Beit Shammai say: Four</b> strings are inserted into the hole in the garment so that there are eight strings hanging down altogether, <b>and Beit Hillel say: Three</b> strings are inserted into the hole so that six are hanging down.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And how much should be hanging</b> beyond the knots and windings? <b>Beit Shammai say: Four</b> fingerbreadths, <b>and Beit Hillel say: Three</b> fingerbreadths. <b>And</b> the <b>three</b> fingerbreadths <b>that Beit Hillel say</b> should be hanging are each <b>one-fourth of a handbreadth of any</b> average <b>person.</b>
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says</b> that this <i>baraita</i> discussing the fingerbreadth is referring <b>to the two cubits</b> mentioned in a different context, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 17:9): <b>There were two</b> rods for measuring <b>cubits</b>

Daf 40a

<b>in</b> the chamber of <b>Shushan the capital,</b> which was located above the eastern gate of the Temple Mount, <b>one in the northeast corner and one in the southeast corner.</b> The one <b>that was in the northeast corner was longer than</b> the cubit used <b>by Moses</b> in the building of the Tabernacle, which was six handbreadths, by <b>half a fingerbreadth,</b> and the one <b>that was in the southeast corner was longer than</b> the other one by another <b>half a fingerbreadth.</b> One therefore <b>finds it longer than Moses’</b> cubit by a full <b>fingerbreadth.</b>
The mishna continues: <b>And why did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that there should be two measures of a cubit, <b>one large and one small?</b> It was <b>so that the artisans</b> who were working in the Temple <b>would take</b> payment according the amount of work they did, as measured <b>by the small</b> cubit, <b>and return</b> it to the Temple through their work, as measured <b>by the large</b> cubit, <b>so they would not come to misuse consecrated property.</b> If they would accept any payment that they did not deserve, they would be misusing consecrated property. It was with regard to the fingerbreadth mentioned in this mishna that the <i>baraita</i> cited above teaches that it is one-fourth of a handbreadth of any average person.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>two</b> large cubits? The Gemara answers: <b>One,</b> the shorter of the two, was used <b>to</b> measure <b>silver and gold.</b> Since silver and gold were valuable, the difference between the two measurements was set at only half a fingerbreadth, so that the artisans would not suffer too great a loss. <b>And</b> the other <b>one,</b> which was longer than Moses’ cubit by a full fingerbreadth, was used <b>in</b> the <b>construction</b> of wood and stone structures.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, and some say Rav Huna bar Natan,</b> said: This <i>baraita</i>, which states that a fingerbreadth is one-fourth of a handbreadth of any average person, is referring <b>to that which we learned</b> in the mishna here with regard to the blemishes of a firstborn animal: In a case <b>where there is a full fingerbreadth of flesh between one joint and another joint.</b> That measure of a full fingerbreadth is one-fourth of a handbreadth.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The firstborn animal may be slaughtered if <b>it has no testicles or</b> if <b>it has only one testicle. Rabbi Yishmael says: If</b> the animal <b>has two</b> scrotal <b>sacs,</b> it can be assumed that <b>it has two testicles;</b> if the animal <b>does not have two</b> scrotal <b>sacs,</b> it can be assumed that <b>it has only one testicle. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The matter can be ascertained: <b>One seats</b> the animal <b>on its rump and mashes</b> the sac; <b>if there is a testicle, ultimately</b> it is going <b>to emerge.</b> There was <b>an incident where one mashed</b> the sac <b>and</b> the testicle <b>did not emerge.</b> Then, the animal <b>was slaughtered and</b> the testicle <b>was discovered attached to the loins. And Rabbi Akiva permitted</b> the consumption of its flesh, as the testicle had not previously emerged, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri prohibited</b> its consumption.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that a firstborn may be slaughtered if it has no testicles or if it has only one testicle. The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> that with regard to a case where <b>it has only one testicle you said</b> that <b>it is a blemish, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state the same in a case where <b>it has no</b> testicles <b>at all?</b> The Gemara answers that the mishna <b>is incomplete and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching:</b> If <b>it does not have two testicles in two</b> scrotal <b>sacs, but in one sac,</b> or <b>alternatively,</b> if it has <b>two sacs and one testicle, it is a blemish.</b>
The Gemara continues this version of the mishna. <b>Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> If the animal <b>has two</b> scrotal <b>sacs, it is known that it has two testicles,</b> and therefore it is not blemished and may not be slaughtered; if the animal <b>has only one</b> scrotal <b>sac it is considered like one that has only one testicle,</b> even if it actually has two testicles. <b>And Rabbi Akiva comes to say:</b> If it has two sacs, <b>we do not say</b> the claim of: <b>It is known. Rather, one seats</b> the animal <b>on its rump and mashes</b> the sac; <b>if there is a testicle, ultimately</b> it is going <b>to emerge.</b> If the testicle does not emerge, clearly it has only one testicle and is blemished.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> there was <b>an incident where one mashed</b> the sac <b>and</b> the testicle <b>did not emerge.</b> Then the animal was slaughtered and the testicle was discovered attached to the loins. And Rabbi Akiva permitted the consumption of its flesh, and Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri prohibited its consumption. The Gemara elaborates on this incident: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei said:</b> There was <b>an incident in Piran of Beit Menaḥem where</b> a firstborn animal apparently had only one testicle, and someone <b>mashed</b> its sac <b>and</b> the other testicle <b>did not emerge. And</b> the animal <b>was slaughtered and</b> the testicle <b>was discovered attached to the loins. And Rabbi Akiva permitted</b> its consumption, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri prohibited</b> its consumption.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Akiva said to Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri: Until when will you consume the property of the Jewish people</b> by prohibiting animals in such cases? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said to Rabbi Akiva: Until when will you feed the Jewish people</b> unslaughtered animal <b>carcasses?</b> The Gemara asks: How could Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri use the term animal carcasses here? After all, <b>aren’t they</b> properly <b>slaughtered?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Rather,</b> Yoḥanan ben Nuri actually referred to <b>animals with a wound that will cause them to die within twelve months [<i>tereifot</i>].</b> The Gemara challenges: But <b>it is not a prohibition of <i>tereifot</i>. Rather,</b> he said: <b>Until when will you feed the Jewish people sacrificial</b> animals <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard? According to Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri this is not a blemish, and therefore the animal is an unblemished offering, which may not be eaten outside the Temple.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> An animal <b>with five legs, or</b> one <b>that has only three, or</b> one <b>whose</b> hooves on its <b>legs were closed like</b> those <b>of a donkey</b> and not split, <b>or the <i>shaḥul</i>, or the <i>kasul</i></b> may be slaughtered. <b>What is a <i>shaḥul</i>?</b> It is an animal with <b>a thighbone that was dislocated. And</b> what is <b>a <i>kasul</i>?</b> It is an animal whose build is asymmetrical in <b>that one of its thighs is higher</b> than the other.
