<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that an animal with five legs or three legs is blemished. <b>Rav Huna says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>was missing or had an additional foreleg. But</b> if it was missing or had <b>an</b> additional <b>hind leg,</b> not only is it blemished, but <b>it is also a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> The reason is <b>that any extra</b> limb <b>is like a removed</b> limb, and an animal whose hind leg was removed is a <i>tereifa</i>.
With regard to the ruling of the mishna that an animal whose hooves were closed like those of a donkey is blemished, <b>Rav Pappa says: Do not say</b> that it is a blemish only in a case <b>where</b> its hooves are entirely like those of a donkey, i.e., <b>round and not split</b> at all. <b>Rather, when they are round, even though they are</b> also <b>split,</b> it is still considered a blemish.
The mishna teaches: <b>Or the <i>shaḥul</i>, or the <i>kasul</i></b> may be slaughtered. In this regard, <b>the Sages taught: What is</b> the <b><i>kasul</i> and what is</b> the <b><i>shaḥul</i>?</b> The <b><i>shaḥul</i></b> is an animal with <b>a thighbone that was dislocated.</b> The <b><i>kasul</i></b> is an animal that is irregular in <b>that one of its legs is inside the loin,</b> i.e., in its proper place, <b>and</b> in <b>one of its legs</b> the bone is dislocated and is <b>above the loin.</b> It is <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: What are <b>the <i>saru’a</i> and <i>kalut</i></b> mentioned in the Torah (see Leviticus 22:23) among the animals disqualified from being sacrificed? The <b><i>saru’a</i></b> is one <b>whose thigh is longer</b> than the other; the <b><i>kalut</i></b> is one <b>whose</b> hooves on <b>its legs are closed like</b> those <b>of a donkey and like</b> those <b>of a horse.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Additional blemishes that permit the slaughter of the firstborn include those where <b>the bone of its foreleg or the bone of its hind leg was broken, even though it is not conspicuous.</b> With regard to <b>these blemishes</b> listed in this chapter, <b>Ila,</b> who was expert in blemishes of the firstborn, <b>enumerated</b> them <b>in Yavne, and the Sages deferred to his</b> expertise.
<b>And</b> Ila <b>added three additional</b> blemishes, and the Sages <b>said to him: We did not hear</b> about <b>those.</b> Ila added: An animal <b>whose eye is round like</b> that <b>of a person, or whose mouth is similar to</b> that <b>of a pig, or where most of</b> the segment of <b>its tongue</b> corresponding to the segment that facilitates <b>speech</b> in the tongue of a person <b>was removed. The court that followed them said</b> with regard to each of those three blemishes: <b>That is a blemish</b> that enables the slaughter of the firstborn.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if the bone of its foreleg or the bone of its hind leg was broken it is considered a blemish, despite the fact that it is not conspicuous. The Gemara asks: If <b>it is not conspicuous, is it a blemish?</b> A blemish must be on an exposed part of the body (see 37b). <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The mishna means that <b>it is not conspicuous on its own account,</b> i.e., the shape of the leg is no different from the usual. <b>But it is conspicuous on account of</b> its <b>work,</b> i.e., the manner in which the animal walks.
§ The mishna teaches that with regard to <b>these blemishes</b> listed in this chapter, Ila <b>enumerated</b> them in Yavne, and he added three more, including an animal whose eye is round like that of a person. The Gemara asks: Is this <b>to say that it is not the manner</b> of animals to have eyes of this kind? <b>And</b> one can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from a mishna (<i>Nidda</i> 21a): With regard to a woman <b>who miscarries</b> a fetus in the form of <b>a type of domesticated animal, undomesticated animal, or bird, whether it is a non-kosher</b> animal <b>or whether it is a kosher</b> animal, <b>if it is male,</b> the woman <b>observes</b> the periods of impurity, i.e., seven days, and purity, i.e., thirty-three days, established in the Torah <b>for</b> a woman who gives birth to <b>a male.</b>
<b>If</b> it is <b>female,</b> the woman <b>observes</b> the periods of impurity, i.e., fourteen days, and purity, i.e., sixty-six days, established in the Torah <b>for</b> a woman who gives birth to <b>a female.</b> If its sex <b>is unknown,</b> the woman <b>observes</b> the more severe restrictions from the case of the birth <b>of a male and</b> the more severe restrictions from the case of the birth <b>of a female:</b> She is impure for fourteen days like a woman who gave birth to a female, but blood that she sees thereafter is pure until only forty days after birth, like a woman who gave birth to a male. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: What is the reason of Rabbi Meir? Since the eye</b> of these animals <b>is round like</b> that <b>of a person,</b> a woman who miscarries a fetus of this kind is impure. <b>Rav Yosef said</b> in resolution of this apparent contradiction: It is <b>not difficult; this</b> is referring <b>to the black</b> portion of the eye, whereas <b>that</b> is referring <b>to the white</b> portion of the eye.
The mishna teaches: <b>Or its mouth is similar to</b> that <b>of a pig. Rav Pappa says: Do not say</b> that this is referring only to a case <b>where</b> the mouth is <b>pointed and</b> the upper lip <b>overlaps</b> the bottom lip, exactly like that of a pig. <b>Rather, when it overlaps, even though it is not pointed,</b> this is a blemish.
The mishna teaches: <b>Or that most of</b> the segment of <b>its tongue</b> corresponding to the segment that facilitates <b>speech</b> in the tongue of a person <b>was removed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna? It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Or that most of its tongue was removed; Rabbi Yehuda says: Most of</b> the segment of <b>its tongue</b> corresponding to the segment that facilitates <b>speech</b> in the tongue of a person must be removed to be considered a blemish.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And</b> there was <b>an incident where the lower jaw</b> of the firstborn <b>protruded beyond the upper</b> jaw, <b>and Rabban Gamliel asked the Sages</b> for a ruling, <b>and they said: That is a blemish</b> that enables the slaughter of the firstborn.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the ruling <b>taught</b> in the previous mishna <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring to when he <b>teaches</b> here: <b>And</b> there was <b>an incident?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since we learned</b> in the list of blemishes in the previous mishna the case where <b>its mouth is similar to</b> that <b>of a pig, and the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi</b> Ila in that case, <b>we say</b> here that <b>when the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi</b> Ila, it is only in a case <b>where its upper lip overlaps the lower</b> lip. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where the lower</b> jaw <b>protrudes beyond the upper</b> jaw, everyone agrees that <b>this is a blemish.</b>

Daf 40b

The Gemara continues this version of the mishna: <b>And</b> there was <b>also an incident where the lower jaw</b> of the firstborn <b>protruded beyond the upper</b> jaw, and <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel asked the Sages</b> for a ruling, <b>and they said: That is a blemish</b> that enables the slaughter of the firstborn.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> the blemishes of <b>a person that we learned</b> in a mishna (44a): If <b>his upper lip protrudes beyond the lower</b> lip <b>or</b> his <b>lower</b> lip <b>protrudes beyond the upper</b> lip, <b>that is a blemish.</b> And <b>it is</b> only <b>with regard to a person that it is written: “Whatever man of the seed of Aaron”</b> (Leviticus 22:4), which teaches that in order to be fit for the Temple service a priest must be <b>a man who is equal to the seed of Aaron,</b> i.e., he has an ordinary appearance like other priests. <b>But</b> this requirement is <b>not</b> stated <b>with regard to an animal,</b> and therefore an animal should not be considered blemished if its lower lip protrudes beyond the upper lip.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> in response: That is <b>not difficult; this</b> mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the lower jaw <b>contains a bone</b> that is longer than the upper jaw, in which case it is a blemish even for an animal, whereas <b>that</b> mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the lower jaw <b>does not contain a bone,</b> and therefore it is a blemish only in the case of a person.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>the ear of the kid</b> that <b>was doubled</b> and appeared like two ears, <b>the Sages said: When</b> the additional ear <b>is one bone,</b> i.e., it has its own cartilage, it is <b>a blemish; when it does not have</b> its own <b>bone it is not a blemish. Rabbi Ḥananya ben Gamliel says:</b> In the case of <b>the tail of a kid that is similar to</b> that <b>of a pig or</b> one that is so short <b>that it does not have three joints, that is a blemish.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught:</b> In a case where <b>the mouth</b> of a firstborn animal is <b>swollen, and</b> likewise, if <b>its legs are swollen,</b> the following distinction applies: If it is swollen <b>due to the wind,</b> i.e., it simply swelled up, <b>it is not a blemish.</b> If it is swollen <b>due to</b> a particularly large <b>bone, this is a blemish.</b> If <b>its ears are doubled,</b> in a case <b>where</b> it has <b>one cartilage, this is a blemish;</b> in a case <b>where</b> it has <b>two cartilages, this is not a blemish.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> With regard to <b>the tail of a kid that is similar to</b> that <b>of a pig,</b> that is a blemish. <b>Rav Pappa says: Do not say</b> that it is a blemish only <b>where</b> its tail is <b>thin</b> like that of a pig; <b>rather,</b> if it is <b>round,</b> i.e., curly like a pig’s tail, <b>even though it is thick,</b> like the tail of a goat, this is considered a blemish.
§ The mishna stated: <b>Or</b> if the tail of a kid is so short <b>that it does not have three joints,</b> that is a blemish. <b>Rav Huna says: In</b> the case of the tail of <b>a kid,</b> if it has <b>two</b> joints, <b>that is a blemish;</b> if it has <b>three</b> joints, <b>it is not a blemish. With regard to a lamb,</b> if it has <b>three</b> joints, <b>that is a blemish;</b> if it has <b>four</b> joints, <b>it is not a blemish.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In</b> the case of <b>a kid,</b> if its tail has <b>one</b> joint, <b>that is a blemish;</b> if it has <b>two</b> joints, <b>it is not a blemish. With regard to a lamb,</b> if it has <b>two</b> joints, <b>that is a blemish;</b> if it has <b>three</b> joints, <b>it is not a blemish.</b> The Gemara concludes: This is <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rav Huna</b> issued his statement because <b>the mishna misled him. He thought</b> that <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the first clause</b> is referring <b>to a kid,</b> whose tail is similar to that of a pig, it can be inferred that <b>the latter clause,</b> with its mention of three joints, is <b>also</b> referring <b>to a kid. But it is not so.</b> Rather, <b>the first clause</b> is referring <b>to a kid, but the latter clause</b> is referring <b>to a lamb,</b> as explained in the <i>baraita</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says</b> that these are blemished animals: One <b>that has a wart in its eyes; and</b> one <b>where the bone of its foreleg or hind leg was damaged; and</b> one <b>where the bone of its mouth,</b> i.e., its jaw, <b>was dislocated;</b> and an animal with <b>one of its eyes large and one small,</b> or <b>one of its ears large and one small</b> where the difference in size is detectable <b>by sight, but not</b> if it is detectable only <b>by being measured. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> An animal is blemished if with regard to <b>its two testicles, one is as large as two of the other, but the Rabbis did not agree with his</b> opinion.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if an animal has a wart in its eyes, it is blemished. The Gemara asks: Is this <b>to say that a wart is</b> considered <b>a blemish? And</b> one can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from the mishna (41a): <b>And these</b> are the blemishes <b>that one does not slaughter</b> the firstborn <b>due to them, neither in the Temple nor in</b> the rest of <b>the country,</b> as these are not considered full-fledged blemishes…an animal <b>with boils</b> that are moist inside and out, <b>and</b> one <b>with warts.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> that a wart is not a blemish? After all, <b>a wart is written in the Torah</b> in its list of blemishes (see Leviticus 22:22). <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>that</b> mishna, which states that a wart is not a full-fledged blemish, is referring to a blemish <b>on</b> the animal’s <b>body,</b> whereas <b>this</b> mention of a wart in the Torah and the mishna here is referring to a wart <b>in its eye.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> consider that <b>the verse</b> is written in <b>an unspecified</b> manner. <b>What</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if the wart is <b>on its body, and what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if the wart is <b>in its eye?</b> How is this distinction derived from the verse? The Gemara suggests an alternative explanation: <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> is referring to a wart <b>that has a bone,</b>and <b>that</b> is referring to a wart <b>that does not have a bone.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: The wart mentioned <b>in the verse</b> and the mishna here is one <b>that has a bone,</b> whereas the wart addressed by <b>the mishna</b> there is one <b>that does not have a bone.</b> Consequently, if the wart is <b>in its eye, it is a blemish,</b> as stated in the verse and the mishna here, but if it is <b>on</b> its <b>body, it is not a blemish,</b> although the animal is disqualified from being sacrificed, in accordance with the ruling of the mishna there.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to a wart that <b>does not have a bone</b> and is <b>on the body,</b> is the animal <b>disqualified</b> from being sacrificed? <b>It is merely hanging</b> flesh, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (45b) that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to those <b>with</b> flesh or skin that <b>hangs</b> from their body, such a blemish <b>disqualifies a person, but with regard to</b> such <b>an animal,</b> it is <b>fit. Rather,</b> both <b>this</b> mishna here <b>and that</b> mishna there are referring to a wart <b>in the</b> animal’s <b>eye, and</b> it is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> mishna is referring to a wart <b>in the black</b> of the eye, the pupil, whereas <b>that</b> mishna is referring to a wart <b>in the white</b> of the eye.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> it has been established that <b>there are no blemishes in the white</b> part of the eye, which indicates that the animal is not even disqualified from being sacrificed on the altar. <b>Rather,</b> both <b>this</b> statement that there are no blemishes in the white of the eye <b>and that</b> ruling of the mishna that a wart disqualifies the animal from being sacrificed are referring to a wart <b>in the white</b> part of the eye. <b>And Reish Lakish says:</b> It is <b>not difficult; this</b> is referring to a wart <b>that has a hair,</b> and therefore the animal is unfit for the altar, whereas <b>that</b> statement is referring to a case <b>where</b> the wart <b>does not have a hair.</b> As for the mishna here, which rules that a wart is a full-fledged blemish, it is referring to a wart in the pupil of the eye, as explained.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to an animal where <b>one of its eyes</b> is <b>large</b> and one is small that this is a blemish. In this regard, it is <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: When the mishna states the term <b>large,</b> it means the eye is as large <b>as</b> the eye <b>of a calf,</b> and when it states the term <b>small,</b> it means it is as small <b>as</b> that of <b>a goose.</b>
The mishna teaches: Or <b>one of its ears</b> is <b>large</b> and one is small, which is detectable by sight, but not if it is detectable only by being measured. Rabbi Yehuda says: An animal is blemished if with regard to its two testicles, one is as large as two of the other, but the Rabbis did not agree with his opinion. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the Rabbis, how large</b> can the difference between the two testicles be without this discrepancy being considered a blemish? The Gemara answers that it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say: Even</b> if <b>the second,</b> smaller testicle is <b>no</b> bigger <b>than a bean,</b> the animal <b>is fit.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>the tail of a calf that does not reach the leg joint [<i>la’arkov</i>], the Sages said:</b> It is a blemish, because <b>all growth of calves</b> is in <b>this</b> manner:<b>As long as they grow,</b> their tails <b>are extended</b> beneath the leg joint. <b>Which is the leg joint</b> about <b>which</b> the Sages <b>spoke? Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says:</b> They are referring <b>to</b> the <b>leg joint that is in the middle of the thigh.</b>

Daf 41a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the case in the mishna of the tail of a calf that does not reach the leg joint, it is <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: This leg joint is <b>the upper joint,</b> between the thighbone and the tibia, <b>and not the lower joint,</b> between the middle and lower bones. <b>And</b> with regard to this upper joint, <b>the corresponding</b> bone <b>in</b> the leg of <b>a camel is conspicuous,</b> but in a calf it is not noticeable from the outside.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>For these blemishes</b> enumerated in the previous <i>mishnayot</i>, <b>one slaughters the firstborn</b> outside the Temple <b>and disqualified consecrated</b> animals <b>may be redeemed on their account.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>this additional</b> statement that for these blemishes one slaughters the firstborn outside the Temple? It was already <b>taught</b> in <b>the first clause,</b> at the beginning of the chapter: <b>For these blemishes, one may slaughter the firstborn</b> animal outside the Temple. The Gemara answers that <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna was <b>necessary: Disqualified consecrated</b> animals <b>may be redeemed due to</b> these blemishes. The Gemara asks: But <b>this too</b> is <b>obvious;</b> if <b>one may slaughter</b> a firstborn due to these blemishes, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that <b>one may redeem them?</b>
<b>Rather, since</b> a previous mishna <b>taught</b> that Ila <b>added three</b> additional blemishes, <b>and</b> the Sages <b>said to him: We did not hear</b> about <b>those, and</b> then the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>proceeded to teach</b> <i>halakhot</i> in the name <b>of individual</b> opinions, those of Rabbi Ḥananya ben Gamliel and Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus, one might have thought that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with their rulings. Therefore, he states <b>an unattributed</b> ruling in this mishna <b>with regard to all their</b> statements: <b>For</b> all <b>these blemishes</b> enumerated in the previous <i>mishnayot</i>, <b>one slaughters the firstborn, and disqualified consecrated</b> animals <b>may be redeemed due to them.</b> This indicates that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with all of these individual opinions.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these</b> are the blemishes <b>that one does not slaughter</b> the firstborn <b>due to them, neither in the Temple nor in</b> the rest of <b>the country: Pale spots</b> on the eye <b>and tears</b> streaming from the eye <b>that are not constant; and internal gums that were damaged but that were not extracted; and</b> an animal <b>with boils</b> that are moist inside and out <b>[<i>garav</i>]; and</b> an animal <b>with warts; and</b> an animal <b>with boils [<i>ḥazazit</i>];</b> and <b>an old or sick</b> animal, <b>or</b> one with <b>a foul odor; and</b> one <b>with which a transgression was performed,</b> e.g., it copulated with a person or was the object of bestiality; <b>and</b> one <b>that killed a person.</b> In these latter two cases, the act of bestiality or killing became known <b>on the basis</b> of the testimony <b>of one witness or on the basis of the owner.</b>
<b>And</b> one does not slaughter <b>a <i>tumtum</i>,</b> whose sexual organs are concealed, <b>and a hermaphrodite [<i>ve’anderoginos</i>],</b> which has both male and female sexual organs, <b>neither in the Temple nor in</b> the rest of <b>the country. Rabbi Shimon says: You have no blemish greater than that,</b> and it may be slaughtered. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The halakhic status of a hermaphrodite <b>is not</b> that of <b>a firstborn; rather,</b> its halakhic status is that of a non-sacred animal that may <b>be shorn and utilized for labor.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the two types of boils: <i>Garav</i> and <i>ḥazazit</i>, are not considered full-fledged blemishes for which one may slaughter a firstborn outside the Temple. The Gemara asks: <b>And is <i>garav</i> not</b> considered a blemish? <b>But isn’t it written “<i>garav</i>” in the Torah,</b> in the list of blemishes (see Leviticus 22:22)? <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>is <i>ḥazazit</i> not</b> considered a blemish? <b>But isn’t it written “<i>yalefet</i>” in the Torah,</b> in the same verse, <b>and it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“<i>Garav</i>”; this is</b> referring to boils that are hard as <b>earthenware [<i>ḥeres</i>]; “<i>yalefet</i>”; this is the <i>ḥazazit</i></b> that affected <b>the Egyptians</b> (see Exodus 9:10). <b>And Reish Lakish says: Why is it called <i>yalefet</i>?</b> The reason is <b>that it grabs [<i>melapefet</i>] continuously</b> onto an invalid <b>until the day of death,</b> i.e., it cannot be healed.
<b>Granted,</b> the contradiction <b>between</b> the status of <b>the <i>ḥazazit</i></b> mentioned in the Torah and that of <b>the <i>ḥazazit</i></b> in the mishna is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>here</b> the Torah is referring <b>to an Egyptian <i>ḥazazit</i>,</b> and <b>there</b> the mishna is referring <b>to a regular <i>ḥazazit</i>. But</b> the contradiction <b>between</b> the status of <b>the <i>garav</i></b> listed in the Torah and <b>the <i>garav</i></b> of the mishna is <b>difficult.</b> The Gemara answers that the contradiction <b>between the <i>garav</i></b> in the Torah and <b>the <i>garav</i></b> in the mishna is <b>also not difficult: This</b> ruling of the mishna is referring <b>to moist</b> boils, whereas <b>that</b> <i>garav</i> of the Torah is referring <b>to dry</b> boils. <b>Moist</b> boils will <b>heal</b> and therefore are considered a temporary blemish for which one may not slaughter a firstborn; <b>dry</b> ones will <b>not heal.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>a moist</b> boil <b>heal? But isn’t it written: “The Lord will smite you with the boil of Egypt,</b> and with the hemorrhoids, and with <i>garav</i>, and with <i>ḥares</i>, from which you cannot be healed” (Deuteronomy 28:27). <b>And since it is written: “And with <i>ḥares</i>,”</b> which is referring to boils that are as hard as earthenware [<i>ḥeres</i>], <b>moist <i>garav</i> is</b> thereby <b>stated, and</b> with regard to both types that verse <b>states: “From which you cannot be healed.”</b>
<b>Rather, there are three</b> types of <i>garav</i>: First, the <i>garav</i> <b>of the verse</b> that deals with blemishes, which is <b>dry both on the inside and on the outside.</b> This cannot be healed, and it is called <i>ḥares</i> in Deuteronomy. The second is the <i>garav</i> <b>of the mishna,</b> which can be healed, and is <b>moist on the outside and inside.</b> Third, the <i>garav</i> <b>of Egypt,</b> mentioned in Deuteronomy as one of the types of boils of Egypt. This <i>garav</i> is <b>dry on the inside</b> and therefore cannot be healed, <b>but</b> it <b>is moist on the outside, as it is written</b> with regard to the plague of boils in Egypt: <b>“And it became a boil breaking forth with <i>avabu’ot</i> upon man</b> and upon animal” (Exodus 9:10). <i>Avabu’ot</i> is referring to a substance that pours out [<i>nove’a</i>] and is moist.
§ Among the conditions that are not considered full-fledged blemishes, but one may not sacrifice an animal with one such condition as an offering either, the mishna lists: <b>And an old</b> animal, <b>or a sick</b> animal, <b>or</b> one with <b>a foul odor.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? They are derived from a verse, <b>as the Sages taught:</b> The verse states: “And if his offering be <b>from [<i>min</i>] the flock, whether from the sheep or from the goats”</b> (Leviticus 1:10). These three instances of the word “from [<i>min</i>]” serve to <b>exclude the old, and the sick, and the</b> animal with <b>a foul odor,</b> which may not be sacrificed.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> all three exclusions <b>are necessary. As, had the Merciful One written</b> the word “from” once, one might have said that this serves <b>to exclude an old</b> animal, <b>which will not become healthy again,</b> as it will never get younger. <b>But</b> with regard to a <b>sick</b> animal, <b>which</b> might <b>become healthy again, say</b> that it is <b>not</b> disqualified. <b>And,</b> alternatively, <b>had</b> the Merciful One <b>written</b> only one term of exclusion, one might have said that it serves <b>to exclude a sick</b> animal, <b>as</b> it is <b>not the</b> natural <b>manner</b> of an animal to be sick. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>an old</b> animal, <b>as this is the</b> natural <b>manner</b> of all animals to grow old, <b>say</b> that it should <b>not</b> be disqualified from the altar.
<b>And had the Merciful One written</b> only <b>two</b> terms of exclusion, one might have said that they serve <b>to exclude these weak</b> animals, the sick and the old, as one should sacrifice only a fat, healthy animal. <b>But</b> with regard to an animal with <b>a foul odor, which is not weak, say</b> that it should <b>not</b> be disqualified. <b>And alternatively,</b> had there been only one term of exclusion, one might have said that it serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal with <b>a foul odor, as</b> it is <b>repulsive. But</b> with regard to <b>these</b> other two cases of an old and a sick animal, <b>which are not repulsive, say</b> that they are <b>not</b> excluded. Therefore, all three exclusions <b>are necessary.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> an animal <b>with which a transgression was performed,</b> and one that killed a person that was known on the basis of the testimony of one witness or the owner, are disqualified from being sacrificed. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived?
They are derived from a verse, <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that when the verse states: “You shall bring your offering from the cattle, even from the herd or from the flock” (Leviticus 1:2), each mention of the word “from” is interpreted as a term of exclusion. The expression <b>“from the cattle”</b> serves <b>to exclude an animal that copulated with a person and an animal that was the object of bestiality.</b> The expression <b>“from the herd”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal <b>worshipped</b> as a deity, and <b>“from the flock”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal <b>set aside</b> for idol worship. Finally, the word “or” in the expression <b>“or from the flock”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal that <b>gored</b> and killed a person.
The Gemara challenges: In <b>these</b> cases of an animal that copulated with a person, an animal that was the subject of bestiality, and an animal that gored and killed a person, <b>they are liable to death</b> by stoning. Why, then, is a verse necessary to exclude them? The Gemara answers that this is referring to a case where the incident was known <b>on the basis</b> of the testimony <b>of one witness or on the basis of the owner.</b> Therefore, the animal is not killed, as there are not two witnesses to the event, but the testimony is sufficient to disqualify the animal as a sacrifice.
§ The mishna teaches that one does not slaughter a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite, neither in the Temple nor in the rest of the country. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> one does not slaughter <b>a <i>tumtum</i>, neither in the Temple,</b> as <b>perhaps it is a female</b> and therefore does not have firstborn status and may not be sacrificed, <b>nor in</b> the rest of <b>the country,</b> as <b>perhaps it is a male and it does not have a blemish,</b> in which case he would be slaughtering a sacrificial animal.
<b>But</b> in the case of <b>a hermaphrodite, granted</b> that one does <b>not</b> slaughter it <b>in the Temple,</b> as <b>perhaps it is a female. But with regard to</b> the rest of <b>the country, even let it be</b> considered <b>a male;</b> nevertheless, its <b>female</b> sex organ <b>should be considered</b> as <b>a crack [<i>ḥaritz</i>],</b> which is included in the blemish of “cracked” [<i>ḥarutz</i>] listed in the Torah (Leviticus 22:22), <b>and</b> let <b>one slaughter</b> it <b>due to</b> that blemish.
<b>Abaye said</b> in response: <b>The verse states: “Or cracked or broken”</b> (Leviticus 22:22), which teaches that the blemish of being <b>cracked is similar to</b> that of being <b>broken: Just as</b> the blemish of being <b>broken</b> is relevant <b>in the location of a bone,</b> as there is no break where there is only flesh, <b>so too,</b> the term <b>cracked</b> is referring to a blemish found <b>in the location of a bone,</b> not in the location of the sex organs.
<b>Rava said:</b> Even <b>without</b> the comparison to <b>“broken,” you cannot say that a crack in the location of flesh,</b> where there is no bone, <b>is a blemish. As, if</b> it would <b>enter your mind</b> that <b>it is a blemish, since</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> cited above <b>said</b> with regard to <b>“<i>garav</i>”</b> that <b>this is</b> referring to boils that are hard as <b>earthenware [<i>ḥeres</i>],</b> evidently this blemish is <b>a crack</b> in the skin, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to the skin disease of leprosy: <b>“And its appearance is deeper than the skin”</b> (Leviticus 13:30), and the Sages explained: <b>It is similar to the appearance of</b> an area lit by the <b>sun that</b> seems <b>deeper than the shade,</b> which appears to cover it.
<b>And</b> if so, <b>let the Merciful One write: Crack, and</b> it would <b>not need</b> to state <b><i>garav</i>, and I</b> would <b>say:</b> If being <b>cracked, which is not repulsive, is a blemish,</b> then with regard to <b><i>garav</i>, which is repulsive,</b> should it <b>not all the more so</b> be considered a blemish? Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes <i>garav</i>, to say that a crack</b> found <b>in the location of flesh is not a blemish.</b> Consequently, one cannot say that the female sex organ of a hermaphrodite should be considered a blemish for which one may slaughter a firstborn outside the Temple.
In this connection, the Gemara cites the statement of the mishna with regard to a hermaphrodite: <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: You have no blemish greater than that,</b> and it may be slaughtered. Evidently, Rabbi Yishmael maintains that the female sex organ of a hermaphrodite is considered a blemish. The Gemara explains: Rabbi Yishmael does <b>not state</b> a ruling <b>like</b> that of <b>Abaye,</b> as he maintains that <b>we do not say</b> that the blemish of being <b>cracked is similar to</b> that of being <b>broken.</b> Rather, they are entirely different blemishes, and a crack found on flesh is considered a blemish.
Rabbi Yishmael <b>also</b> does <b>not state</b> a ruling <b>like</b> that of <b>Rava,</b> as <b>perhaps</b> his conclusion that a crack found where there is no bone is not a blemish applies only in a case <b>where it is not conspicuous. But</b> in a case <b>where it is conspicuous,</b> such as the female sex organ, <b>we call it “an ill blemish”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:21), and the animal is disqualified for use as an offering.

Daf 41b

<b>Rava raises a dilemma: What is the reason of Rabbi Yishmael</b> that a hermaphrodite is definitely blemished? Is it <b>obvious to him</b> that <b>a hermaphrodite</b> animal <b>is</b> a male that has <b>firstborn</b> status, <b>and</b> it comes <b>with its blemish,</b> i.e., the female sex organ, and therefore it is permitted to slaughter it outside the Temple? <b>Or perhaps</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>is uncertain</b> whether or not a hermaphrodite is considered a male, <b>and he says</b> his ruling in the manner of: <b>If you say.</b> In other words, <b>if you say</b> that a hermaphrodite animal <b>is a firstborn,</b> it comes <b>with its blemish,</b> and it may be slaughtered outside the Temple.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> between the reasons? The Gemara answers that there is a difference with regard <b>to being flogged on account of</b> this animal <b>due to</b> violating the prohibition of <b>shearing and</b> utilizing a firstborn animal for <b>labor</b> (see Deuteronomy 15:19). If it is definitely a firstborn, then one would be flogged for violating the prohibition. But if one is uncertain whether it is a firstborn, although one may not shear it or perform labor with it, one is not liable to flogging for doing so. <b>Alternatively,</b> there is a difference with regard <b>to giving it to a priest.</b> If its status is uncertain, the priest cannot demand the animal from him, in accordance with the principle that the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Ilai says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: A hermaphrodite is a firstborn, and</b> it comes <b>with its blemish. Learn from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that it is <b>obvious to Rabbi Yishmael</b> that a hermaphrodite is a firstborn. The Gemara responds: <b>But perhaps he said</b> his ruling in the manner of: <b>If you say,</b> as explained earlier.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another <i>baraita</i>. It states with regard to a burnt offering from cattle: <b>“A male”</b> (Leviticus 1:3), from which it can be inferred: <b>But not a female. When it says below,</b> with regard to a burnt offering from sheep: <b>“A male”</b> (Leviticus 1:10), a second time, it is difficult to understand, <b>as</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> this. <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> “a male” again? This serves <b>to exclude a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite,</b> which are disqualified from being sacrificed as burnt offerings.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>Whose</b> opinion is this? <b>If we say</b> it is the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna, who maintains that a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite may not be slaughtered in the Temple or in the rest of the country, then the status of a hermaphrodite <b>is uncertain,</b> as it is unknown whether it is male or female. <b>But</b> does <b>a verse come to exclude</b> a case of <b>uncertainty?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the latter Rabbis</b> in the mishna, who hold that a hermaphrodite is definitely not a male, but a distinct entity. Therefore, it is necessary for a verse to exclude it. This, too, is difficult, as according to these Rabbis the exclusion of a female, a <i>tumtum</i>, and a hermaphrodite is <b>derived from one verse</b> alone. The Gemara elaborates: <b>As with regard to a firstborn, it is one “male” alone that is written,</b> from which the Rabbis <b>exclude all</b> of the three categories <b>from</b> firstborn status. By contrast, the <i>baraita</i> excludes a female from one mention of the word “male” and a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite from another mention of the word “male.”
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael. And</b> in that case, <b>granted, if you say</b> that it is <b>obvious to Rabbi Yishmael</b> that a hermaphrodite is a firstborn male, <b>that is</b> why <b>a verse was necessary to exclude</b> a hermaphrodite from being brought as a burnt offering. <b>But if you say</b> that Rabbi Yishmael <b>is uncertain</b> whether or not a hermaphrodite is considered a male, is it <b>necessary</b> for <b>the verse to exclude</b> a case of <b>uncertainty?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the latter Rabbis,</b> who maintain that a hermaphrodite is not a male, but a distinct entity. <b>And</b> as for the difficulty that in the case of a firstborn they excluded a female, a <i>tumtum</i>, and a hermaphrodite from a single verse, that is not so. <b>With regard to a firstborn</b> there are also <b>two verses written: “Males”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:19), and: <b>“That is a male”</b> (Exodus 13:12). As in the case of a burnt offering, one of these serves to exclude a female, while the other serves to exclude a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> A hermaphrodite <b>does not</b> have <b>firstborn</b> status; rather, its status is that of a non-sacred animal that may be shorn and utilized for labor. <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> This <b>dispute</b> applies <b>to a hermaphrodite,</b> which the Rabbis maintain is a distinct entity, as it has both male and female sex organs, and therefore it does not have firstborn status. <b>But with regard to a <i>tumtum</i>,</b> whose genitalia is covered by skin, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is an uncertain</b> case, as it is definitely either a male or a female, but there is uncertainty as to which it is. <b>And</b> consequently, it is <b>consecrated due to uncertainty,</b> and it may not be slaughtered either in the Temple or in the rest of the country.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>If that is so,</b> that a <i>tumtum</i> is certainly either a male or a female, <b>with regard to valuations,</b> when someone vows to give the valuation of a <i>tumtum</i>, <b>it should be valuated,</b> either in accordance with the valuation of a man or a woman.

Daf 42a

<b>Why,</b> then, <b>is</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse: “Then your valuation shall be for <b>the male”</b> (Leviticus 27:3), includes one whose status as a male is certain <b>but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Omit from</b> this <i>baraita</i> the mention of <b>a <i>tumtum</i>,</b> as it is referring only to a hermaphrodite, which is a distinct entity.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the continuation of that <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that these <b>shall not be</b> valuated according to <b>the valuation of a man, but</b> they <b>shall be</b> valuated according to <b>the valuation of a woman.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “The male,”</b> and in the following verse it states: “And <b>if</b> she is <b>a female,</b> then your valuation shall be thirty shekels” (Leviticus 27:4), indicating only one whose status as a male or female is certain, <b>but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite,</b> which are categorized as neither male nor female. The Gemara again answers: <b>Omit from</b> this <i>baraita</i> the mention of <b>a <i>tumtum</i>,</b> as it is referring only to a hermaphrodite.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> discussing the peace offering, with regard to which it states: <b>“Whether male or female”</b> (Leviticus 3:1). This indicates: Only <b>a definite male</b> or <b>a definite female, but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b> Yet again the Gemara responds: <b>Omit from</b> this <i>baraita</i> the mention of <b>a <i>tumtum</i>.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: It states with regard to a burnt offering from cattle: <b>“A male”</b> (Leviticus 1:3), from which it can be inferred: <b>But not a female. When it says below,</b> with regard to a burnt offering from sheep: <b>“A male”</b> (Leviticus 1:10), a second time, it is difficult to understand, <b>as</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> this. <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> “a male” again? This serves <b>to exclude a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite,</b> which are disqualified as burnt offerings. The Gemara answers: <b>Omit from</b> this <i>baraita</i> the mention of <b>a <i>tumtum</i>.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> discussing the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity imparted by a bird in the throat: Any bird that was not slaughtered in the proper manner, i.e., in its neck with a knife, has the status of a carcass. This carcass renders the one who eats it impure when it is in his throat. Bird offerings, which are killed by pinching the nape of the neck with a fingernail, are the exception to this principle, and they do not impart impurity. With regard to a bird <b>that is worshipped</b> as a deity, <b>or one set aside</b> for idol worship, <b>or one</b> given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute, <b>or one</b> that was given as <b>the price</b> of a dog (see Deuteronomy 23:19), <b>and</b> similarly with regard to a bird that is <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite,</b> if one killed any of them by pinching, they are ritually impure, as they are disqualified as offerings, and the pinching does not purify them. Therefore, <b>they all render</b> a person and the <b>garments</b> he is wearing <b>ritually impure</b> if an olive-bulk of them comes into contact <b>with the throat</b> while eating.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If one pinched the neck of <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite, it does not render</b> the person and <b>the garments</b> he is wearing <b>ritually impure</b> when they are <b>in the throat,</b> as they are in fact fit to be sacrificed. <b>As Rabbi Eliezer would say: Wherever it is stated</b> explicitly in the Torah: <b>“Male,” and: “Female,” you</b> should <b>exclude a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite from among them,</b> as their status is uncertain. This applies to animal offerings, with regard to which the Torah states “male” and “female.”
<b>But</b> in the case of <b>a bird</b> offering, <b>since “male” and “female” are not stated with regard to it,</b> but simply doves and pigeons are stated with regard to it, <b>you do not exclude a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite from among them,</b> as they are fit for the altar. Now if a <i>tumtum</i> is considered either definitely a male or a female, then why does the first <i>tanna</i> disqualify it from being sacrificed? The Gemara again replies: <b>Omit from</b> this <i>baraita</i> the mention of <b>a <i>tumtum</i>.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: An animal with a condition that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>], and</b> prohibited <b>diverse kinds</b> of livestock, <b>and</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section,</b> and an animal that is <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite do not become consecrated and do not render</b> another animal <b>consecrated</b> in their place.
<b>And Shmuel says</b> in explanation: <b>They do not become consecrated by substitution,</b> i.e., if one sought to substitute one of these animals for a sacrificial animal, it does not become sacred. <b>And</b> if one of these was born to a sacrificial animal, <b>they do not render</b> a non-sacred animal <b>consecrated</b> in a case where one wanted <b>to render</b> it <b>a substitute</b> for them. And if a <i>tumtum</i> is either a male or female, why would it not become consecrated and render another animal consecrated? The Gemara answers: <b>Omit from</b> this <i>baraita</i> the mention of <b>a <i>tumtum</i>.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a slightly different version of that <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> There are <b>five</b> types of animals that <b>do not become consecrated and do not render</b> another animal <b>consecrated, and they are: A <i>tereifa</i>, and</b> prohibited <b>diverse kinds</b> of livestock, <b>and</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section, and</b> an animal that is <b>a <i>tumtum</i>, and a hermaphrodite. And if you would say: Here too, omit from this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>a <i>tumtum</i>,</b> then <b>there are</b> only <b>four</b> types of animals listed in the <i>baraita</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>Remove</b> the mention of <b>a <i>tumtum</i> and</b> in its place <b>insert an orphan,</b> i.e., an animal born after the death of its mother, which is also disqualified as a sacrifice.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this question of whether a <i>tumtum</i> is a distinct entity or is definitely either a male or female <b>is the subject of</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> As it is taught in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ilai says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: A hermaphrodite is a firstborn, and</b> it comes <b>with its blemish; and the Rabbis say: It is not imbued with sanctity. Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> The verse <b>states: “Males”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:19), <b>and wherever it is stated: Male,”</b> this serves <b>to exclude only a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite.</b> Since according to Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda it is necessary for a verse to exclude a <i>tumtum</i>, like a hermaphrodite, from the category of a male, evidently in his opinion a <i>tumtum</i> is not considered to be one whose status as a male is uncertain but a distinct entity.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>And if you would say:</b> Here too, <b>omit from</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>a <i>tumtum</i>,</b> then the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda is</b> the same as that of <b>the Rabbis,</b> as they too maintain that a hermaphrodite is not sacred. <b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> that the difference <b>between them</b> is with regard to the status of <b>a <i>tumtum</i>, as the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds: It is not imbued with sanctity,</b> and they are referring specifically <b>to a hermaphrodite,</b> which was the subject of Rabbi Ilai’s statement, <b>but a <i>tumtum</i> is an uncertain</b> case, <b>and</b> therefore <b>it is sacred due to uncertainty. And Rabbi Shimon</b>

Daf 42b

<b>ben Yehuda comes to say: A <i>tumtum</i> is</b> not of uncertain status, but a distinct <b>entity, and it is not sacred</b> at all. The Gemara responds: <b>No, everyone</b> agrees <b>with regard to</b> the statement that <b>a <i>tumtum</i> is</b> a distinct <b>entity</b> that <b>there is no doubt</b> that this is incorrect. <b>Where</b> there is <b>doubt is</b> with regard to whether it is <b>a male or a female.</b>
In addition, in a case where the <i>tumtum</i> <b>urinates from the place of the male</b> sex organ, then <b>everyone agrees that it is a male. When they disagree</b> is in the case <b>of</b> a <i>tumtum</i> that <b>urinates from the place of the female</b> sex organ. One <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps its male</b> sex organ <b>was inverted toward its female</b> sex organ; therefore, it is of uncertain status. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>we are not concerned</b> about this possibility; rather, it is definitely a female. And Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda maintains <b>in accordance with that which Rabbi Elazar ruled: With regard to</b> a firstborn <b>animal</b> that <b>urinates from the place</b> where <b>the female</b> sex organ is found, it is <b>non-sacred,</b> as it is certainly a female.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan wondered</b> about this ruling of Rabbi Elazar: <b>Who</b> is the Sage <b>who is not concerned about</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i></b> in the mishna <b>and about</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> who maintain that a <i>tumtum</i> is a case of uncertainty? The Gemara asks: <b>And let Rabbi Yoḥanan also say: Who</b> is this <b>who is not concerned about</b> the opinion of <b>the latter Rabbis</b> in the mishna, <b>as Rav Ḥisda says:</b> This <b>dispute</b> refers <b>to a hermaphrodite; but with regard to a <i>tumtum</i>, everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is an uncertain</b> case.
The Gemara explains that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan does not hold</b> in accordance with that statement <b>of Rav Ḥisda;</b> rather, he maintains that according to the latter Rabbis a <i>tumtum</i> is a distinct entity. The Gemara asks: <b>If Rabbi Yoḥanan does not hold</b> in accordance with Rav Ḥisda, why did he wonder about Rabbi Elazar’s ruling? <b>Let him say that</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>said</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the latter Rabbis.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That is indeed what he is saying: Who</b> is the Sage <b>who leaves</b> aside the opinion of <b>two</b> Sages, the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yishmael, <b>and acts in accordance with one</b> opinion, the latter Rabbis?
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Elazar, in accordance with whose</b> opinion does <b>he hold?</b> The Gemara answers that he holds <b>in accordance with that which Reish Lakish says:</b> The Sages <b>said that</b> the halakhic status of <b>a <i>tumtum</i> is an uncertain</b> case <b>only with regard to a person, since the male</b> sex organ <b>and the female</b> sex organ <b>are in one place,</b> i.e., a man and a woman urinate from the same area of the body. Since that area is concealed in the case of a <i>tumtum</i>, its status is uncertain. <b>But</b> with regard to a <i>tumtum</i> <b>animal,</b> there is no uncertainty whether it is a male or a female, as the genitals of a male and a female are not found in the same place. Rather, if it <b>urinates from the place</b> of <b>the male</b> sex organ, it is <b>a male;</b> if it <b>urinates from the place of the female</b> sex organ, it is <b>a female.</b>
<b>Rav Oshaya objects to this: And let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps its male</b> sex organ <b>was turned round to</b> the place of <b>its female</b> sex organ. Abaye <b>said to him: In accordance with whose</b> opinion do you raise this objection? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who is concerned about the minority</b> of cases? The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, and therefore one should follow the majority of animals, to whom this does not occur.
<b>Abaye bar Avin and Rav Ḥananya bar Avin both say: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that Rav Oshaya’s objection is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who are not concerned about a minority. The reason is that <b>since</b> in this case, the animal <b>has changed</b> in that it is different from typical animals, as it is a <i>tumtum</i>, perhaps it is also <b>changed</b> with regard to its male sex organ being inverted toward the female sex organ. If so, the Sages disagree with regard to this principle: <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that since it has changed, it has <b>changed, and there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that the claim that since it has changed, it has <b>changed</b> is <b>not</b> accepted.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the question of whether an animal that has changed in one respect has <b>changed</b> in a different respect, <b>or</b> whether it has <b>not changed,</b> is the subject of a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a <i>tumtum</i> who betrothed</b> a woman, the <b>betrothal is</b> considered <b>a betrothal,</b> due to uncertainty, as the <i>tumtum</i> might be a male; and similarly, if the <i>tumtum</i> <b>was betrothed</b> by a man, the <b>betrothal is</b> deemed <b>a betrothal</b> due to uncertainty, as the <i>tumtum</i> might be a female.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> if the brother of the <i>tumtum</i> died childless, and there is no other brother who can perform levirate marriage with the widow, the <i>tumtum</i> <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> i.e., his brother’s widow removes his shoe, as the <i>tumtum</i> might be a male, and she would require <i>ḥalitza</i> to release her from the levirate bond. <b>And</b> if the <i>tumtum</i> died, one of the brothers of the <i>tumtum</i> <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with the wife of</b> the <i>tumtum</i>, <b>or enters into levirate marriage with the wife of</b> the <i>tumtum</i>, in case the <i>tumtum</i> was a male. <b>And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>The wife of a <i>tumtum</i> performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and does not enter into levirate marriage.</b>
With regard to these two <i>baraitot</i>, the Sages <b>assumed that everyone</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says: A eunuch</b> whose condition is caused <b>naturally,</b> i.e., one who was entirely lacking in sexual capacity from birth, <b>does not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and does not enter into levirate marriage</b> with his sister-in-law, as he is not included in the mitzva of levirate marriage. Likewise, if he died his brothers do not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with his wife, and they may not enter into levirate marriage with her, as she is forbidden to them as a brother’s wife who does not require levirate marriage.
Based on this assumption, the Gemara suggests: <b>What, is it not</b> that the two <i>baraitot</i> <b>disagree about this, that the one who says</b> that a <i>tumtum</i> <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and</b> one of the brothers <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with the wife of</b> the <i>tumtum</i> <b>or enters into levirate marriage with the wife of</b> the <i>tumtum</i> holds that <b>we do not say</b> that <b>since</b> this <i>tumtum</i> has <b>changed</b> from an average person, he might also have <b>changed</b> in that he is a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally, and therefore the brothers would be prohibited from entering into levirate marriage with the wife? Rather, if the <i>tumtum</i> is a male, it is assumed that he is capable of fathering children, and consequently his wife requires levirate marriage.
<b>And the one who says</b> that the wife of a <i>tumtum</i> <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and does not enter into levirate marriage</b> maintains that <b>we say</b> that <b>since</b> this person has <b>changed,</b> he has <b>changed,</b> i.e., the possibility that he might be a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally is considered, and therefore his wife may not enter into levirate marriage.
The Gemara responds: <b>No; everyone</b> agrees that <b>we say</b> that <b>since</b> this person has <b>changed,</b> he has <b>changed,</b> and there is a concern that he might be a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally. Rather, the difference between the rulings is that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits the wife of the <i>tumtum</i> to enter levirate marriage, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who disagrees with Rabbi Akiva and maintains that levirate marriage may be performed with the wife of a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally, <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits levirate marriage, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> that the brothers of a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally do not enter into levirate marriage with the wife of the <i>tumtum</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva</b> that the wife of a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally does not require levirate marriage, and yet he maintains that the wife of a <i>tumtum</i> must perform <i>ḥalitza</i>? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> this cannot be, as in his opinion even if the genitals of a <i>tumtum</i> were revealed and he was found to be a male, <b>he deems him</b> like <b>a definite eunuch</b> whose condition is caused naturally, and therefore his wife does not require <i>ḥalitza</i> at all.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Yevamot</i> 81a) that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>a <i>tumtum</i> who was torn</b> open so that his genitals were exposed, <b>and he was found</b> to be <b>a male,</b> he <b>must not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, because he is</b> treated <b>like a eunuch</b> whose condition is caused naturally. Just as this <i>tumtum</i> does not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, so too, his widow does not require <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>Rather, it is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that if a <i>tumtum</i> was torn open and he was found to be a male, he is considered as a matter of uncertainty to be a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally, and consequently his wife requires <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: A <i>tumtum</i> does not perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with the wife of his late, childless brother if there are other brothers to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, as <b>perhaps</b> the skin covering his genitals <b>will be torn</b> open <b>and he will be found</b> to be <b>a eunuch</b> whose condition is caused <b>naturally,</b> and the widow would not be released from the levirate bond by his <i>ḥalitza</i>. According to this opinion, it is not certain that a <i>tumtum</i> would be found to be a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally.
With regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, the Gemara asks: Why does this individual not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> due only to the possibility that he will be found to be a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally? <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>every</b> <i>tumtum</i> <b>whose</b> skin <b>was torn is found</b> to be <b>a male</b> and is <b>not found</b> to be <b>a female?</b> The Gemara explains that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>said</b> his opinion in the formulation of: <b>Perhaps,</b> which includes multiple uncertainties: A <i>tumtum</i> must not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, as <b>perhaps he will be torn</b> open <b>and found</b> to be <b>a female,</b> who can certainly not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>Alternatively,</b> if he is found to be <b>a male,</b> he may <b>also</b> not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, since <b>perhaps he will be found</b> to be <b>a eunuch</b> whose condition is caused <b>naturally.</b> The Gemara asks: Since both Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, agree that a <i>tumtum</i> may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> for his brother’s wife, <b>what is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> their opinions? <b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 43a

There is a practical difference <b>with regard to disqualifying</b> the widow, through his <i>ḥalitza</i>, from entering into levirate marriage <b>in a case</b> where there are other <b>brothers.</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, who maintains that this individual is certainly a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally, his <i>ḥalitza</i> is of no effect whatsoever, and therefore she may enter into levirate marriage with one of the other brothers. Conversely, according to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, since it is possible that he is not a eunuch and his <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid, she is forbidden to the other brothers as their brother’s wife.
<b>And</b> there is also a practical difference <b>between their</b> opinions <b>with regard to performing <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with the widow <b>in a case where there are no brothers</b> other than this <i>tumtum</i>. According to Rabbi Yehuda, <i>ḥalitza</i> is not necessary in this case, as she requires <i>ḥalitza</i> only if her late husband had brothers who are obligated to perform levirate marriage, and this individual is definitely a eunuch whose condition is caused naturally. By contrast, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, maintains that he must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her, in case he is a male and not a eunuch.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Concerning <b>these blemishes</b> which were taught with regard to an animal, <b>whether</b> they are <b>permanent or transient, they</b> also <b>disqualify in</b> the case of <b>a person,</b> i.e., they disqualify a priest from performing the Temple service. <b>And in addition to those</b> blemishes, there are other blemishes that apply only to a priest: <b>One whose</b> head <b>is pointed,</b> narrow above and wide below; <b>and one whose</b> head <b>is turnip-like,</b> wide above and narrow below; <b>and one whose</b> head <b>is hammer-like,</b> with his forehead protruding; <b>and</b> one <b>whose head</b> has <b>an indentation; and</b> one <b>wherein the back of his head protrudes.</b>
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>those with humped</b> backs, <b>Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> them <b>fit</b> for service <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> them <b>disqualified. The <i>kere’aḥ</i> is disqualified</b> from performing the Temple service. <b>What is a <i>kere’aḥ</i>?</b> It is <b>anyone who does not have a row of hair encircling</b> his head <b>from ear to ear. If he has</b> a row of hair from ear to ear, <b>that</b> person is <b>fit</b> for service.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> does the mishna say that all the blemishes that disqualify an animal disqualify a priest as well? <b>But there is</b> the blemish of <b>a wart, which is not written in the Torah with regard to a person</b> but is written with regard to an animal (see Leviticus 22:22). <b>And furthermore,</b> there are also the blemishes of <b>a cataract</b> and <b>a <i>tevallul</i>, which</b> appear in the Torah with regard to a person but <b>are not written</b> in the Torah <b>with regard to an animal</b> (see Leviticus 21:20). Why, then, does the mishna on 38a teach that such blemishes disqualify an animal?
The Gemara responds: These blemishes <b>are derived from one another, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In</b> the case of <b>a person,</b> i.e., a priest, <b>it is not stated of him</b> that <b>a wart</b> disqualifies him from Temple service, and <b>in</b> the case of <b>an animal, it is not stated</b> that <b>a cataract</b> or <b>a <i>tevallul</i></b> disqualify it from being sacrificed. <b>From where</b> is it derived that one <b>applies that which is said of this</b> case <b>to that</b> case, <b>and that which is said of this</b> case <b>to that</b> case? <b>The verse states: “Scabbed”</b> and <b>“scabbed,” “scurvy”</b> and <b>“scurvy,”</b> both with regard to a person and an animal (Leviticus 21:20; 22:22), which serves <b>to</b> draw <b>a verbal analogy</b> from the verses.
The Gemara notes: These verses must be <b>free,</b> i.e., they are superfluous and are stated only for the purpose of the verbal analogy. This means that the verbal analogy cannot be refuted by logical reasoning, whereas if the verses are not free one can refute the analogy if there is a significant difference between the two cases. <b>As, if they are not free,</b> the verbal analogy <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: One <b>cannot derive</b> the disqualifications of <b>a person</b> for performing the Temple service <b>from</b> those of <b>an animal,</b> as the case of an animal can be considered more stringent <b>because</b> the animal <b>itself is sacrificed upon the altar.</b> Similarly, one <b>cannot derive</b> the disqualifications of <b>an animal from</b> those of <b>a person,</b> as one can claim that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a person should be more stringent, <b>since</b> a person <b>was included in</b> the performance of <b>mitzvot.</b>
<b>Indeed,</b> the terms <b>are free.</b> Accordingly, since these disqualifications are derived from a verbal analogy they must be accepted as though they were written explicitly in the Torah. The Gemara proves these verses are free: <b>Let the Merciful One write</b> that <b>scurvy</b> disqualifies a person and an animal, <b>and</b> it would be <b>unnecessary</b> for the Merciful One to write that <b>a scab</b> disqualifies them, as <b>I would say: And if scurvy, which is not repulsive, is</b> considered a disqualifying <b>blemish,</b> then in the case of <b>a scab, which is repulsive,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> a disqualifying blemish? If so, then with regard to <b>“scabbed”</b> and <b>“scabbed,” which the Merciful One writes</b> with regard to a person and an animal, <b>why do I</b> need them? Evidently, they are <b>to</b> be considered <b>free</b> for the verbal analogy.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> if animals and priests are disqualified by the same blemishes, <b>let the Merciful One write all the</b> disqualifying blemishes <b>with regard to one</b> of them, either a person or an animal, <b>and</b> let the Merciful One write that <b>a scab and scurvy</b> disqualify both <b>here and here,</b> for the purpose of the verbal analogy, <b>and let</b> all the other blemishes <b>be derived</b> in one case <b>from</b> the other <b>one,</b> through the verbal analogy.
The Gemara responds: <b>To which</b> is this referring, i.e., <b>in which</b> case <b>should the Merciful One write</b> all the blemishes? <b>If</b> the Merciful One had <b>written</b> all of them <b>with regard to a person</b> then <b>I would say: All</b> blemishes <b>that disqualify in</b> the case of <b>a person</b> likewise <b>disqualify in</b> the case of <b>an animal.</b> If so, then with regard to <b>closed</b> hooves <b>and</b> damaged <b>gums, which are not</b> written <b>with regard to a person</b> as they are not relevant because a person has no hooves and his gums are covered with teeth, I would say: <b>In</b> the case of <b>an animal as well they should not disqualify.</b>
<b>And</b> if you would say: <b>Let the Merciful One write all</b> the blemishes <b>with regard to an animal, I would say: All</b> blemishes <b>that disqualify in</b> the case of <b>an animal</b> likewise <b>disqualify in</b> the case of <b>a person.</b> Accordingly, with regard to <b>a <i>gibben</i>,</b> one with blemished eyebrows, <b>or a <i>ḥarum</i>,</b> one with a sunken nose, <b>which are not</b> written <b>with regard to an animal</b> as such blemishes do not occur among animals, I would say: <b>In</b> the case of <b>a person as well they should not disqualify.</b> Therefore, the Torah delineates all the disqualifying blemishes with regard to both an animal and a person in order to state the blemishes that are unique to animals and the blemishes that are unique to people.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> even so, why is it necessary for the Torah to delineate all the common blemishes? <b>Let the Merciful One write all of them in</b> the verses discussing <b>one</b> of them, either an animal or a person, <b>and</b> as for <b>those that are not</b> relevant <b>for the other,</b> i.e., those blemishes that apply only in the case of an animal, <b>let the Merciful One write with regard to an animal, and</b> as for <b>those that are not</b> relevant <b>for the other,</b> i.e., those blemishes relevant only to a person, <b>let</b> the Merciful One <b>write with regard to a person. And</b> let the Torah write the blemishes of <b>a scab and scurvy</b> both <b>here and there,</b> for the purpose of the verbal analogy, <b>and let</b> the fact that their common blemishes disqualify in both cases <b>be derived from one another.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the reason the Torah repeats their common blemishes is <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught, as the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Every passage</b> in the Torah <b>that was stated and repeated was repeated only for the novel element introduced therein.</b> It is the style of the Torah to repeat a passage even in order to teach only one additional <i>halakha</i>. Consequently, with regard to the blemishes of a person and an animal, their common blemishes were repeated on account of those blemishes that apply only to an animal or a person.
§ <b>Rava says: Why do I</b> need <b>the Merciful One to write</b> that <b>a blemish</b> causes disqualification from Temple service <b>in</b> the case of <b>a person,</b> i.e., a priest (see Leviticus 21:17–23), and that <b>a blemish</b> causes disqualification <b>in</b> the case of <b>sacrificial</b> animals (see Leviticus 22:20–25), and that <b>a blemish</b> causes disqualification for sacrifice <b>in</b> the case of <b>a firstborn</b> animal (see Deuteronomy 15:21)?
Rava answers: They are all <b>necessary. As, had the Merciful One written</b> only that <b>a blemish</b> causes disqualification <b>in</b> the case of <b>a person,</b> one might suggest that blemishes cause disqualification only in that case, <b>since</b> a person <b>was included in</b> the performance of <b>mitzvot.</b> Similarly, had the Merciful One written only that blemishes disqualify a firstborn animal from being sacrificed, it could be claimed that one <b>cannot derive</b> the disqualification of <b>a person</b> on account of blemishes <b>from</b> the disqualification of <b>a firstborn animal, since</b> an animal has an added aspect of stringency in that <b>it itself is sacrificed upon the altar.</b>
Additionally, one <b>cannot derive</b> the disqualifications of <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>from</b> those of <b>a firstborn</b> animal, <b>since</b> the <b>sanctity of</b> a firstborn animal is <b>from the womb,</b> i.e., from birth, whereas the sanctity of other offerings applies only upon consecration by a person, and they are therefore of a lesser sanctity.
Furthermore, had the Merciful One written only that sacrificial animals are disqualified due to blemishes, it could be claimed that one <b>cannot derive</b> the disqualifications of <b>a person from</b> that of <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>as</b> the offerings <b>themselves are sacrificed.</b> Similarly, one <b>cannot derive</b> the disqualifications of <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>from</b> those of <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>as the sanctity</b> of other offerings <b>is greater</b> than that of a firstborn animal because there are many types of other offerings, whereas a firstborn animal has only one type of sanctification. Therefore, it was necessary for the Merciful One to specify that blemishes disqualify in each case.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: Granted, the disqualification of <b>one</b> of these cases <b>cannot be derived from</b> only a single other <b>one.</b> But <b>let one</b> of them <b>be derived from</b> the other <b>two.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>From which</b> two <b>should</b> the other one <b>be derived?</b> If you will say: <b>Let the Merciful One not write that</b> blemishes disqualify <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>and</b> one should <b>derive</b> that case <b>from these,</b> i.e., the disqualifications of a person and sacrificial animals, this suggestion can be rejected. <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these?</b> They are notable <b>in that their sanctity is greater</b> than that of a firstborn offering, as in the case of a person, he is included in the performance of mitzvot; and in the case of a sacrificial animal, there are many types of offerings. <b>Moreover,</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of these blemishes <b>apply to regular,</b> i.e., non-firstborn, animals and people.
Furthermore, if one will say: Let the Merciful One not write that blemishes disqualify <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>and</b> one should <b>derive</b> that case <b>from these</b> cases, a person, i.e., a priest, and a firstborn animal, this too can be rejected: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these?</b> They are notable <b>in that their sanctity is automatic</b> and requires no consecration, as a priest is a priest by virtue of being the son of a priest, and a firstborn attains its status by being the first child of its mother, while offerings are consecrated by their owners.
Finally, if one will say: Let the Merciful One not write that blemishes disqualify <b>a person and</b> one should <b>derive</b> that case <b>from these</b> cases, the firstborn animal and sacrificial animals, this suggestion too can be rejected: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these?</b> They are notable <b>in that they themselves are sacrificed upon the altar,</b> whereas a person is not. Therefore, all three verses <b>are necessary,</b> to teach that blemishes disqualify in all these cases.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>in addition to those</b> blemishes that disqualify an animal, there are other blemishes that apply <b>to a person</b> despite the fact that they are not actual defects. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> These <i>halakhot</i> are derived from <b>that</b> which <b>the verse states: “No man among the seed of Aaron the priest who has a blemish</b> shall come forward to sacrifice the offerings of the Lord made by fire” (Leviticus 21:21). The verse indicates that the priest must be <b>a man who is equal among the seed of Aaron,</b> i.e., one whose appearance is similar to the other priests.

Daf 43b

The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> a priest disqualified from performing the Temple service due to a full-fledged <b>blemish</b> that disqualifies both people and animals, and a priest disqualified from performing the Temple service because <b>he is not equal among the seed of Aaron?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>There is</b> a difference between them <b>with regard to profaning</b> the Temple <b>service.</b> A priest with a full-fledged <b>blemish</b> who performs rites in the Temple <b>profanes</b> the <b>service</b> he has performed, <b>as it is written: “He has a blemish; that he not profane</b> My Sanctuaries” (Leviticus 21:23). A priest <b>who is not equal among the seed of Aaron</b> does <b>not profane</b> the <b>service</b> he performs.
The Gemara further asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> a priest disqualified from performing the Temple service because <b>he is not equal among the seed of Aaron,</b> e.g., one whose head is pointed, <b>and</b> a priest disqualified from performing the Temple service <b>due to the</b> mere <b>appearance of</b> a blemish, such as one whose eyelashes have fallen out, as stated in the <i>mishnayot</i> further on in this chapter? The Gemara responds: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to the violation of the prohibition, which is stated as <b>a positive mitzva,</b> i.e., that priests who are equal shall serve in the Temple. A priest who is not equal among the seed of Aaron who performs the Temple service transgresses this prohibition. By contrast, a priest who is disqualified due to the appearance of a blemish is disqualified by rabbinic law, and he does not transgress a Torah prohibition by performing the Temple service.
§ The Gemara clarifies the blemishes that the mishna lists as disqualifying a priest: <b>One whose</b> head <b>is pointed [<i>kilon</i>],</b> this is one <b>whose head resembles the cover of a barrel,</b> narrow above and wide below. <b>One whose</b> head <b>is turnip-like,</b> this is one <b>whose head resembles the top of a turnip,</b> wide above and narrow below. The Sages <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> another detail relating to this blemish: <b>And his neck stands in the middle of his head,</b> i.e., his head protrudes equally in all directions around his neck, whereas a typical person’s neck is situated at the back of his head.
<b>One whose</b> head <b>is hammer-like [<i>makkavan</i>],</b> this is one <b>whose head resembles a hammer,</b> with his forehead protruding. <b>And</b> one <b>whose</b> head is <b>indented [<i>shakut</i>],</b> this is one with a depression <b>in the front of his</b> head. <b>And</b> one <b>wherein the back of his head protrudes [<i>sekifat</i>]</b> is someone for whom it appears a piece <b>from the back of his</b> head has been removed, <b>as people say: A piece has been taken [<i>shakil pisa</i>].</b> <i>Sekifat</i> is understood to be an abbreviation of that term. The Sages <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> a priest <b>whose neck is short, or</b> one whose neck <b>is narrow,</b> is disqualified from performing the Temple service as well. A priest with <b>a short</b> neck is one <b>whose</b> neck <b>is hidden</b> and is not visible between his shoulders. A priest with <b>a narrow</b> neck is one <b>whose</b> neck <b>is long and narrow.</b>
The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>those with humped</b> backs, <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> deems them fit for service and the Rabbis deem them disqualified. The Gemara elaborates: In a case <b>where there is a bone in</b> his hump, <b>everyone agrees that</b> the priest is <b>disqualified</b> for Temple service. <b>They disagree when there is no bone.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>this</b> person <b>is not equal among the seed of Aaron</b> and is therefore disqualified from performing the Temple service; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>it is merely a piece of flesh</b> and is not considered a blemish.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>the <i>kere’aḥ</i>,</b> i.e., anyone who does not have a row of hair encircling his head from ear to ear, <b>is disqualified</b> from performing the Temple service. <b>Rava says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that a <i>kere’aḥ</i> is disqualified <b>only if he does not have</b> a row of hair <b>in the back</b> of <b>his</b> head <b>but he has</b> a row of hair <b>in the front. But</b> if <b>he has</b> a row of hair both in the front and <b>in the back,</b> he is <b>fit</b> for performing the Temple service. <b>And all the more so, when he has</b> hair <b>in the back but he does not have in the front</b> he is fit for performing the Temple service, as this is typical of older men.
<b>And there are those who teach</b> the statement of Rava <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And if he has</b> a row of hair, <b>that</b> person is <b>fit</b> for performing the Temple service. <b>Rava says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that such a person is fit <b>only when he has</b> a row of hair <b>in the back but he does not have in the front. But</b> if <b>he has</b> a row of hair <b>both in the back and in the front,</b> he is <b>disqualified</b> from performing the Temple service. <b>And all the more so,</b> one <b>who has</b> a row of hair <b>in the front and does not have in the back, or</b> one <b>who does not have</b> any hair <b>at all,</b> is <b>disqualified.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The bald</b> priests, <b>and the</b> priests who are <b>dwarves, and the</b> priests with <b>leaky</b> eyes, are <b>disqualified</b> from performing the Temple service, <b>since they are not equal among the seed of Aaron.</b> The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary for Rabbi Yoḥanan to state this? With regard to <b>bald</b> priests, <b>we learn</b> in the mishna that they are disqualified. Similarly, with regard to priests who are <b>dwarves, we learn</b> in a mishna (45b) that they are disqualified.
The Gemara responds: <b>It was necessary for him to teach us</b> this statement with regard to priests with <b>leaky</b> eyes, as the <i>halakha</i> with regard to them does not appear in any mishna. <b>And</b> furthermore, it was necessary for him to reiterate the <i>halakha</i> with regard to bald priests and dwarves <b>lest you say</b> they are disqualified only by rabbinic law, <b>due to the appearance</b> of a blemish.
