This is not effective, as the Torah requires redemption with actual money.
<b>A <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>in the presence of Rav Naḥman: His son is redeemed when</b> the father <b>gives</b> the money. <b>Rav Naḥman said to him: This</b> <i>baraita</i> is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> which was recorded as <b>unattributed. And some say: This</b> <i>baraita</i> is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> which was recorded as <b>unattributed. But the Rabbis say his son is not redeemed.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>his son is not redeemed.</b>
§ The mishna further teaches: <b>Therefore, if the priest wished to give</b> back the five <i>sela</i> coins <b>to him as a gift</b> he is <b>permitted</b> to do so. The Gemara comments: <b>We learn</b> in the mishna <b>that which the Sages taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: If the father <b>gave</b> the redemption money for his son <b>to ten priests all at once,</b> i.e., he placed five <i>sela</i> coins in front of a group of ten priests, he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. If he gave it to them <b>one after the other,</b> he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. If a priest <b>took</b> the redemption money <b>and returned it to</b> the father, the father has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation.
<b>And this was the practice of Rabbi Tarfon, as he would take</b> the redemption money <b>and return it. And when the Sages heard of</b> this <b>matter they said: This</b> individual <b>has fulfilled this <i>halakha</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: Has he fulfilled only <b>this <i>halakha</i> and nothing more?</b> Certainly, Rabbi Tarfon fulfilled many <i>halakhot</i>. <b>Rather,</b> they meant: <b>This</b> individual <b>fulfilled even this <i>halakha</i>.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> a priest, <b>was accustomed</b> to <b>take</b> the redemption money <b>and return it.</b> On one occasion, <b>he saw that a certain man</b> from whom he had received the redemption money for his son <b>was passing to and fro before him,</b> to hint to Rabbi Ḥanina that he should return the money. Rabbi Ḥanina <b>said to him:</b> Evidently, <b>you did not conclusively</b> resolve to <b>give</b> the money. This is <b>a bad matter,</b> and <b>therefore his son is not redeemed.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>one who designates</b> five <i>sela</i> coins for <b>redemption of his son and he lost</b> the money before he gave it to the priest, the father <b>bears</b> financial <b>responsibility for its</b> loss. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> It is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between <b>“valuation” and “valuation,” from</b> the passage discussing <b>valuations.</b> With regard to a firstborn son it states: “From a month old you shall redeem, according to your valuation” (Numbers 18:16), and it is written with regard to valuations: “And he shall give your valuation on that day” (Leviticus 27:23). Just as one bears financial responsibility to pay for valuations, the same applies to redemption money.
<b>Rav Dimi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan</b> says: The verse states concerning the redemption of the firstborn: <b>“And every firstborn of your sons you shall redeem, and none shall appear before Me empty”</b> (Exodus 34:20). <b>And</b> therefore this <i>halakha</i> is <b>derived</b> through a verbal analogy between <b>“empty”</b> and <b>“empty,” from</b> the passage discussing <b>the burnt offering of appearance,</b> which every pilgrim must bring on a Festival. With regard to the burnt offering of appearance it states: “And none shall appear before Me empty” (Exodus 23:15). <b>Just as</b> in the case of the <b>burnt offering of appearance one bears</b> financial <b>responsibility</b> for the loss of the offering, <b>so too,</b> with regard to the <b>redemption of the firstborn one bears</b> financial <b>responsibility</b> for its loss as well.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this:</b> Is it necessary here to cite one <b>verse in</b> support of another <b>verse?</b> The mishna itself cites the verse that is the source of the <i>halakha</i> that the father bears financial responsibility for the redemption money. <b>Rather, Rav Pappa says:</b> The reason for <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> is <b>the reason that</b> the mishna itself <b>teaches:</b> “Everything that opens the womb in man and animal <b>shall be yours; yet you shall redeem</b> the firstborn of man” (Numbers 18:15).
<b>And when</b> the comment <b>of Reish Lakish was stated,</b> it <b>was stated with regard to the first clause</b> of the mishna (49a), which teaches: If the firstborn son <b>dies after thirty days</b> have passed, <b>even if</b> the father <b>did not</b> yet <b>give</b> five <i>sela</i> coins to the priest <b>he must give</b> them then. <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> It is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between <b>“valuation”</b> and <b>“valuation,” from</b> the passage discussing <b>valuations.</b> Just as in a case where one says: It is incumbent upon me to donate so-and-so’s valuation, he must do so even if that individual dies, so too, concerning the redemption of the firstborn the father must pay even though his son died.
<b>Rav Dimi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan</b> says: It is written with regard to the redemption of the firstborn: <b>“And all the firstborn of your sons you shall redeem, and none shall appear before Me empty”</b> (Exodus 34:20), and it likewise states with regard to the burnt offering of appearance: “And none shall appear before Me empty” (Exodus 23:15). <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of the burnt offering of appearance, if one died after becoming obligated to bring the offering <b>the heirs are obligated</b> to bring his offering, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the redemption of the firstborn, if the obligation already took effect, and the son and the father then died, <b>the heirs are obligated</b> to give five <i>sela</i> coins to a priest.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The firstborn</b> son <b>takes a double</b> portion, i.e., twice the portion taken by the other sons, <b>when</b> inheriting <b>the property of the father, but he does not take twice</b> the portion <b>when</b> inheriting <b>the property of the mother. And neither does he take</b> twice the portion <b>in</b> any <b>enhancement</b> of the value of the property after the death of the father, <b>nor</b> does he take twice the portion <b>in</b> property <b>due</b> the father, <b>as</b> he does <b>in</b> property the father <b>possessed.</b>

Daf 52a

<b>And neither does a woman</b> take these portions, i.e., any enhancement of the value of the property or the property due the husband, from her husband’s property <b>for</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract</b> upon her divorce or her husband’s death; <b>nor</b> do <b>the daughters</b> take this share of the property <b>for their sustenance,</b> to which they are entitled from their late father’s possessions. <b>Nor</b> does <b>a man whose married brother died childless [<i>yavam</i>]</b> receive these portions, even though he acquires his brother’s portion of their shared father’s inheritance after performing levirate marriage with his brother’s wife. The mishna summarizes: <b>And all of them do not take</b> a portion <b>in</b> any <b>enhancement</b> of the value of the property after the death of the owner, <b>nor</b> do they take a portion <b>in</b> property <b>due</b> the deceased, <b>as</b> they do in property <b>in</b> his <b>possession.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the firstborn son does not receive a double portion when inheriting the property of his mother. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason?</b> The Gemara explains that <b>the verse states: “The law of primogeniture is his”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:17); this is understood to mean that there is <b>a law of primogeniture for a man,</b> i.e., a duty to bequeath a double portion to his firstborn son, <b>and there is no law of primogeniture for a woman.</b>
The mishna teaches further: <b>And neither does he take</b> twice the portion <b>in</b> any <b>enhancement</b> of the value of the property after the death of his father. The Gemara explains that this is <b>because it is written:</b> “A double portion <b>of all that he has”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:17), and this enhancement was not in his father’s possession at the time of his death. The mishna also teaches: <b>Nor</b> does he take twice the portion in property <b>due</b> the father, <b>as</b> he does in the property <b>in possession</b> of the father. The Gemara explains that this too is <b>because it is written: “Of all that he has”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:17), and property due the father is not in his possession.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And neither does a woman</b> take any enhancement of the value of the property or the property due the husband, from her husband’s property <b>for</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But doesn’t Shmuel say a creditor collects</b> the value of <b>the enhancement</b> of the field of a borrower after the latter’s death? Since a wife’s marriage contract is like a promissory note, she is considered a creditor. <b>Rabbi Abba says:</b> The Sages <b>taught here</b> one <b>of the leniencies</b> for the husband that apply to <b>a marriage contract:</b> That a woman does not collect the value of the enhancement despite the fact that she is a creditor.
The mishna teaches: <b>Nor</b> do <b>the daughters</b> take this share of the property <b>for their sustenance,</b> to which they are entitled from their late father’s possessions. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara explains that <b>a stipulation in the marriage contract,</b> such as that the daughters are entitled to sustenance from the father’s property after his death, <b>is comparable to the marriage contract</b> itself, and therefore they cannot claim that which cannot be claimed from a marriage contract, i.e., an enhancement to the father’s property.
The mishna teaches: <b>Nor</b> does <b>the <i>yavam</i></b> receive these portions. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara answers that <b>the Merciful One calls</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>a firstborn,</b> in the verse: “And it shall be, the firstborn” (Deuteronomy 25:6). <b>Abaye says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only with regard to an enhancement by</b> which <b>the property</b> was <b>enhanced between the death</b> of the brother <b>and the levirate marriage. But</b> concerning the enhancement <b>that</b> occurs <b>between the levirate marriage and the distribution</b> of the inheritance, <b>he does take</b> it. <b>What is the reason? The Merciful One states: “Shall succeed in the name of his brother who is dead”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:6), <b>and</b> by that stage <b>he has succeeded</b> him, and the enhancement occurred at that stage.
<b>Rava says: Even with regard to</b> the enhancement that occurs <b>between the levirate marriage and the distribution</b> of the inheritance, the <i>yavam</i> <b>does not take</b> it. <b>What is the reason?</b> He is compared <b>to a firstborn: Just as a firstborn does not have</b> any special right to the inheritance <b>before</b> its <b>distribution, so too, a <i>yavam</i> does not have</b> any right to the inheritance <b>before</b> its <b>distribution.</b>
The mishna teaches: <b>And all of them do not take</b> a portion <b>in</b> any <b>enhancement.</b>

Daf 52b

The Gemara explains that this <i>halakha</i> is repeated in order <b>to include an enhancement that</b> occurs <b>by itself</b> after the death of the father or husband, for instance in a case when <b>fodder [<i>ḥafura</i>],</b> i.e., produce that has grown stalks but is not yet ripe, <b>becomes full ears,</b> or when <b>date flowers [<i>shalpufei</i>] become</b> fully developed <b>dates.</b> Despite the fact that in such cases the property became enhanced by itself, without any effort on the part of the other brothers, the firstborn may not claim his double portion from that enhancement, and the same applies in the other cases mentioned in the mishna.
With regard to the repetition of the statement: <b>Nor</b> does he take twice the portion <b>in</b> property <b>due</b> the father <b>as</b> he does <b>in</b> property <b>in</b> his <b>possession,</b> this serves <b>to include property of the father’s father,</b> in a case where the father died before his own father. The firstborn does not receive his portion in such property, despite the fact that it will certainly come into the father’s possession, as this too is considered property that is due the father, not property in his possession. The same <i>halakha</i> applies also in the case of property due the wife, the daughters, or a <i>yavam</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these</b> are the people <b>whose</b> properties, unlike an ancestral field, <b>do not return</b> to their original owners <b>in the Jubilee</b> Year: The firstborn who inherited his father’s property by the right of <b>primogeniture</b> need not return the extra portion for redistribution among the brothers; <b>and one who inherits his wife’s</b> property need not return it to her family; <b>and one who consummates the levirate marriage with the wife of his brother</b> and gains the right to his brother’s property need not return it for redistribution among the brothers.
<b>And</b> likewise, <b>a gift</b> of land need not be returned to the original owners in the Jubilee Year; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> The halakhic status of <b>a gift</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a sale,</b> and it must be returned. <b>Rabbi Elazar says: All these</b> lands <b>return in the Jubilee</b> Year. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: Even one who inherits his wife’s</b> property <b>must return</b> the land <b>to the members of</b> her father’s <b>family and should deduct from them the monetary</b> value of the land, as the Gemara will explain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Meir,</b> who holds that none of these items return in the Jubilee Year? The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> with regard to land acquired specifically by means of <b>a sale that the Merciful One states</b> that it <b>should be returned during the Jubilee</b> Year (see Leviticus 25:28), whereas <b>a gift and an inheritance</b> are <b>not</b> returned. <b>And these</b> cases listed in the mishna that are derived <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>an inheritance</b> have the status of <b>an inheritance, and those</b> that are derived <b>from a gift</b> have the status of <b>a gift.</b> The Gemara elaborates: With regard to <b>a firstborn,</b> it is stated: <b>“By giving him a double portion”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:17); here <b>the Merciful One calls</b> the portion of a firstborn <b>a gift,</b> an item that is given.
<b>And one who inherits his wife’s</b> property need not return it to her family in the Jubilee Year, as Rabbi Meir maintains that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by Torah law,</b> not a rabbinic enactment, and land acquired through inheritance is not returned. <b>And</b> likewise, <b>one who consummates the levirate marriage with the wife of his brother</b> need not return the brother’s property for redistribution among the brothers. This is because <b>the Merciful One calls</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>a firstborn,</b> in the verse: “And it shall be, the firstborn” (Deuteronomy 25:6), and Rabbi Meir holds that the portion of the firstborn is not returned in the Jubilee Year, as explained earlier.
The mishna further teaches: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The halakhic status of <b>a gift</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a sale,</b> and must be returned. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of the Rabbis?</b> The Gemara answers that the term <b>“you shall return”</b> in the verse: “In the Jubilee Year you shall return every man to his possession” (Leviticus 25:13), is superfluous, as it is already stated: “It shall be a Jubilee for you, and you shall return every man to his possession” (Leviticus 25:10). Therefore, this term serves <b>to include a gift,</b> which is also returned in the Jubilee Year.
<b>And these</b> other cases listed in the mishna <b>are all</b> considered as <b>an inheritance,</b> and consequently they are not returned in the Jubilee Year. With regard to the husband’s inheritance of his wife’s property, the Rabbis, like Rabbi Meir, maintain that it applies by Torah law, and they agree that the <i>yavam</i> is considered like a firstborn with respect to his portion.
As for <b>a firstborn, the verse states: “By giving him a double portion”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:17), and the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Meir, who derives from this verse that the portion of the firstborn has the status of a gift. Rather, they maintain that the verse <b>juxtaposes the</b> extra <b>portion of the firstborn to the portion</b> he receives as <b>an ordinary</b> brother: <b>Just as the portion</b> of <b>an ordinary</b> brother is not redistributed among the brothers in the Jubilee Year, but rather is <b>an inheritance,</b> as it is stated: “On the day that he causes his sons to inherit” (Deuteronomy 21:16), <b>so too the portion of the firstborn</b> is <b>an inheritance,</b> and is not returned in the Jubilee Year.
The mishna further teaches that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: All these</b> lands <b>return in the Jubilee</b> Year. The Gemara explains that Rabbi Elazar <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that the term <b>“you shall return”</b> serves <b>to include a gift, and</b> he further maintains that <b>these</b> cases listed in the mishna <b>are all</b> considered <b>gifts.</b> The Gemara elaborates: With regard to <b>a firstborn</b> it is stated: <b>“By giving him a double portion.”</b> Through the use of the term “giving,” <b>the Merciful One calls</b> his portion <b>a gift.</b>
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>one who inherits his wife’s</b> property, Rabbi Elazar maintains that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by rabbinic law,</b> and therefore it does not have the status of an inheritance that does not return in the Jubilee Year. <b>And</b> finally, <b>one who consummates the levirate marriage with the wife of his brother</b> returns the property for redistribution among the brothers, as <b>the Merciful One calls</b> him <b>a firstborn,</b> and Rabbi Elazar rules that the portion of the firstborn is returned in the Jubilee Year.
§ <b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Brothers who divided</b> property received as an inheritance <b>are</b> considered <b>purchasers</b> from each other, i.e., one does not say they each received the exact inheritance to which they were entitled. <b>And</b> as purchasers of land, <b>they must return</b> the portions <b>to each other in the Jubilee</b> Year, at which point they redistribute the property. <b>Rav Hoshaya raises an objection</b> from the mishna: <b>And these</b> are the people <b>whose</b> properties <b>do not return</b> to their original owners <b>in the Jubilee</b> Year: The firstborn who inherited his father’s property by <b>the</b> right of <b>primogeniture.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar said to</b> Rav Hoshaya: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the clause: <b>They do not return?</b> It means that <b>they do not return for naught,</b> i.e., the firstborn does not forfeit the double portion; rather, when they redistribute the property he again receives a double portion. <b>Rav Sheshet objects to this: By inference</b> from this answer, should one conclude <b>that the one who says</b> the portion of the firstborn <b>returns</b> in the Jubilee Year <b>is saying</b> that <b>it returns for naught?</b> Why should the firstborn lose his double portion?
<b>Rav Ḥama read</b> the verse <b>about Rav Sheshet: “Wisdom is good with an inheritance”</b> (Ecclesiastes 7:11), i.e., it is not enough to inherit knowledge of <i>baraitot</i>, as does Rav Sheshet; rather, one must also be expert in the wisdom of <i>amora’im</i>. Rav Ḥama explained: <b>Didn’t</b> Rav Sheshet <b>hear this</b> matter, <b>that when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> says, <b>and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said</b> it <b>in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua,</b> who is the <i>tanna</i> Rabbi Elazar in the mishna: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the clause: <b>They return</b> in the Jubilee Year? It means that <b>they return for naught,</b> and they forfeit that which they received.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: Even one who inherits his wife’s</b> property <b>must return</b> the land <b>to the members of</b> her father’s family and should deduct from them the monetary value of the land. The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka <b>hold? If he holds</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by Torah law, why must he return</b> the property <b>to the members of</b> his wife’s <b>family?</b> An inheritance by Torah law is not given back in the Jubilee Year. <b>And if he holds</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by rabbinic law, what is the purpose of the money</b> he receives from his wife’s relatives? Since the property belongs to them, they should not have to pay him anything.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka <b>holds</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by Torah law, and what are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where his wife bequeathed to him</b> her family’s <b>graveyard. And due to</b> the need to avoid <b>a family flaw,</b> i.e., harm to the family name, if the wife’s family would be buried in plots belonging to others, <b>the Sages said he should take money</b> from them <b>and return</b> the graveyard.
<b>And</b> this is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> discussing <i>halakhot</i> connected with burial that serve to uphold family honor: In the case of <b>one who sells his grave, or the path</b> to <b>his grave,</b> or <b>the place</b> where visitors would <b>stand</b> to comfort the mourners, <b>or the place of his eulogies, the members of</b> his <b>family may come and bury him</b> in his ancestral plot <b>against</b> the purchaser’s <b>wishes, due to</b> the need to avoid <b>a family flaw,</b> i.e., harm to the family name. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the clause: <b>And deduct for them</b> part <b>of the monetary</b> value of the property? It means that he must deduct <b>the monetary</b> value <b>of his wife’s grave</b> from the value of the field, as a husband is obligated to pay for his wife’s burial (see <i>Ketubot</i> 47b).

Daf 53a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mitzva of <b>animal tithe is in effect</b> both <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>in the presence of,</b> i.e., in the time of, <b>the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple.</b> It is in effect <b>with regard to non-sacred</b> animals <b>but not with regard to sacrificial</b> animals. <b>And it is in effect with regard to the herd and the flock, but they are not tithed from one for the other;</b> and it is in effect <b>with regard to sheep and goats, and they are tithed from one for the other.</b>
And it is in effect <b>with regard to</b> animals from <b>the new</b> flock <b>and with regard to</b> animals from <b>the old</b> flock, <b>but they are not tithed from one for the other. As by right, it should be</b> inferred: <b>If</b> in the case of animals from the <b>new</b> flock <b>and the old</b> flock, <b>which do not</b> carry the prohibition of mating <b>diverse kinds</b> when mated <b>with each other</b> because they are one species, <b>are</b> nevertheless <b>not tithed from one for the other,</b> then with regard to <b>sheep and goats, which do</b> carry the prohibition of mating <b>diverse kinds</b> when mated <b>with each other, is it not right that they will not be tithed from one for the other?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And all the tithe of the herd <b>or the flock,</b> whatever passes under the rod, the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32), indicating that with regard to animal tithe, <b>all</b> animals that are included in the term <b>flock</b> are <b>one</b> species.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the mitzva of animal tithe is in effect both in Eretz Yisrael and outside of Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a person</b> must <b>bring up</b> his <b>animal tithe from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and sacrifice it</b> in the Temple. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And you shall bring there your burnt offerings, and your offerings, and your tithes,</b> and the offering of your hand, and your vows, and your gift offerings, and the firstborn of your herd and of your flock” (Deuteronomy 12:6).
Rabbi Akiva explains: The plural form “tithes” indicates that <b>the verse is speaking of two tithes; one</b> is the <b>animal tithe, and</b> the other <b>one</b> is the second <b>tithe of grain,</b> i.e., produce. Since these two tithes are included in the same word, it is derived from here that <b>from the place where you bring up</b> the <b>tithe of grain,</b> i.e., Eretz Yisrael, as the obligation to separate tithe of grain applies only there, <b>you</b> also <b>bring up</b> the <b>animal tithe; but from a place where you do not bring up</b> the <b>tithe of grain,</b> i.e., outside of Eretz Yisrael, <b>you do not bring up</b> the <b>animal tithe</b> either. This <i>baraita</i>, which states the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, apparently contradicts the ruling of the mishna.
The Gemara responds: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> and the mishna are referring to different cases. The <i>baraita</i> <b>there</b> is referring to the requirement to bring the animal tithe to Jerusalem for it <b>to be sacrificed</b> on the altar. By contrast, the mishna <b>here</b> is speaking of the status of every tenth animal; these animals are <b>to be</b> separated and <b>consecrated.</b> The Gemara adds that the language of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise,</b> as it <b>adduces a derivation</b> from the phrase <b>“and you shall bring there.” Conclude from</b> this citation that the <i>baraita</i> is referring specifically to the requirement to bring the animal tithe and sacrifice it in Jerusalem.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, since</b> animal tithe outside of Eretz Yisrael <b>is not sacrificed</b> on the altar, <b>why is it consecrated?</b> What is the significance of its sanctity? The Gemara answers that it is consecrated <b>to</b> the extent that it may <b>be eaten by its owner</b> only <b>when</b> it develops <b>a blemish.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that the animal tithe is in effect both <b>in the presence of the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> then <b>even nowadays</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the animal tithe should be in effect. Why then do people not remove every tenth animal from their flock or herd? The Gemara answers: The reason is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Huna, as Rav Huna says:</b> This is a rabbinic <b>decree due to an orphan,</b> i.e., a baby animal whose mother died before it was born, lest it be included with the other animals to be tithed; the obligation of animal tithe does not apply to it.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> then even <b>originally,</b> when the Temple stood, the practice should have <b>also</b> been <b>not</b> to separate animal tithe in case an orphaned animal was included in the counting. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that there was no concern for an orphaned animal when the Temple stood, as it was <b>possible</b> to remove this concern <b>by</b> issuing <b>an announcement</b> to everyone that an orphaned animal is exempt from animal tithe. The Gemara suggests: <b>Here too,</b> it is <b>possible</b> to remove the concern <b>by</b> means of <b>an announcement</b> that an orphaned animal is exempt from animal tithe.
<b>Rather, Rabba says:</b> The reason animal tithe is no longer separated is <b>due to</b> concern that <b>a mishap</b> might occur. <b>And from where do you say that we are concerned for a mishap</b> after the destruction of the Temple? <b>As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may neither consecrate</b> items, <b>nor valuate</b> an item’s worth based on its appraisal, <b>nor dedicate</b> items for sacred use (see Leviticus, chapter 27) and dedicate its monetary worth to the Temple treasury, <b>in the present</b> time, when the Temple is no longer standing.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And if one did consecrate, or valuate, or dedicate</b> items for sacred use, the presence of these items might lead to the mishap of the violation of the prohibition against using consecrated property. Therefore, if one dedicated <b>an animal it should be destroyed.</b> If he dedicated <b>produce, garments, or vessels</b> made from materials that decompose, he should store them until <b>they decompose.</b> And if he dedicated <b>money or metal vessels, he should take them</b> and cast them <b>into the Dead Sea.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> in the case of an animal, <b>what</b> constitutes <b>uprooting? He locks the door before it, and it dies on its own</b> from hunger. This <i>baraita</i> indicates that animals that cannot be sacrificed nowadays must be left to die so that they are not used improperly.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> then <b>a firstborn should also not be consecrated,</b> as this too could lead to a mishap. The Gemara responds: Does the <b>matter</b> of the consecration of <b>a firstborn depend on us?</b> The animal is automatically <b>consecrated upon</b> its exit from <b>the womb.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what the questioner <b>is saying: Let us sell the ears</b> of all firstborn animals <b>to gentiles</b> before their births, so <b>that they are not consecrated from the outset.</b> A firstborn animal that is jointly owned by a Jew and a gentile does not become consecrated as a firstborn.

Daf 53b

The Gemara explains that it is <b>possible</b> to act in a different manner, so that the priest does not lose out on his rights to the firstborn animal. One can act <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, as Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It is <b>permitted for a person to inflict a blemish upon a firstborn</b> animal fetus <b>before it emerges into the air of the world.</b> The Gemara challenges: If so, <b>here too, it is possible</b> for one <b>to inflict a blemish from the outset,</b> before the animal becomes consecrated as the tithed animal.
The Gemara answers: <b>How</b> can one <b>know which</b> animal will <b>emerge</b> as the tenth? Since it is impossible to know this, one cannot inflict a blemish on the animal before it becomes consecrated. <b>And if you would say that</b> one should <b>bring out</b> the animal upon which he has inflicted the blemish <b>at the head of</b> the <b>ten</b> animals to ensure that it will be the tithed animal, this is not a valid option, as <b>the Merciful One states: “He shall not inquire whether it be good or bad”</b> (Leviticus 27:33). This means one may not plan in advance which animal will be the tenth.
<b>And if you would say it is possible to inflict a blemish on the entire herd</b> of animals and thereby ensure the tenth one will be blemished, that is also undesirable. The reason is that <b>soon the Temple will be rebuilt and we</b> will <b>require animals for offerings, and</b> there will be <b>none</b> remaining without a blemish.
The Gemara asks: But <b>here too, with regard to a firstborn animal,</b> why not also say that <b>soon the Temple will be rebuilt and we</b> will <b>require animals for offerings and</b> there will be <b>none</b> remaining without a blemish? The Gemara answers: It is <b>possible</b> to bring the offerings <b>from ordinary</b> animals that are not firstborns.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Here too,</b> with regard to the animal tithe, <b>it is possible</b> to bring the offerings <b>from</b> animals <b>purchased</b> from another person, which are exempt from animal tithe, as taught in the mishna on 55b. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> anyone who has animals <b>inflicts a blemish on all of</b> the animals in <b>his herd</b> to avoid consecrating the tithe, there will be very few unblemished animals available for purchase. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>blemishes that disqualify sacrificial</b> animals <b>are common, as even</b> if the blemish is small, e.g., <b>on the</b> animal’s <b>eyelid, it disqualifies</b> the animal from being used for sacrifice. Therefore, it will <b>not</b> be <b>common</b> to find animals fit to be used as offerings. For this reason the Sages decreed that one should not tithe his animals in the present time.
§ The mishna teaches that the mitzva of animal tithe is in effect <b>with regard to non-sacred</b> animals <b>but not with regard to sacrificial</b> animals. The Gemara raises a difficulty: It is <b>obvious</b> that the mitzva to tithe is not in effect with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals, as <b>they are not his.</b> Since sacrificial animals have been dedicated to the Temple, of course the owner cannot subsequently consecrate them.
The Gemara answers: The mishna is referring <b>to offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> e.g., peace offerings, <b>and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says: Offerings of lesser sanctity are the monetary property of their owners,</b> and therefore the owner can consecrate them. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the guilt offering of a robber who takes a false oath, that the verse: <b>“And he commits a trespass against the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 5:21), serves <b>to include</b> one who takes a false oath with regard to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity</b> belonging to another, <b>which are the property of their owners.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b> Accordingly, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that such animals <b>should be tithed.</b> Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the mitzva of animal tithe is not in effect with regard to sacrificial animals at all.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> one can <b>say it is indeed so,</b> i.e., perhaps offerings of lesser sanctity can indeed be tithed. The Gemara responds that <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “And all the tithe of the herd or the flock, whatever passes under the rod, the tenth <b>shall be sacred</b> to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). This teaches that this mitzva applies only to an animal that can become sacred in the future <b>but not</b> to an animal <b>that is already sanctified,</b> e.g., that has been set aside as an offering of lesser sanctity.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>The reason</b> that offerings of lesser sanctity cannot be tithed is <b>that the Merciful One writes:</b> “The tenth <b>shall be sacred</b> to the Lord,” from which it can be inferred that <b>were that not</b> the case, <b>I would say</b> that <b>the sanctity of</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> does <b>take effect on</b> the animal. This claim is difficult, as <b>now</b> that consecration of <b>stringent sanctity does not take effect with regard to</b> offerings of <b>lesser sanctity,</b> as will be explained, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to teach that a consecration of <b>lesser sanctity does not take effect with regard to</b> offerings of <b>lesser sanctity?</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is this</b> <i>halakha</i> that consecration of stringent sanctity does not take effect with regard to offerings of lesser sanctity? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Temura</i> 32a): <b>Both</b> concerning animals <b>consecrated for the altar and</b> items <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance, one cannot alter their</b> designation <b>from</b> one form of <b>sanctity to</b> another form of <b>sanctity. But one can consecrate</b> an animal already consecrated for the altar by <b>consecration of its value,</b> and that value is donated to the Temple treasury for maintenance, in addition to the sacrificing of the animal. <b>And one can dedicate</b> that value for the purpose of giving it to the priests. This mishna teaches that one may not consecrate an animal that has already been consecrated for Temple maintenance as an offering for the altar, despite the fact that an offering has more stringent sanctity, and if so, then the sanctity of the animal tithe certainly does not take effect with regard to offerings of lesser sanctity.
The Gemara answers: Even so, it is necessary for the mishna to teach that tithes do not take effect on offerings of lesser sanctity, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>there,</b> in the mishna in <i>Temura</i>, the reason is <b>that not every animal stands to</b> potentially become <b>a burnt offering,</b> i.e., an offering of more stringent sanctity, from the time it is born. For this reason the greater sanctity cannot take effect once the animal has been consecrated as an offering of lesser sanctity. <b>But</b> in the mishna <b>here, where every animal stands to</b> potentially become an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, one might have thought that <b>even though it is consecrated</b> as an offering of lesser sanctity, nevertheless the initial potential <b>prohibition,</b> i.e., status, <b>of</b> animal <b>tithe is not abrogated from it.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What difference is</b> there if an animal that has been consecrated as a peace offering is also sanctified as an animal tithe offering? The Gemara explains that if it is sanctified as an animal tithe offering, the prohibition <b>of: “It shall not be redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:33), <b>and</b> the prohibition <b>of: It shall not be sold</b> (see 32b), take effect. A peace offering can be redeemed, whereas it is prohibited to redeem or sell animal tithe even after its slaughter. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the sanctity of animal tithe does not take effect on animals that have been consecrated as offerings of lesser sanctity.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> the animal tithe <b>is in effect with regard to the herd and the flock, but they are not tithed from one for the other;</b> and it is in effect <b>with regard to sheep and goats,</b> and they are tithed from one for the other. In this regard the Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Let</b> it be proven that the animals from <b>the new</b> flock and the animals from <b>the old</b> flock <b>can be tithed from one for the other, by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And if sheep and goats, which are</b> prohibited for interbreeding <b>with each other</b> due to the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds, are</b> nevertheless <b>tithed from one for the other,</b> with regard to animals from the <b>new</b> flock <b>and</b> the <b>old</b> flock, <b>which are not</b> prohibited for interbreeding <b>with each other</b> as <b>diverse kinds, is it not logical that they should be tithed from one for the other?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall tithe a tithe</b> from all the increase of your seed that the field brings forth year by year. And you shall eat before the Lord your God, in the place that He shall choose to place His name there, the tithe of your grain, of your wine, and of your oil, and the firstborn of your herds and of your flocks; that you may learn to fear the Lord your God always” (Deuteronomy 14:22–23). Here, <b>the verse is speaking of two tithes; one</b> is <b>the animal tithe and</b> the other <b>one</b> is <b>the grain tithe. And</b> the verse <b>juxtaposes</b> the <b>animal tithe to</b> the <b>grain tithe,</b> teaching that <b>just as</b> the <b>grain tithe</b> is <b>not</b> taken <b>from the new</b> grain <b>for the old</b> grain, <b>so too,</b> the <b>animal tithe</b> is <b>not</b> taken <b>from the new</b> flock <b>for the old</b> flock.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, let us say</b> with regard to <b>sheep and goats</b> that they <b>too</b> are not tithed for each other, by the same reasoning, i.e., that the verse <b>juxtaposes</b> the <b>animal tithe to</b> the <b>grain tithe: Just as grain tithe</b> is <b>not</b> separated <b>from</b> one <b>type</b> of grain <b>for</b> another grain <b>that is not its type, so too, animal tithe</b> is <b>not</b> separated <b>from</b> one <b>type</b> of animal <b>for</b> another species of animal <b>that is not its type.</b> The Gemara answers that with regard to animal tithe <b>the Merciful One has amplified</b> the <i>halakha</i> by stating <b>“flock”</b> (Leviticus 27:32). This teaches that all species referred to with the term flock, i.e., sheep and goats, are tithed together.
The Gemara suggests: <b>If so,</b> let us <b>also</b> say that <b>new</b> flocks are tithed together with <b>old</b> flocks, based on that amplification of the verse. The Gemara answers that <b>it is written: “You shall tithe a tithe”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:22), to teach that old and new flocks are not tithed together. The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you to use the juxtaposition to prohibit tithing old and new flocks together but not to prohibit tithing sheep and goats together? <b>Rava said the verse states: “Year by year”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:22), which teaches that <b>I have juxtaposed</b> the flocks <b>with regard to the year</b> in which they were born, i.e., to prohibit tithing old and new flocks together, <b>but not with regard to another matter.</b>
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Terumot</i> 2:4): <b>One may not separate the portion of the produce designated for the priest [<i>teruma</i>] from</b> one <b>type</b> of produce <b>to</b> exempt another type of produce <b>that is not its type, and if one did separate <i>teruma</i></b> in that manner, <b>his <i>teruma</i> is not <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Ami says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai says, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says,</b> that the verse states with regard to <i>teruma</i>: <b>“All the best of the oil, and all the best of the wine, and of the grain,</b> the first part of them, which they give to the Lord, to you have I given them” (Numbers 18:12). <b>The Torah says: Give the best,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> and tithes, <b>of this,</b> the oil, <b>and the best of that,</b> the wine, separately, i.e., one may not give <i>teruma</i> or tithes from one for the other. This mitzva also applies to tithes, as it too is called: “The best” (Numbers 18:30).

Daf 54a

The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that one may not separate <i>teruma</i> from <b>wine and oil</b> together; <b>from where</b> is it derived that one may not separate <i>teruma</i> from <b>wine and grain</b> together, or from <b>grain</b> of one kind <b>and grain</b> of a different kind together? The Gemara answers that this can be derived by <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And if wine and oil, which are not</b> prohibited due to the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds</b> if they are planted <b>with each other,</b> nevertheless <b>may not be tithed from one for the other,</b> then with regard to <b>wine and grain</b> or <b>grain and grain, which are</b> subject to the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds</b> when planted <b>with each other, is it not logical that they may not be tithed from one for the other?</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> this derivation is problematic <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoshiya, who says</b> that the verse: “You shall not sow your vineyard with diverse kinds” (Deuteronomy 22:9), means that one who sows diverse kinds is not liable by Torah law <b>until he sows wheat and barley and</b> a grape <b>seed with a single hand motion.</b> According to this opinion, the above <i>a fortiori</i> inference is not valid; consequently, <b>how does he derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> that one may not tithe grain for wine or grain for grain?
The Gemara answers that <b>he derives it in this manner: And if wine and oil, which are not</b> prohibited as <b>diverse kinds with each other even by means of something else,</b> i.e., even if one planted a different kind of grain seed with them, do not become prohibited, and yet <b>they may not be tithed from one for the other,</b> then with regard to <b>wine and grain</b> or <b>grain and grain, which are</b> prohibited as <b>diverse kinds with something else,</b> i.e., if they are planted with another type of seed, <b>is it not logical that they may not be tithed from one for the other?</b>
The Gemara asks: It can be derived in this manner that one may not separate <i>teruma</i> or tithes from wine for grain or vice versa; <b>but from where do we</b> derive the prohibition against separating <i>teruma</i> or tithes from <b>two species in general</b> that are not grain, e.g., lentils and beans, one for the other? The Gemara answers that the obligation to separate tithes from <b>these</b> other species, which are not mentioned in the Torah, applies <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>and</b> concerning <b>all</b> ordinances <b>that the Sages instituted, they instituted</b> them <b>parallel to Torah law.</b> Therefore, <b>just as by Torah law two species may not be tithed from one for the other,</b> so <b>too,</b> those mixtures that are prohibited <b>by rabbinic law</b> may not be tithed one for another.
<b>Rava bar Rav Ḥanan said to Abaye: If that is so,</b> then <b>with regard to animal tithe, where it is not written</b> in the Torah: <b>And all the tithe of the herd or the tithe of the flock,</b> with the word “tithe” mentioned twice, once in reference to the herd and once in reference to the flock, but rather the verse states: “And all the tithe of the herd or the flock, whatever passes under the rod, the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32),

Daf 54b

<b>let them be tithed from one for the other.</b> Abaye <b>said to him</b> that <b>the verse states: “The tenth</b> shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). This indicates that one must <b>give the tenth</b> animal <b>from this,</b> the flock, <b>and give the tenth</b> animal <b>from that,</b> the herd, with each counted and given separately. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, sheep and goats</b> should <b>also</b> have to be tithed separately. The Gemara answers that the verse states: <b>“Or the flock,”</b> which <b>means</b> that <b>all</b> the goats and sheep <b>are one flock</b> and may be tithed together.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>Here too,</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i> and tithes, <b>let us say</b> that the term “grain” (Numbers 18:12) <b>means</b> that <b>all</b> the different types of grain are considered <b>one grain,</b> and may be tithed together. <b>Abaye said</b> in response that there it is different, as the verse states: <b>“The first part of them”</b> (Numbers 18:12), in the plural, which teaches that one must give the first part for each type of produce separately. <b>And Rabbi Ile’a says likewise</b> that <b>“the first part of them”</b> teaches that one must give the first part for each type of produce separately.
<b>Rava said</b> that there is an alternative answer: Even <b>without</b> the term <b>“the first part of them”</b> there is <b>also</b> no difficulty, as <b>you cannot say</b> the term “grain” <b>means</b> that <b>all</b> the different types of grain are considered <b>one grain.</b> Rava explains: <b>Granted, there,</b> with regard to sheep and goats, <b>we say</b> that the term <b>“or the flock” means</b> that <b>all</b> goats and sheep <b>are one flock. Because if it enters your mind</b> that <b>sheep and goats</b> may <b>also</b> not be tithed one for the other, like the herd and the flock, <b>let</b> the verse <b>write: And all the animal tithe,</b> without distinguishing between herds and flocks.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>if</b> the verse <b>had written: All the animal tithe, I would say</b> that the requirement to tithe animals applies <b>even to undomesticated animals,</b> this is not so. The reason is that one <b>derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the animal tithe <b>from sacrificial</b> animals, via a verbal analogy of the terms “under” and “under.” With regard to sacrificial animals it states: “When a bull, or a sheep, or a goat is brought forth, then it shall be seven days <b>under</b> its mother, but from the eighth day onward it may be accepted for an offering made by fire to the Lord” (Leviticus 22:27), and with regard to animal tithe it states: “And all the tithe of the herd or the flock, whatever passes <b>under</b> the rod, the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). It is derived through this verbal analogy that just as an undomesticated animal cannot be consecrated as an offering, so too, it cannot be tithed.
Rava continues his explanation: <b>And</b> as one would not have thought that undomesticated animals are included in the animal tithe the verse could have stated: And all the animal tithe, and one would <b>derive</b> that one species may not be tithed for another <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from new</b> grain <b>and old</b> grain, as specified earlier: If the grain tithe may not be taken from the new grain for the old grain despite the fact that the prohibition of diverse kinds does not apply, all the more so with regard to different species of animal, which are prohibited as diverse kinds; the animal tithe may not be taken from one for another. If so, <b>why do I</b> need the verse to state: <b>“The herds or the flock”?</b> This teaches that <b>herds</b> of cattle <b>and flocks</b> of sheep or goats <b>may not be tithed from one for the other, but sheep and goats,</b> which are both called flocks, <b>may be tithed</b> from one for the other.
Rava concludes: <b>But here,</b> in the case of grain, <b>would it suffice if</b> the Torah <b>had not written: “Grain,” to exclude other types</b> of foods from the obligation of tithes by Torah law? In other words, the term “grain” must be serving to exclude other types of food, as one cannot claim they could have been excluded in some other manner.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Naḥman, objects to this</b> claim of Rava in which it is derived from the words “herd” and “flock” that cattle and sheep may not be tithed together. One can <b>say</b> instead that this teaches <b>that</b> one should <b>intermingle the</b> cattle in the <b>herd with</b> the sheep in the <b>flock</b> and tithe them all together. <b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman, said to</b> Rav Huna, son of Rav Naḥman: <b>Rava also accepts</b> the opinion of Abaye that the verse <b>“The tenth</b> shall be sacred to the Lord” teaches that cattle and sheep must be tithed separately, and therefore he does not entertain that derivation.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rava said:</b> Even <b>without</b> the verse <b>“The tenth</b> shall be sacred to the Lord” <b>you also cannot say</b> that <b>a herd and a flock</b> should <b>be tithed from one for the other, as animal tithe is juxtaposed to grain tithe: Just as grain tithe</b> may <b>not</b> be separated <b>from</b> one <b>type</b> of grain <b>for</b> another grain <b>that is not its type, so too, animal tithe</b> may <b>not</b> be separated <b>from</b> one <b>type</b> of animal <b>for</b> another species of animal <b>that is not its type.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> it <b>Rava</b> himself <b>who said</b> that the term: <b>“Year</b> by year” (Deuteronomy 14:22), teaches that <b>I have juxtaposed</b> the two types of tithe <b>with regard to the year</b> in which they were born, teaching that one may not tithe old and new flocks together, <b>but not with regard to another matter,</b> i.e., there is no prohibition against tithing two types together? The Gemara answers: <b>Rava retracted that</b> first opinion, and maintains that the juxtaposition applies even to the tithing of two types together. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>one of</b> those opinions was <b>said</b> by <b>Rav Pappa,</b> not by Rava. Since Rav Pappa was Rava’s closest student and took over as head of the academy after Rava’s death, his statements were occasionally mistaken for those of Rava himself.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Animals subject to the obligation of <b>animal tithe join together</b> if the distance between them is no greater <b>than the distance that a grazing animal</b> can <b>walk</b> and still be tended by one shepherd. <b>And how much is the distance that a grazing animal walks?</b> It is <b>sixteen <i>mil</i>.</b> If the distance <b>between these</b> animals <b>and those</b> animals <b>was thirty-two <i>mil</i> they do not join together.</b> If <b>he</b> also <b>had</b> animals <b>in the middle</b> of that distance of thirty-two <i>mil</i>, <b>he brings</b> all three flocks to a pen <b>and tithes them in the middle. Rabbi Meir says: The Jordan</b> River <b>divides</b> between animals on two sides of the river <b>with regard to animal tithe,</b> even if the distance between them is minimal.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that animals join together for the purposes of tithing if the distance between them is no greater than the distance a grazing animal can walk and still be tended by one shepherd. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? What is the source that this is the maximum distance at which they can be tithed together?
<b>Rabba bar Sheila said that the verse states:</b> “So says the Lord of hosts: Yet again shall there be in this place, which is desolate, without man and without animal, and in all its cities, a habitation of shepherds causing their flocks to lie down. In the cities of the hill country, in the cities of the lowland, and in the cities of the south, and in the land of Benjamin, and in the places about Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, <b>the flock shall again pass under the hands of him who counts them,</b> says the Lord” (Jeremiah 33:12–13). It is derived from here that animals that can pass under the hands of one shepherd are called one flock and can be counted together for the animal tithe. <b>And the Sages have</b> an accepted <b>tradition that the eye of the shepherd can see</b> up to a distance of <b>sixteen <i>mil</i>.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that if the distance <b>between these</b> animals <b>and those</b> animals <b>was thirty-two <i>mil</i> they do not join together.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>It is</b> only if the distance between them is <b>thirty-two</b> <i>mil</i> <b>that they do not join together,</b> from which it can be inferred that if the distance between them is <b>less than this</b> they do <b>join together. But</b> the mishna earlier <b>teaches: Sixteen <i>mil</i>,</b> which indicates: <b>And no more.</b> The Gemara answers: One cannot infer that if the distance is less than thirty-two <i>mil</i> the animals join together. The mishna mentions thirty-two <i>mil</i> only <b>because it wants to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause:</b> If <b>he</b> also <b>had</b> animals <b>in the middle</b> of that distance of thirty-two <i>mil</i>, <b>he brings</b> them all to a pen <b>and tithes them in the middle.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And how many</b> animals must he have on the two sides and in the middle in order to tithe them as one group? <b>Rav says: Five from here and five from there and five in the middle.</b> The reason is <b>that these five</b> in the middle <b>are fit</b> to combine <b>with</b> the animals <b>here and are</b> likewise <b>fit</b> to combine <b>with</b> the animals <b>there,</b> to amount to a total of ten, to which the obligation of animal tithe applies. For this reason all three flocks are considered as one flock.
<b>And Shmuel says: Even</b> if there are <b>five from here and five from there and</b> only <b>one in the middle</b> they may be tithed together. The reason is that <b>we see the shepherd as one who stands here</b> in the middle <b>and we apply</b> the verse: <b>“Who counts them”</b> (Jeremiah 33:13), to him. Since he can see and count both sides from his vantage point in the middle, they are all considered one flock.

Daf 55a

The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one had five</b> sheep <b>in the village of</b> Ḥ<b>ananya and five</b> sheep <b>in the village of Otnai,</b> which is a distance of thirty-two <i>mil</i> from the village of Ḥananya, <b>they do not combine, unless he</b> also <b>has one</b> sheep between them, <b>in Tzippori.</b> This is apparently <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav</b> that there must be at least five sheep in the middle.
<b>Shmuel interpreted</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav.</b> The <i>baraita</i> does not mean he had five sheep on either side, but rather it is referring to a case <b>where he had nine</b> sheep <b>from here and nine</b> sheep <b>from there and one in the middle.</b> This case is different, <b>as that</b> one sheep in the middle <b>is fit</b> to combine <b>with</b> the animals <b>here and is fit</b> to combine <b>with</b> the animals <b>there,</b> to constitute a total of ten animals on either side, to which the obligation applies.
<b>Rav Pappa says: And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel</b> that one animal in the middle is sufficient to combine the two groups on either side of it, <b>even</b> if <b>the shepherd</b> himself is in the middle without any sheep, he <b>combines</b> the two flocks on either side. <b>And even</b> if only <b>the implements of the shepherd</b> are in the middle, they <b>combine</b> the two flocks on either side into one flock. Since the shepherd must go there to collect his implements it is considered as though he is already there and therefore the two flocks are combined.
<b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>the dog of the shepherd</b> is in the middle? Does it combine the two flocks into one or not? <b>Since</b> the shepherd can <b>call</b> the dog <b>and it comes,</b> perhaps it does <b>not combine</b> the two flocks, as the shepherd himself has no need to go to the middle, so the dog is not like the implements of the shepherd. <b>Or perhaps,</b> because <b>sometimes</b> the dog <b>does not come</b> when the shepherd calls it, <b>and</b> in such cases the shepherd <b>himself must go and bring it,</b> it does combine the two flocks. The Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Meir says: The Jordan</b> River <b>divides</b> between animals on two sides of the river with regard <b>to animal tithe,</b> even if the distance between them is minimal. <b>Rabbi Ami says: They taught</b> that the Jordan River serves as a partition <b>only when there is no bridge there, but</b> if <b>there is a bridge there, the bridge combines</b> the two flocks into one for the purposes of tithing.
The Gemara notes: <b>Apparently,</b> the Jordan River serves as a partition <b>because</b> the flock on one side <b>is not close</b> and is unable to join the flock on the other side due to the river between them. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one had</b> sheep <b>on both sides of the Jordan</b> River, <b>here and there; or</b> if the flocks were <b>in two counties [<i>avtilaot</i>], e.g., Namer and Namori,</b> even if they were under the control of the same ruler, the flocks <b>do not combine,</b> even if there is no river between them and they are less than thirty-two <i>mil</i> apart. <b>And needless to say,</b> if one flock is <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and</b> the other is inside <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael, they do not combine.
The Gemara clarifies its objection: <b>But</b> the partition between <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and</b> inside <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael is <b>like a place that has a bridge,</b> as the two areas are not necessarily separated by water. <b>And</b> yet the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that they <b>do not combine.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara retracts its previous explanation. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir: As the verse states: “And the Jordan was to be its border on the east side.</b> This was the inheritance of the children of Benjamin, by its borders round about, according to their families” (Joshua 18:20). Here, <b>the verse renders</b> the Jordan River as <b>a border in and of itself.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: But <b>if that is so,</b> should one say that the demarcation of the land allotted to each tribe has the status of a border? Consider the verse: <b>“And the border was drawn</b> and turned about on the west side southward, from the mountain that lies before Beit Horon southward; and its goings out were at Kiriath Ba’al, which is Kiriath Jearim, a city of the children of Judah; this was the west side” (Joshua 18:14). And consider the verse: <b>“And the border went up</b> to the side of Jericho on the north, and went up through the hill country westward; and its goings out were at the wilderness of Beit Aven” (Joshua 18:12). Here <b>also, the verse</b> apparently <b>renders</b> each of these places <b>a border by itself.</b> If so, flocks on either side should not combine for purposes of tithing.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with regard to the demarcation of each inheritance, it <b>is different, as the verse states:</b> “And the border shall go down to the Jordan, and its goings out shall be at the Dead Sea; <b>this shall be your land according to its borders round about”</b> (Numbers 34:12). This teaches that <b>all of Eretz Yisrael is</b> considered to be within <b>one border,</b> notwithstanding the demarcations of each inheritance within.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>If so, the Jordan</b> River <b>also</b> should not be considered a border with regard to animal tithes. The Gemara explains that the verse states: “This shall be your <b>land,”</b> which is referring to those parts of land that are connected, <b>but not</b> to areas separated by the <b>Jordan</b> River, which is not land but water.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba,</b> who maintains that the ruling of Rabbi Meir is a Torah edict, <b>this</b> is the reason <b>that the</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: The Jordan</b> River divides between animals on two sides of the river with regard to animal tithe. <b>But according to Rabbi Ami,</b> who holds that the Jordan River serves as a partition because the animals are unable to cross from one side to the other, <b>let</b> Rabbi Meir <b>teach</b> his principle <b>with regard to all rivers</b> that cannot be crossed. They should all divide flocks with regard to animal tithe. The Gemara comments: This is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the question of whether or not the Jordan River is part of Eretz Yisrael is <b>the subject of</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them: <b>When you pass over the Jordan into the land of Canaan”</b> (Numbers 35:10). The term <b>“into the land”</b> indicates that <b>the land of Canaan</b> is considered part of Eretz Yisrael, <b>but the Jordan</b> River itself <b>is not</b> considered part of <b>the land of Canaan;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says:</b> The verse <b>states</b> with regard to the portions of the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh: “The two tribes and the half tribe have received their inheritance <b>beyond the Jordan at Jericho eastward, toward the sunrise”</b> (Numbers 34:15). <b>Just as Jericho</b> is part of <b>the land of Canaan, so too, the Jordan</b> River is part of <b>the land of Canaan.</b>
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The river is called <b>Jordan only from Beit Jericho and below,</b> i.e., to the south. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this statement relevant? <b>If we say</b> it is relevant <b>for one who takes a vow,</b> e.g., that water from the Jordan River is forbidden to him, this cannot be so, as there is a principle with regard to vows that one must <b>follow</b> the ordinary <b>language of people.</b> The meaning of a vow is interpreted in accordance with the manner in which the words are used in common speech. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>anywhere that</b> most people <b>call</b> the river by the name <b>Jordan, it is prohibited for him</b> to drink from it, regardless of whether it is north or south of Beit Jericho. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement is relevant <b>for animal tithe.</b>
According to the opinion of Rabbi Meir the Jordan River acts as a partition only south of Beit Jericho, but north of that point it is not a partition. The Gemara notes: <b>That is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>Jordan</b> River <b>issues forth from the Cave of Pamyas and flows via the Sea of Sivkhi,</b> i.e., Lake Hula, <b>and via the Sea of Tiberias,</b> i.e., the Sea of Galilee, <b>and via the Sea of Sodom,</b> i.e., the Dead Sea, <b>and continues and falls</b> down <b>to the Great Sea. But it is</b> called <b>Jordan only from Beit Jericho and below,</b> i.e., to the south.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Why is</b> the river <b>called Jordan? Because it descends [<i>yored</i>] from</b> the city of <b>Dan. Rabbi Abba said to Rav Ashi: You learned</b> that the Jordan River emerges from the territory of Dan <b>from there,</b> i.e., from its name. <b>We learn it from here:</b> “And the border of the children of Dan went out from them; and the children of Dan went up and fought against Leshem, and took it, and smote it with the edge of the sword, and possessed it, and dwelt there, <b>and called Leshem: Dan, after the name of Dan their father”</b> (Joshua 19:47). <b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>this Leshem</b> is a city that was known in the talmudic period as <b>Pamyas. And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>the Jordan</b> River <b>emerges from the Cave of Pamyas.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana says: The source of the Jordan</b> River is <b>from the Cave of Pamyas.</b> Therefore, in a case <b>where</b> one <b>says: I will not drink water from the Cave of Pamyas, it is prohibited for him</b> to drink water <b>from the entire Jordan</b> River.
Rav Kahana also states: <b>The source of blood is the liver.</b> The halakhic ramification of this observation is <b>in accordance with</b> a statement <b>of Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzḥak says: A liver that dissolved,</b> i.e., a decomposed liver from a corpse, <b>imparts</b> ritual <b>impurity</b> if it has the volume <b>of a quarter-</b><i>log</i>, which is the minimum amount of blood that imparts ritual impurity.
Rav Kahana also states: <b>The source of</b> all <b>the water</b> in the world is the <b>Euphrates</b> River. The halakhic ramification of this is in accordance with a statement of Rav Yehuda, <b>as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>one who takes a vow</b> rendering <b>the waters of the Euphrates</b> River forbidden to him, <b>it is prohibited</b> for him to drink <b>from any water in the world.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> in which it is prohibited to drink from any water in the world? <b>If we say</b> this is a case <b>where he says: I will not drink from the water of the Euphrates</b> River, <b>it is</b> only <b>the waters of the Euphrates</b> River <b>that he may not drink,</b> whereas <b>he may drink</b> water <b>from another river,</b> since one follows the ordinary language of people.
<b>Rather,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where he says: I will not drink from</b> any <b>water that comes from the Euphrates</b> River. It is prohibited for him to drink any water at all, <b>as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: All the rivers are below,</b> i.e., they receive their waters <b>from, three rivers:</b> The Pishon, the Gihon, and the Tigris (see Genesis 2:11–14). <b>And</b> these <b>three rivers are below</b> and receive their waters <b>from the Euphrates</b> River. The Gemara asks: <b>But there are</b>

Daf 55b

<b>springs that are higher</b> in the mountains than the Euphrates; how can their water come from the Euphrates? <b>Rav Mesharshiyya said: These are ladders of the Euphrates,</b> i.e., the waters of the Euphrates seep through the ground and are drawn upward to emerge from these springs.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written:</b> “And a river went out of Eden to water the garden; and from there it was separated, and became four heads…And the name of the third river is Tigris; that is the one that goes toward the east of Ashur. <b>And the fourth river is the Euphrates”</b> (Genesis 2:10, 14)? This indicates that the Euphrates, which is mentioned last, is the least of the four rivers, not the source of the other three.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov</b> who said: <b>It is the Euphrates that</b> the verse mentions <b>initially</b> as the river that went out of Eden, which divided into all the other rivers. After the other three branched out from it, the Euphrates continued to flow.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir says: Yuval is the name of</b> the Euphrates River where it emerges from Eden, <b>as it is stated: “For he shall be as a tree planted by the waters, and that spreads out its roots by the river [<i>yuval</i>],</b> and shall not see when heat comes, but its foliage shall be luxuriant; and shall not be anxious in the year of drought, neither shall cease from yielding fruit” (Jeremiah 17:8). <b>And why is it named Euphrates [<i>perat</i>]? Because its waters are fruitful [<i>parim</i>] and multiply</b> without the need for rainfall.
The Gemara adds that this <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel says: The river is blessed from its riverbed;</b> the additional water in the river is not from rainfall but rather from subterranean sources. <b>And</b> this statement <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion <b>of Rav, as Rav Ami says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> When <b>rain</b> falls <b>in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>the great witness</b> attesting to that fact is <b>the Euphrates,</b> as the water flow in the Euphrates increases after the rainy season.
The Gemara relates that <b>Shmuel’s father fashioned a ritual bath for his daughters during the days of Nisan, and</b> placed <b>mats</b> in the Euphrates River <b>during the days of Tishrei</b> when his daughters immersed in the river. He fashioned <b>a ritual bath during the days of Nisan,</b> because <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, as Rav Ami says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> When <b>rain</b> falls <b>in the West, the great witness</b> attesting to that fact is <b>the Euphrates.</b> Shmuel’s father was concerned that <b>perhaps</b> the rainwater and snow water <b>that fell</b> and accumulated in the river <b>would exceed</b> the amount of naturally <b>flowing</b> spring water that originated in the river’s sources, <b>and the</b> flowing <b>rainwater would be the majority.</b> Rainwater purifies only when it is collected; it does not purify when it is flowing. Therefore, Shmuel’s father fashioned ritual baths of standing water for his daughters.
<b>And</b> he placed <b>mats during the days of Tishrei,</b> when his daughters immersed in the river itself, to give them privacy. During Tishrei the waters of the Euphrates do not come from rainwater; rather, the waters are from the river itself, and therefore immersion is valid even when that water is flowing.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> this statement <b>of</b> Shmuel’s, that the additional water in the Euphrates is not from rainfall but from subterranean sources, <b>disagrees</b> with another ruling that he <b>himself</b> issued. <b>As Shmuel says: Waters purify when flowing,</b> i.e., when they are not collected into a ritual bath, <b>only</b> in the <b>Euphrates during the days of Tishrei.</b> Since rain does not fall in the summer, only after the summer, in Tishrei, is it clear that the water one is immersing in is in fact river water.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who purchases</b> an animal <b>or</b> has an animal <b>that was given to him as a gift</b> is <b>exempt from</b> separating <b>animal tithe.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Rav Kahana says that the verse states:</b> “You shall not delay to offer of the fullness of your harvest, and of the outflow of your presses. <b>The firstborn of your sons you shall give to Me. So you shall do with your oxen, and with your sheep:</b> Seven days it shall be with its mother; on the eighth day you shall give it to Me” (Exodus 22:28–29).

Daf 56a

<b>Just as</b> the redemption of <b>your</b> firstborn <b>son</b> does <b>not</b> apply to a child who was <b>purchased or</b> received <b>as a gift,</b> i.e., the mitzva applies only to one’s own son, <b>so too,</b> the mitzva of separating tithe from <b>your flock and your herd</b> does <b>not</b> apply <b>to</b> animals that were <b>purchased or</b> received <b>as a gift.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But this</b> verse, which juxtaposes the firstborn son to an animal, <b>is written with regard to</b> redemption of <b>a firstborn,</b> not with regard to animal tithe. The Gemara explains that <b>the verse states: “So you shall do</b> with your oxen, and with your sheep: Seven days it shall be with its mother; on the eighth day you shall give it to Me” (Exodus 22:29). <b>If</b> this <b>is not</b> needed <b>for</b> the <b>matter of firstborn</b> animals, <b>which do not</b> require <b>any action</b> to sanctify them <b>as</b> the animal is already <b>consecrated when</b> it leaves <b>the womb, apply it to the matter of animal tithe,</b> where an animal is sanctified only when the owner counts it as the tenth animal.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> instead one can <b>say</b> to <b>apply</b> this phrase: “So you shall do,” to <b>the matter of a sin offering and a guilt offering</b> rather than animal tithe, i.e., one should derive that these offerings are sanctified only if they originally belonged to the individual who is attempting to sanctify them, not if they are purchased or received as a gift. The Gemara explains that one expounds the phrase as referring to animal tithe because that case is <b>similar to</b> the case of: <b>Your son. Just as your son does not come</b> to be redeemed to atone <b>for a sin, so too,</b> the phrase: <b>Your sheep and your oxen,</b> discussed in the verse, is referring to animal tithe, <b>which does not come</b> to the Temple to atone <b>for a sin.</b> Sin offerings and guilt offerings are brought only if one commits a sin.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> instead one can <b>say</b> to <b>apply</b> this phrase to <b>the matter of a burnt offering and a peace offering,</b> which can be brought even if one has not sinned, like the animal tithe. The Gemara explains that one expounds the phrase as referring to animal tithe because that case is <b>similar to</b> the case of: <b>Your son. Just as your son cannot come</b> in the form <b>of a vow or a gift, so too,</b> the phrase: <b>Your sheep and your oxen,</b> discussed in the verse, is referring to animal tithe, which cannot be brought as a vow or as a gift. It is not referring to a burnt offering or a peace offering, both of which can be brought as a vow or as a gift.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> instead that one should <b>apply</b> this phrase to <b>the matter of a burnt offering of appearance,</b> which one brings when he ascends to Jerusalem on one of the three pilgrimage Festivals. This offering is not brought for a sin, nor as a vow or a gift, as it is obligatory. The Gemara explains that one expounds the phrase as referring to animal tithe because that case is <b>similar to</b> the case of: <b>Your son. Just as your son does not have a fixed time</b> of year to be redeemed, but is redeemed after the thirtieth day from his birth, <b>so too: Your oxen and your sheep,</b> discussed in the verse, is referring to animal tithe, <b>which does not have a fixed time</b> to be brought. By contrast, the burnt offering of appearance is brought only on the three pilgrimage Festivals.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the tithing of a purchased animal is derived from the juxtaposition to the mitzva of redemption of a firstborn son, then all the <i>halakhot</i> of one should apply to the other: <b>Just as your</b> firstborn <b>son cannot be purchased at all,</b> under any circumstances, <b>so too, your oxen and your sheep</b> should <b>not be</b> subject to animal tithe if they are <b>purchased at all.</b> If so, <b>why</b> does <b>Rabbi Asi say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>purchased ten</b> animal <b>fetuses</b> while they were still <b>in their mothers’ wombs</b> and the animals were born once he already owned them, <b>they all enter the pen to be tithed?</b> If the <i>halakha</i> is derived from a firstborn son, there should be no concept of tithe in the case of purchased animals.
<b>Rava said</b> in response that <b>the verse states:</b> “So <b>you shall do</b> with your oxen, and with your sheep: Seven days it shall be with its mother; on the eighth day you shall give it to Me.” <b>The verse excludes</b> purchased animals from animal tithe only <b>at the time of doing,</b> i.e., from the time the animals are fit to be sacrificed in the Temple, not while they are still in their mothers’ wombs, as at that time they are as yet unfit to be sacrificed on the altar.
The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself,</b> to cite the relevant discussion in full. <b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>purchased ten</b> animal <b>fetuses</b> while they were still <b>in their mothers’ wombs</b> and the animals were born once he already owned them, <b>they all enter the pen to be tithed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>One who purchases</b> an animal <b>or</b> has an animal <b>that was given to him as a gift</b> is <b>exempt from animal tithe?</b> If so, why isn’t the owner of these fetuses also exempt from animal tithe?
<b>Rabbi Elazar said: I saw Rabbi Yoḥanan in a dream,</b> which is a sign that <b>I am saying a proper matter</b> in explaining his opinion. <b>The verse states:</b> “So <b>you shall do”</b> (Exodus 22:29); <b>the verse excludes</b> purchased animals from animal tithe only <b>at the time of doing,</b> i.e., from the time the animals are fit to be sacrificed in the Temple. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elyakim raised an objection to Rabbi Elazar</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The exemption of <b>a purchased</b> animal <b>applies</b> even <b>to</b> an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, i.e., before it is eight days old and fit to be sacrificed in the Temple. By the same token, the exemption should also apply to a fetus, despite the fact that it is not yet fit to be sacrificed.
