Rabbi Elazar <b>said to</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elyakim: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is not a tannaitic source</b> that can be relied upon, as it is not accurate. <b>And if you say</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>is a tannaitic source</b> that can be relied upon, <b>it is</b> only in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda in the name of Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> that an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived also <b>enters the pen to be tithed, and</b> in this regard it is <b>like a firstborn</b> animal. <b>Just as a firstborn</b> animal <b>is sanctified before its time</b> arrives to be sacrificed, <b>but is sacrificed after its time,</b> i.e., after it is at least eight days old, <b>so too,</b> an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived enters the pen to be tithed, and if it comes out as the tenth animal, it <b>is sanctified before its time</b> for sacrifice has arrived <b>but is sacrificed</b> only <b>after its time,</b> i.e., after it is at least eight days old.
<b>A <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>in the presence of Rav: Which</b> is the type of animal set aside as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute, about which the Sages said (see 57a) <b>that it enters the pen to be tithed? Any</b> animal <b>that he gave to her</b> as payment <b>and subsequently purchased</b> back <b>from her.</b> The <i>tanna</i> asked: <b>But doesn’t it</b> become <b>disqualified</b> from the status of animal tithe <b>as a purchased</b> animal, as he purchased it back from the prostitute?
The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> statement <b>escaped</b> that <i>tanna</i>: <b>As Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>purchased ten</b> animal <b>fetuses</b> while they were still <b>in their mothers’ wombs they all enter the pen to be tithed.</b> Accordingly, the <i>baraita</i> can be understood as referring to an animal that was given to a prostitute as payment and purchased back from her while it was still inside its mother’s womb.

Daf 56b

The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if that is the meaning of the <i>baraita</i>, why is it necessary to purchase the animal back from the prostitute for it to be subject to animal tithe? <b>Let her tithe it</b> herself, as it is not prohibited as payment to a prostitute, since it was in the womb when he gave it to her. The Gemara answers that the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a gentile prostitute,</b> to whom the mitzva of tithing animals does not apply.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>establish</b> this case, of an animal set aside as payment to a prostitute that nevertheless enters the pen to be tithed, as a case <b>involving a Jewish prostitute, and let</b> it be referring to a case where <b>she tithes it</b> herself. The Gemara explains that this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that</b> an animal given as payment to <b>a Jewish prostitute does not</b> have the halakhic status of <b>payment</b> to a prostitute, and is not prohibited for sacrifice.
The Gemara adds that this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Abaye, as Abaye says:</b> An animal given to <b>a gentile prostitute</b> is considered to be <b>payment</b> to a prostitute, which is <b>prohibited</b> for sacrifice on the altar. <b>And a priest who engages in intercourse with</b> a gentile prostitute <b>is not flogged due to</b> the prohibition of: “A widow, or one divorced, or a profaned woman, or a prostitute, these shall he not take, but a virgin of his own people shall he take to wife. <b>And he shall not profane his seed</b> among his people, for I am the Lord who sanctifies him” (Leviticus 21:14–15). Conversely, an animal given to <b>a Jewish prostitute</b> is not considered <b>payment</b> to a prostitute and it is <b>permitted</b> to sacrifice it. <b>But a priest who engages in intercourse with</b> a Jewish prostitute <b>is flogged due to</b> the prohibition of: <b>“And he shall not profane his seed</b> among his people, for I am the Lord who sanctifies him.”
The Gemara clarifies Abaye’s opinion. An animal given to <b>a gentile prostitute</b> is considered <b>payment</b> to a prostitute, which is <b>prohibited</b> for sacrifice on the altar, as Abaye <b>derives</b> a verbal analogy from the word <b>“abomination”</b> stated with regard to payment to a prostitute: “You shall not bring the payment of a prostitute, or the price of a dog, into the House of the Lord your God for any vow, for both of these are an abomination to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 23:19), and the word <b>“abomination”</b> stated <b>in</b> the verses discussing <b>those with whom relations are forbidden:</b> “For whosoever shall do any of these abominations, the souls that do them shall be cut off from among their people” (Leviticus 18:29).
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Just as</b> the verses discussing <b>those with whom relations are forbidden</b> are referring specifically to those women <b>upon</b> whom <b>betrothal does not take effect, so too,</b> the <b>prostitute</b> referred to in the verse <b>is one upon</b> whom <b>betrothal does not take effect,</b> i.e., a gentile prostitute.
Abaye further stated: <b>And a priest who engages in intercourse with her is not flogged due to</b> the prohibition of: <b>“And he shall not profane his seed</b> among his people, for I am the Lord who sanctifies him.” The Gemara explains: The reason is that <b>the Merciful One states that he should not profane his seed,</b> i.e., his children, <b>and</b> any children born from <b>this</b> gentile prostitute <b>are not</b> considered to be <b>his seed,</b> as the children of a gentile mother are gentiles.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>brothers and partners,</b> i.e., brothers who are partners in the inheritance of their father, <b>when they are obligated to</b> add <b>the premium [<i>bakalbon</i>]</b> to their annual half-shekel payment to the Temple <b>they are exempt from animal tithe.</b> Conversely, those whose halakhic status is like that of sons who are supported by their father and <b>are obligated to</b> separate <b>animal tithe are exempt from</b> adding <b>the premium.</b>
The mishna clarifies: If the brothers <b>acquired</b> the animals through inheritance <b>from</b> the property in <b>the possession of</b> their father’s <b>house they are obligated</b> in animal tithe; <b>but if not, they are exempt.</b> How so? If <b>they divided</b> the inheritance between them <b>and then reentered a partnership, they are obligated to</b> add <b>the premium and are exempt from animal tithe.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “That you shall set apart for the Lord all that opens the womb; every firstborn male that emerges from an animal that <b>shall be yours</b> belongs to the Lord” (Exodus 13:12). This teaches that the obligation of animal tithe applies only to an animal that belongs to you, i.e., to one owner, <b>but not</b> to an animal owned <b>by partners.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that the obligation of the tithe does not apply to the animal <b>even if</b> brothers <b>acquired</b> the animals through inheritance <b>from</b> the property in <b>the possession of</b> their father’s <b>house.</b> Therefore, the <b>verse states: “Shall be,”</b> to include animals acquired through inheritance in the obligation of animal tithe.
The Gemara asks: <b>But this</b> verse is not referring to animal tithe; rather, it is <b>written with regard to firstborn</b> animals. The Gemara answers: <b>If it is not</b> needed <b>for the matter of firstborn</b> animals, <b>as</b> the mitzva of sanctifying a firstborn animal <b>does</b> apply <b>in</b> a case of <b>partnership, as it is written,</b> in the plural form: “And you shall bring there your burnt offerings, and your offerings, and your tithes, and the offering of your hand, and your vows, and your gift offerings, <b>and the firstborn of your herd and of your flock”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:6), <b>apply</b> the verse <b>to the matter of animal tithe,</b> teaching that it does not apply to an animal owned by partners.
§ The mishna teaches: If the brothers divided the inheritance between them and then reentered a partnership, they are obligated to add the premium and are exempt from animal tithe. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> There are <b>times when they are obligated</b> both <b>in this,</b> the premium, <b>and in that,</b> animal tithe. <b>And</b> there are <b>times when they are exempt</b> both <b>from this and from that.</b> Furthermore, there are <b>times when they are obligated to</b> add <b>the premium and are exempt from animal tithe; and</b> finally, there are <b>times when they are obligated in animal tithe and are exempt from</b> having to add <b>the premium.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: The guiding principle is that partners are exempt from animal tithe but obligated to pay the premium, whereas in the case of individual ownership one is obligated in the animal tithe but exempt from paying the premium. Therefore, the case where <b>they are obligated</b> both <b>in this,</b> the premium, <b>and in that,</b> animal tithe, is <b>when they divided the money</b> they inherited from their father <b>but did not divide the animals</b> they inherited. The case where <b>they are exempt</b> both <b>from this and from that</b> is <b>when they divided the animals but did not divide the money.</b>
The case where <b>they are obligated to</b> pay <b>the premium and are exempt from animal tithe</b> is <b>when they divided</b> up both <b>this and that,</b> the money and the animals, from the estate of their deceased father. Afterward they reestablished a partnership and are therefore partners in the normal sense, rather than co-owners of the original inherited estate, and partners are obligated to pay the premium and are exempt from the animal tithe.
Finally, the case where <b>they are obligated in the animal tithe and are exempt from</b> paying <b>the premium</b> involves brothers <b>who have not divided this or that,</b> the money and the animals of their father’s estate, between them at all. It is therefore considered as though their father is still the sole owner of the estate and is contributing the shekel for the pair of them. Since the estate is under individual ownership, the animal tithe must be separated from the livestock.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious?</b> What is the novelty of Rabbi Yirmeya’s statement? The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary for</b> Rabbi Yirmeya to teach the case where <b>they divided the animals but did not divide the money.</b> It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since they divided the animals they</b> have thereby <b>revealed their intent</b> to divide the entire estate. Consequently, the estate <b>stands to be divided, and they should be obligated</b> to pay <b>the premium.</b> Therefore, Rabbi Yirmeya <b>teaches us</b> that they are exempt from paying the premium until they have actually divided the money.
§ <b>Rav Anan says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where they divided kids for goats and goats for kids,</b> i.e., when the two brothers inherited both kids and goats, but one took all the goats and the other all the kids. Since each originally inherited both goats and kids, this division is tantamount to one brother trading his goats for the other’s kids. When they again become partners, they are considered like strangers who join together. Consequently, they are exempt from the animal tithe.
<b>But</b> if <b>they divided kids for kids and goats for goats,</b> so that each takes some of both types, in the normal manner, one can <b>say</b> that <b>this,</b> i.e., the group of animals that each brother takes, <b>is</b> considered <b>his share to which he is entitled from the outset,</b> and no transaction between them has occurred. Consequently, when they reestablish the partnership the estate reverts to its original status as a single entity, and they are therefore obligated to separate animal tithe.
<b>And Rav Naḥman says: Even</b> if <b>they divided</b> the estate in the manner of <b>kids for kids and goats for goats, we do not say</b> that <b>this,</b> the group of animals taken by each brother, <b>is</b> considered <b>his share to which he is entitled from the outset.</b> Therefore, if they reestablish a partnership they are considered like partners and are exempt from separating animal tithe.
The Gemara notes that this matter is also the subject of a dispute between other <i>amora’im</i>. <b>And Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only when they divided nine</b> large goats <b>for ten</b> kids, <b>and ten</b> kids <b>for nine</b> large ones. Since the nine large goats are worth the same as ten kids, this division is tantamount to one brother trading his large goats for the other’s kids. When they again become partners they are considered as strangers who join together, and therefore they are exempt from the animal tithe.
<b>But</b> if <b>they divided nine</b> large goats <b>for nine</b> large goats <b>and ten</b> kids <b>for ten</b> kids, so that each takes some of both types, one can <b>say</b> that <b>this,</b> the group of animals taken by each brother, <b>is</b> considered <b>his share to which he is entitled from the outset,</b> and no transaction between them has occurred. Consequently, when they reestablish the partnership the estate reverts to its original status as a single entity, which means they are obligated to separate animal tithe.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even</b> if <b>they divided</b> the estate in the manner of <b>nine</b> large goats <b>for nine</b> large goats <b>and ten</b> kids <b>for ten</b> kids, one does <b>not say</b> that <b>this,</b> the group of animals taken by each brother, <b>is</b> considered <b>his share to which he is entitled from the outset.</b> Therefore, if they reestablish a partnership they are considered as partners and are exempt from separating animal tithe.

Daf 57a

<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> established line of <b>reasoning</b> in this regard. <b>As Rav Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Brothers who divided</b> real estate received as an inheritance <b>are</b> considered <b>purchasers</b> who have purchased from each other, <b>and</b> as purchasers of land <b>they must return</b> the portions <b>to each other in the Jubilee</b> Year, at which point they may redistribute the property. This demonstrates that Rabbi Yoḥanan does not hold that it is retroactively established that each brother’s portion was designated for him upon their father’s death. Rather, it is considered as though all the land was joint property until the brothers traded or bought their respective portions from each other.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> both statements of Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>are necessary. As, if he had taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> to <b>us</b> only <b>here,</b> with regard to animal tithe, one might have thought that it is <b>in this</b> case that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> each one has not received his own portion. This is because the case must be <b>similar to</b> the case of <b>your</b> firstborn <b>son,</b> in accordance with the juxtaposition between the two cases. <b>Just as your</b> firstborn <b>son</b> is redeemed only if it <b>is clear to you</b> that he is your son, not if he is purchased from another, <b>so too, your cattle and your sheep</b> are subject to animal tithe only if it <b>is clear to you,</b> i.e., if there is no aspect of acquisition at all. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>a field,</b> one might think <b>it is</b> only with regard to a field that is <b>sold that the Merciful One states</b> that the purchaser <b>should return it in the Jubilee</b> Year, whereas a field that <b>is an inheritance or a gift</b> need <b>not</b> be returned.
<b>And if</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>had taught us</b> only the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a field</b> inherited by two brothers must be returned in the Jubilee Year, one might have thought that Rabbi Yoḥanan was uncertain and therefore ruled <b>to be stringent.</b> If so, he would rule stringently with regard to animal tithe as well, deeming the brothers liable. <b>Alternatively,</b> one might think Rabbi Yoḥanan rules in this manner with regard to returning fields in the Jubilee Year only because the field must return to how it was <b>in the beginning. But here,</b> in the case of animal tithe, where there is no requirement to return matters to their initial state, one might <b>say</b> that the brothers are <b>not</b> considered to be purchasers, but rather each received the animals that were retroactively designated for him and they are therefore obligated in animal tithe. For this reason it <b>is necessary</b> for Rabbi Yoḥanan to teach both cases.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> against the opinion that there is retroactive designation of the animals: <b>And similarly</b> in the case of two <b>partners who divided</b> their common property, and <b>one took ten</b> lambs <b>and</b> the other <b>one took nine</b> lambs <b>and a dog,</b> sacrificing any of the ten lambs taken <b>in exchange for the dog is prohibited.</b> This is because they are considered “the price of a dog,” as it states in the Torah (Deuteronomy 23:19), since they were given in exchange for it. Nevertheless, the nine lambs <b>that</b> were taken <b>with the dog are permitted</b> for sacrifice. The Gemara explains the objection: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>there is</b> retroactive <b>designation,</b> why are all ten lambs prohibited? <b>Let him select one of</b> the lambs <b>to correspond to the dog and take it</b> away, <b>and</b> all the rest of <b>these</b> lambs <b>should be permitted.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: If</b> this is referring to a case <b>where they are all equal</b> in value <b>to each other, indeed</b> one may consider only one of the lambs as corresponding to the dog. <b>Here, we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where they are not all equal</b> in value <b>to each other, but the value of this dog is one and</b> a small <b>amount</b> more than the value of each one of the ten lambs. Therefore, one cannot set aside a single lamb in exchange for the dog, <b>and</b> consequently one <b>draws this</b> extra small <b>amount,</b> i.e., the additional value of the dog, and divides it <b>between all of</b> the other nine lambs. As a result, all ten lambs are prohibited, since part of the price of a dog is included in each of them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All</b> cattle, sheep, and goats <b>enter the pen to be tithed, except for</b> an animal crossbred <b>from diverse kinds,</b> e.g., a hybrid of a goat and a sheep; <b>a <i>tereifa</i>;</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section;</b> one <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, i.e., that is younger than eight days old, which is when animals become eligible for sacrifice; <b>and an orphan. And what is an orphan?</b> It is <b>any</b> animal <b>whose mother died</b> or <b>was slaughtered</b> while giving birth to it <b>and thereafter</b> completed <b>giving birth</b> to it. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: Even if its mother was slaughtered but its hide exists</b> at birth, i.e., if the mother’s hide is present after the birth, <b>this is not an orphan.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> i.e., the fact that those animals are not included in the animal tithe, derived? The Gemara answers: <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that discusses offerings in general: “When a bull or a sheep or a goat is born, then it shall be seven days under its mother, but from the eighth day onward it may be accepted for an offering made by fire to the Lord” (Leviticus 22:27). The phrase <b>“a bull or a sheep”</b> serves to <b>exclude</b> an animal born <b>from diverse kinds; “or a goat”</b> serves to <b>exclude</b> an animal that <b>resembles</b> another, e.g., a sheep that is the offspring of two sheep but which looks like a goat, or vice versa; <b>“when…is born”</b> serves to <b>exclude</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section; “then it shall be seven days”</b> serves to <b>exclude</b> an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived; <b>“under its mother”</b> serves to <b>exclude an orphan.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: From where is it derived that these <i>halakhot</i> also apply to animal tithe? <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says</b> it is learned by a verbal analogy from the term “under.” It <b>is stated here,</b> with regard to animal tithe: “Whatever passes <b>under the rod”</b> (Leviticus 27:32), <b>and</b> it <b>is stated there,</b> with regard to all offerings: <b>“Under its mother”</b> (Leviticus 22:27). <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of all offerings, the verse serves to <b>exclude all these categories, so too here,</b> with regard to animal tithe, the verse serves to <b>exclude all these categories. And just as here,</b> with regard to animal tithe, the verse serves to <b>exclude a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> as the verse states: “Whatever passes under the rod,” and a <i>tereifa</i> is unable to pass unaided, <b>so too there,</b> with regard to all offerings, the verse serves to <b>exclude a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does the mishna’s expansive term: <b>All,</b> serve <b>to include?</b> The Gemara answers that it serves <b>to include this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>an animal that copulated with a person, or an animal that was the object of bestiality, or</b> an animal that was <b>set aside</b> for idol worship, <b>or</b> one that <b>was worshipped</b> as a deity, <b>or</b> one that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute <b>or</b> as the <b>price</b> of a dog, <b>or a <i>tumtum</i>,</b> i.e., an animal whose sexual organs are indeterminate, <b>or a hermaphrodite,</b> i.e., an animal displaying sexual organs of both sexes, <b>all of these enter the pen to be tithed</b> despite the fact that they are disqualified from being brought as offerings. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: A <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite do not enter the pen to be tithed.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> as for <b>the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna, <b>if he derives</b> the verbal analogy of: <b>“Under”</b> (Leviticus 27:32), and: <b>“Under”</b> (Leviticus 22:27), <b>from</b> the verse referring to <b>sacrificial</b> animals, then <b>these</b> types listed in the <i>baraita</i> should <b>also not</b> enter the pen to be tithed, as they are all disqualified from being sacrificed. <b>And if he does not derive</b> the verbal analogy from sacrificial animals, <b>from where</b> does he derive the exemption of <b>these</b> categories listed in the mishna, e.g., one whose time has not yet arrived and an orphan?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>tanna</i> does <b>derive</b> the verbal analogy, <b>but these</b> categories listed in the <i>baraita</i> <b>are included by the Merciful One</b> in the animal tithe. <b>As it is written</b> with regard to those animals that may not be brought as offerings: “Neither from the hand of a foreigner shall you offer the bread of your God of any of these, <b>because their corruption is in them, there is a blemish in them”</b> (Leviticus 22:25). This verse indicates that corruption is considered a blemish, <b>and the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Anywhere that</b> the term: <b>Corruption, is stated,</b> it <b>is</b> a reference to <b>nothing other than a matter of licentiousness and idol worship.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> supports this claim: Corruption is a reference to <b>a matter of licentiousness, as it is written</b> with regard to the generation of the flood: “And God saw the earth, and behold, it was corrupt; <b>for all flesh had corrupted their way upon the earth”</b> (Genesis 6:12). <b>And</b> corruption is also a reference to <b>idol worship, as it is written: “Lest you deal corruptly, and make you a graven image, the form of any figure, the likeness of male or female”</b> (Deuteronomy 4:16).
<b>And</b> the juxtaposition of the word “corruption” with the word “blemish” in Leviticus 22:25 teaches that in <b>any</b> case <b>where a blemish disqualifies</b> an animal, <b>a matter of licentiousness or</b> a matter of <b>idol worship also disqualifies it. And</b> in a case <b>where a blemish does not disqualify</b> an animal, <b>a matter of licentiousness or</b> a matter of <b>idol worship</b> also <b>does not disqualify it. And</b> with regard to <b>this</b> animal <b>tithe, since a blemish</b> on an animal <b>does not disqualify it, as it is written: “He shall not inquire whether it be good or bad, neither shall he change it”</b> (Leviticus 27:33), <b>a matter of licentiousness or</b> a matter of <b>idol worship also does not disqualify it.</b>
The Gemara further explains that the categories listed in the <i>baraita</i> are either matters of licentiousness or matters of idol worship. <b>An animal that copulated with a person and an animal that was the object of bestiality</b> are both <b>a matter of licentiousness.</b> An animal that was <b>set aside</b> for idol worship <b>and</b> one that <b>was worshipped</b> are cases of <b>idol worship. And</b> an animal that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute is <b>a matter of licentiousness, and</b> an animal used as the <b>price</b> of a dog <b>is juxtaposed to</b> an animal that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute (see Deuteronomy 23:19).
Finally, with regard to an animal that is <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that <b>it is uncertain</b> whether it is male or female, not a creature unto itself, and therefore a <i>tumtum</i> is also subject to the tithe.
The <i>baraita</i> states that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says</b> in the name of Rabbi Shimon: A <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite do not enter the pen to be tithed. The Gemara explains: <b>He holds that</b> the case of an animal that is a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite involves an <b>uncertainty,</b> and <b>the Merciful One excluded</b> cases of uncertainty <b>with regard to sacrificial</b> animals. Only <b>a definite male or a definite female</b> is fit to be sacrificed on the altar, <b>but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b> Consequently, with regard to animal <b>tithe too,</b> they do not enter the pen to be tithed, as he <b>derives</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“under”</b> and <b>“under” from sacrificial</b> animals.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All</b> animals <b>enter the pen to be tithed except for</b> an animal crossbred <b>from diverse kinds,</b> e.g., a hybrid of a goat and a sheep, <b>and a <i>tereifa</i>;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yehuda, of the village of Bartota, who said</b> it <b>in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua. Rabbi Akiva said: I heard from</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>that</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section and</b> an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, i.e., that is less than eight days old, <b>and an orphan</b> animal, are <b>also</b> excluded from animal tithe.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the first <i>tanna</i> of</b> the <i>baraita</i>, what does he maintain? <b>If he derives</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“under”</b> and <b>“under” from sacrificial</b> animals, then <b>these</b> categories listed by Rabbi Akiva should <b>also not</b> enter the pen to be tithed. <b>And if he does not derive</b> the verbal analogy, <b>granted,</b> he rules that <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> does not enter the pen to be tithed, as <b>it is written: “Whatever passes under the rod”</b> (Leviticus 27:32), which <b>excludes a <i>tereifa</i>, as it does not pass</b> under the rod due to its physical state. <b>But from where</b> does he derive that an animal crossbred <b>from diverse kinds</b> does not enter the pen to be tithed?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually, he does derive</b> the verbal analogy of “under” and “under,” and therefore he excludes a <i>tereifa</i> and diverse kinds from the animal tithe. <b>But</b> with regard to an animal <b>born by caesarean section</b>

Daf 57b

<b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> that a human child <b>born by caesarean section is a full-fledged offspring</b> and renders its mother ritually impure with the impurity of childbirth. Likewise, with regard to an animal born by caesarean section, he holds the birth was a proper birth and the animal may be brought as an offering, and therefore it also enters the pen to be tithed. <b>And</b> this is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who holds that Rabbi Shimon concedes that an animal born by caesarean section is disqualified from being brought as an offering (see <i>Nidda</i> 40a).
And <b>with regard to</b> an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, this <i>tanna</i> <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda,</b> who maintains that the obligation of animal tithe applies to such an animal. As for <b>an orphan</b> animal, he is referring to a case <b>where</b> the mother’s <b>hide exists</b> at birth, i.e., the mother’s hide is present after the birth, and therefore the animal is not considered an orphan. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> whose opinion this <i>tanna</i> follows, conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says: Even if its mother was slaughtered but its hide exists</b> at birth, i.e., if the mother’s hide is present after the birth, <b>this is not an orphan.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael ben Satriel, from</b> a place called <b>Arkat Leveina, testified before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: <b>In our locale,</b> if an animal dies while giving birth <b>they flay the dead</b> mother’s skin <b>and clothe the living</b> newborn animal with it for protection. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> This testimony of yours <b>reveals the reason for</b> the ruling of <b>the mishna</b> that if the hide of the mother still exists the offspring is not considered to be an orphan; the hide serves as a substitute for the mother.
Rabbi Yishmael ben Satriel also testified before Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>The lettuce in our locale has 600,000 leaves in its omasum,</b> i.e., in its core. Rabbi Yishmael ben Satriel further testified before Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>Once one cedar</b> tree <b>fell in our locale, and</b> it was so wide that <b>sixteen wagons passed over its back,</b> meaning the width of its trunk, as <b>one,</b> i.e., side by side.
Rabbi Yishmael ben Satriel also testified before Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>Once an egg of</b> the bird called <b><i>bar yokhani</i> fell, and</b> the contents of the egg <b>drowned sixty cities and broke three hundred cedar</b> trees. The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> the <i>bar yokhani</i> bird <b>throw</b> its eggs to the ground? <b>But isn’t it written: “The <i>kenaf renanim</i> bird rejoices,</b> but are her wings and feathers those of the stork? For she leaves her eggs on the earth, and warms them in dust” (Job 39:13–14)? The Sages understood that <i>kenaf renanim</i> is another name for the <i>bar yokhani</i> bird. If so, how could its egg fall if it lays its eggs on the ground? <b>Rav Ashi said</b> in explanation: <b>That</b> egg <b>was unfertilized,</b> and since it would never hatch the bird threw it to the ground.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There are <b>three</b> times during the year designated for <b>gathering</b> the animals that were born since the last date <b>for animal tithe: Adjacent to Passover, and adjacent to <i>Shavuot</i>, and adjacent to <i>Sukkot</i>. And those are the gathering</b> times <b>for animal tithe;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>Ben Azzai says</b> the dates are: <b>On the twenty-ninth of Adar, on the first of Sivan,</b> and <b>on the twenty-ninth of Av. Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say</b> that the dates are: <b>On the first of Nisan, on the first of Sivan,</b> and <b>on the twenty-ninth of Elul. And why did</b> Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon <b>say the twenty-ninth of Elul, and</b> why <b>did they not say the first of Tishrei?</b> It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the first of Tishrei <b>is</b> the <b>festival</b> of Rosh HaShana, <b>and one cannot tithe on a Festival. Consequently, they brought it earlier, to the twenty-ninth of Elul.</b>
<b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> The beginning of <b>the new year for animal tithe is on the first of Elul. Ben Azzai says:</b> The animals born in <b>Elul are tithed by themselves,</b> due to the uncertainty as to whether the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, i.e., that the new year begins on the first of Elul, or in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, which would mean that the new year begins on the first of Tishrei.
According to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, with regard to <b>all</b> animals <b>that are born from the first of Tishrei until the twenty-ninth of Elul, those</b> animals <b>join</b> to be tithed <b>together.</b> If <b>five</b> were born <b>before Rosh HaShana and five after Rosh HaShana,</b> those animals <b>do not join</b> to be tithed <b>together.</b> If <b>five</b> were born <b>before</b> a time designated for <b>gathering and five after</b> that time designated for <b>gathering, those</b> animals <b>join</b> to be tithed <b>together. If so, why were three</b> times <b>stated</b> for <b>gathering</b> the animals <b>for animal tithe?</b> The reason is <b>that until the</b> time designated for <b>gathering arrives</b> it is <b>permitted to sell and slaughter</b> the animals. Once <b>the</b> time designated for <b>gathering arrives one may not slaughter</b> those animals before tithing them; <b>but if he slaughtered</b> an animal without tithing it he is <b>exempt.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that there are three times during the year designated for gathering the animals born since the last date for animal tithe. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about these dates, i.e., why are there specifically <b>three</b> times designated in the year? <b>Rabba bar Sheila said:</b> There are three times in order <b>to collect</b> the animals born <b>early</b> in winter, <b>and</b> the animals born <b>later</b> in spring, <b>and</b> the animals born in the <b>summer.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is different about these</b> three <b>times,</b> i.e., before Passover, <i>Shavuot</i>, and <i>Sukkot</i>, that they are chosen? <b>Rabbi Tanḥum, son of Rav Ḥiyya, of the village of Akko, says:</b>

Daf 58a

The reason is <b>so that animals will be</b> readily <b>available to</b> those <b>ascending</b> to Jerusalem <b>for the pilgrimage Festivals.</b> The animals are tithed shortly before each of the Festivals so that their owners will refrain from selling or killing them until those times, when they gather them together to set aside the animal tithe. As a result, there are plenty of non-sacred animals ready to be sold, for food or offerings, to those on their way to Jerusalem.
<b>And even though we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>Until the</b> time designated for <b>gathering arrives,</b> it is <b>permitted to sell and slaughter</b> the animals, which means that there is no obligation to keep the animals until those dates and there is no concern that the owners will sell the animals before tithing them. This is because a person <b>prefers to perform a mitzva with his money,</b> by separating the animal tithe, <b>and</b> only <b>afterward sell or eat</b> those animals.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>call</b> the time designated for gathering animal tithe <b><i>goren</i>,</b> which literally means threshing floor? The Gemara explains that it is due to the fact <b>that</b> the arrival of this time <b>renders</b> the halakhic status of new animals like that of <b>untithed produce</b> gathered <b>on a threshing floor,</b> as from the time that produce is gathered on the threshing floor one becomes obligated to tithe it. Likewise, from this stage onward it is prohibited to slaughter the new animals until they have been tithed.
The mishna states that according to Rabbi Akiva the times for tithing animals are adjacent to Passover, <i>Shavuot</i>, and <i>Sukkot</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>And how much is adjacent [<i>peras</i>]? Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, explained</b> that the term <b>adjacent</b> means <b>not less than fifteen days.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is this <b>inferred? Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that the term <b><i>peros</i></b> means <b>half.</b> The Gemara inquires: <b>Half of what?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Half of</b> the time during which one must learn <b>the <i>halakhot</i> of Passover,</b> and this is <b>like that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One asks</b> about <b>and teaches the <i>halakhot</i> of Passover</b> for <b>thirty days before Passover. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> One begins studying those <i>halakhot</i> <b>two weeks</b> before the Festival.
§ The mishna states that <b>ben Azzai says</b> the times are <b>on the twenty-ninth of Adar, on the first of Sivan,</b> and on the twenty-ninth of Av. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do Rabbi Akiva,</b> who says fifteen days before Passover, <b>and ben Azzai,</b> who refers to the twenty-ninth of Adar, <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that the month of <b>Adar that</b> immediately <b>precedes Nisan is sometimes a full</b> month of thirty days <b>and sometimes a defective</b> month of only twenty-nine days. Therefore, <b>sometimes</b> the fifteenth day before Passover <b>occurs on the thirtieth</b> of Adar <b>and sometimes it occurs on the twenty-ninth</b> of Adar. <b>Due to that</b> reason Rabbi Akiva <b>does not fix a time</b> by date, but simply states fifteen days before Passover. <b>And ben Azzai holds</b> that the <b>Adar that</b> immediately <b>precedes Nisan is always defective. Therefore, he fixes a time</b> in the calendar that the animals must be tithed, which is <b>on the twenty-ninth of Adar.</b>
With regard to the fact that ben Azzai does not require fifteen days before <i>Shavuot</i> but maintains that the animals must be tithed on <b>the first of Sivan,</b> the reason is that <b>since</b> there are <b>not</b> so <b>many</b> animals born between the previous time of tithing and this one, <b>if you say that</b> the owner <b>should tithe earlier,</b> then <b>before the pilgrimage Festival arrives</b> all the animals will already be gone, their sales having been <b>completed.</b> If so, there will be no animals remaining for those coming to Jerusalem for <i>Shavuot</i>.
The mishna teaches that ben Azzai says the last gathering time is <b>on the twenty-ninth of Av,</b> rather than fifteen days before <i>Sukkot</i>. The Gemara notes that <b>ben Azzai</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he said: The</b> animals born <b>in Elul are tithed by themselves,</b> because it is uncertain whether the new year for animal tithes begins on the first of Tishrei or the first of Elul. Consequently, he sets the time for animal tithe before the beginning of Elul to avoid the possibility of tithing animals born in one year with animals born in the next year.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> him require that <b>one tithe</b> the animals <b>on the thirtieth day</b> of Av, which is the last day before Elul begins. The Gemara explains: <b>Sometimes</b> the month <b>of Av is defective,</b> i.e., it has only twenty-nine days, and therefore the thirtieth day after the start of Av is the first day of Elul. <b>And we are required to implement a distinction between the new</b> animals born in Elul <b>and the old</b> animals born in Av, which is considered to be the previous year.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say</b> that the times are <b>on the first of Nisan, on the first of Sivan,</b> and on the twenty-ninth of Elul. The Gemara explains with regard to the first date: <b>On the first of Nisan,</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who says</b> one begins studying and teaching the <i>halakhot</i> of Passover <b>two weeks</b> before the Festival. And Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon hold that the second time for animal tithe is <b>on the first of Sivan,</b> and this is <b>as we said</b> with regard to the opinion of ben Azzai, so that there will be enough animals born since the previous time.
Finally, they hold that the third time for animal tithe is <b>on the twenty-ninth of Elul,</b> since <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon</b> conform <b>to their</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as they say: On the first of Tishrei</b> is the <b>new year for animal tithe.</b> All animals born prior to that date belong to the previous year for tithe and are tithed as a single unit, whereas those born after that date belong to the next year for tithe, and therefore there is a distinction drawn between the new animals and the old.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And why did</b> Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon <b>say the twenty-ninth of Elul and</b> why <b>did they not say the first of Tishrei?</b> It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the first of Tishrei <b>is</b> the <b>festival</b> of Rosh HaShana and one cannot tithe on a Festival; consequently, they brought it earlier, to the twenty-ninth of Elul. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But let</b> the mishna <b>derive it</b> from the fact <b>that we require a distinction between the new</b> animals born in Tishrei <b>and the old</b> animals born in Elul, which is considered to be the previous year.
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>states one</b> reason <b>and</b> adds <b>another. One</b> reason is <b>that we require a distinction between the new</b> animals <b>and the old</b> animals. <b>And another</b> reason is <b>because it is</b> the <b>festival</b> of Rosh HaShana <b>and one cannot tithe on a Festival, due to the <i>sakreta</i>,</b> a lead-based red paint for marking every tenth animal, as explained on 58b. It is prohibited to apply paint on a Festival.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> The beginning of <b>the new year for animal tithe is on the first of Elul. Ben Azzai says:</b> The animals born in Elul are tithed by themselves, due to the uncertainty as to whether the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir or in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon. The Gemara notes that <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>ben Azzai said: Since these</b> Rabbis, Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, <b>say this,</b> that the first of Tishrei is the beginning of the new year for animal tithe, <b>and those,</b> i.e., Rabbi Meir, <b>say that</b> the first of Elul is the beginning of the new year for animal tithe, <b>the</b> animals born in <b>Elul are tithed by themselves.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But let</b> ben Azzai <b>see whose opinion</b> is more <b>reasonable,</b> and decide accordingly. <b>And if you would say</b> that <b>it is not possible</b> for him <b>to establish their reasoning,</b> that is difficult: <b>But it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>ben Azzai says: All the Sages of Israel appear to me</b> to be as unimpressive in their intellect <b>as garlic peel, except for this bald</b> one, i.e., Rabbi Akiva.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that ben Azzai was unable to establish their reasoning in this particular case, as <b>they said</b> their opinions <b>by tradition, from</b> a chain of transmission stretching back to <b>Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachi,</b> the last of the prophets. Each Sage claimed his tradition concerning their ruling was the correct one. Since this dispute is based on tradition, it cannot be resolved by logical reasoning.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what manner</b> did <b>ben Azzai say</b> that animals born in <b>Elul are tithed by themselves?</b> For example, if <b>five</b> animals <b>were born in Av and five</b> were born <b>in Elul, they do not combine</b> to make ten animals that require tithing. Likewise, if <b>five</b> were born <b>in Elul and five in Tishrei, they do not combine.</b> But if <b>five</b> were born <b>in Tishrei and five</b> were born <b>in</b> the following <b>Av, they do combine.</b>
The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious;</b> what is the novelty of the ruling of the <i>baraita</i>? The Gemara answers: This ruling is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>just as years separate</b> between animals that may be tithed together, so too, the designated times for <b>gathering</b> and tithing the animals <b>separate</b> between those animals born before and after each one of them. If so, animals born in Tishrei and those born in the following Av would not combine. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that these designated times do not prevent animals born before and after them from being tithed together.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>five</b> were born <b>before Rosh HaShana and five after Rosh HaShana,</b> those animals <b>do not combine</b> to be tithed; if <b>five</b> were born <b>before</b> the time designated for <b>gathering and five after</b> the time designated for <b>gathering, those</b> animals <b>combine</b> to be tithed.
<b>Rava says: According to the statement of ben Azzai,</b> if <b>five</b> animals <b>were born in Av and five</b> animals were born <b>in Elul and five</b> animals were born <b>in Tishrei,</b> the owner <b>gathers them</b> all <b>in a pen to be tithed,</b>

Daf 58b

<b>and he takes one of</b> the animals born <b>in Elul</b> as the tithe, <b>and the remainder are exempt, whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it. Rava explains: <b>If the new year</b> for animal tithe <b>is on the first of Elul,</b> then the animals born <b>in Elul and Tishrei combine</b> to form a total of ten, <b>and</b> the animals born <b>in Av are exempt,</b> as they are from the previous year and there are less than ten of them. <b>And if the new year is on the first of Tishrei,</b> the animals born <b>in Av and Elul combine</b> to form a total of ten, whereas the animals born <b>in Tishrei are exempt.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the opinion of Rava: <b>What are you saying?</b> Why are the five animals born in Tishrei exempt? <b>Let them combine</b> with animals at <b>another</b> time of <b>gathering</b> to form a total of ten. Rather, what is the reason one is not required to tithe these five animals born in Tishrei? It is because <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “And all the tithe of the herd or the flock, whatever passes under the rod, the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32), from which it is derived that <b>a definite tenth</b> must be tithed, <b>and not an uncertain tenth,</b> i.e., an animal that is not definitely the tenth. If the first of Elul is the new year, then the five born in Tishrei would have combined with the five of Elul and are exempt. Therefore, the obligation in this case is uncertain.
Rava said he takes one of the animals born in Elul as the tithe. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that he must take one of those animals, as those are the only ones concerning which the obligation is definite? The Gemara answers: It is necessary for Rava to specify this <b>lest you say</b> the Sages <b>should decree</b> that one should not even take one of the animals born in Elul as a tithe, as <b>perhaps he</b> might <b>come to take from those</b> that were born in Av or Tishrei by mistake. Therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that the Sages are not concerned about this error.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>In what manner does one tithe</b> the animals? <b>He gathers them in a pen and provides them with a small,</b> i.e., narrow, <b>opening, so that two</b> animals <b>will not be able to emerge together. And he counts</b> the animals as they emerge: <b>One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine; and he paints</b> the animal <b>that emerges tenth with red paint and declares: This is tithe.</b> Even if <b>he did not paint it with red paint, or if he did not count</b> the animals <b>with a rod</b> in accordance with the verse: “Whatever passes under the rod, the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32), <b>or if he counted</b> the animals when they were <b>prone or standing</b> in place and did not make them pass through a narrow opening, <b>these</b> animals <b>are tithed</b> after the fact.
But <b>if he had one hundred</b> animals <b>and he took ten</b> as tithe, or if he had <b>ten</b> animals <b>and he</b> simply <b>took one</b> as tithe, <b>that is not tithe,</b> as he did not count them one by one until reaching ten. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> In that case too, it is <b>tithe.</b> If before the owner completed tithing his animals, <b>one of</b> those already <b>counted jumped</b> back into the pen <b>among</b> the animals that had not yet been counted, <b>all those</b> in the pen <b>are exempt</b> from being tithed, as each of them might be the animal that was already counted. If one <b>of</b> those animals that had been <b>tithed,</b> i.e., designated as the tenth, jumped back into the pen <b>among</b> the animals that had not yet been counted, creating uncertainty with regard to all the animals there which was the animal tithe, <b>all</b> the animals <b>must graze until they become unfit</b> for sacrifice, <b>and</b> each of them <b>may be eaten in its blemished</b> state <b>by</b> its <b>owner</b> once it develops a blemish.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what manner does</b> one <b>tithe</b> his animals? <b>He gathers them in a pen and provides them with a small,</b> i.e., narrow, <b>opening so that two</b> animals <b>will not be able to emerge together. The mothers</b> of those animals stand <b>outside, and</b> the newborn animals to be tithed <b>are inside</b> the pen. <b>And</b> the mothers <b>bleat and</b> the young ones <b>emerge toward their mothers.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why is it performed this way? Let the owner simply <b>make them emerge</b> from the pen by pushing them. The Gemara answers that it is <b>written:</b> “Whatever <b>passes</b> under the rod, the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). This means that the animal must pass under the rod of its own volition, <b>and not that</b> one <b>will cause it to pass</b> by pushing it out of the pen.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not simply <b>throw</b> the animals <b>a vegetable</b> outside the pen, <b>and they will go out toward it</b> to eat it? <b>Rav Huna said:</b> The use of the mothers is a rabbinic <b>decree due to a purchased</b> animal <b>and due to an orphan,</b> i.e., a baby animal whose mother died before it was born. Neither of these animals is subject to tithing. Since neither a purchased animal nor an orphaned animal will have its mother outside calling to it, these animals will remain in the pen and will not be tithed accidentally.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“Whatever passes under</b> the rod, the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32); this teaches that all animals may be sanctified as animal tithe, <b>excluding a <i>tereifa</i>, as</b> on account of its physical state <b>it does not pass</b> under the rod. The phrase <b>“under the rod”</b> teaches that it is <b>a mitzva to count them with a rod. If one did not count them with a rod, or he counted them</b> when they were <b>prone or standing, from where</b> is it derived that the tenth animal is nevertheless sanctified? <b>The verse states: “The tenth shall be sacred,”</b> indicating that the tenth animal is sacred <b>in any case,</b> even if it was not tithed correctly.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And I have</b> derived <b>only that</b> an animal that <b>one</b> explicitly <b>called</b> by the <b>name of</b> the <b>tenth</b> one is the animal tithe. <b>From where</b> do I derive that the tenth animal is sanctified even if <b>one did not</b> explicitly <b>call</b> it <b>the tenth</b> one? <b>The verse states: “Shall be sacred.”</b> This teaches that it shall be sacred <b>in any case,</b> even if it was not called the tenth. One <b>might</b> have thought with regard to <b>one</b> who <b>had one hundred</b> animals <b>and</b> simply <b>took ten</b> of them without counting them, or one who had <b>ten</b> animals <b>and took one</b> of them without counting, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they should be</b> considered <b>tithed.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “The tenth,” and this</b> animal that he removed <b>is not the tenth,</b> as he did not count the animals. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> Even if he simply removed one animal from ten without counting, that animal is <b>tithe.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Elazar ben Gomel. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Abba Elazar ben Gomel says</b> with regard to the verse: <b>“And your <i>teruma</i> shall be reckoned to you</b> as though it were the grain of the threshing floor” (Numbers 18:27), that in using the plural form of the term “your,” <b>the verse speaks about two <i>terumot</i>. One is standard <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e. the grain of the threshing floor, <b>and</b> the other <b>one is <i>teruma</i> of the tithe.</b> The verse equates these two <i>terumot</i>.
Abba Elazar ben Gomel explains: <b>Just as standard <i>teruma</i> is taken by estimate,</b> as there is no requirement for the amount separated to be measured precisely, <b>and</b> it can be taken <b>by thought,</b> as one is not required to physically separate it before consuming the remaining produce,

Daf 59a

<b>so too, <i>teruma</i> of the tithe may be taken by estimate and by thought. And</b> this ruling of Abba Elazar ben Gomel’s also applies to tithes of the grain, because <b>the Merciful One calls tithe “<i>teruma</i>,” as it is written: “For the tithe of the children of Israel, which they set apart as <i>teruma</i> for the Lord, I have given to the Levites for an inheritance”</b> (Numbers 18:24). <b>And animal tithe is juxtaposed to grain tithe,</b> as is derived from the verse: “You shall tithe a tithe” (Deuteronomy 14:22; see 53b). <b>Just as grain tithe is separated by estimate and by thought, so too, animal tithe is separated by estimate and by thought.</b> For this reason, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, maintains that even with regard to an animal that was not counted, if it was separated as tithe the separation is valid.
<b>Rava says:</b> If one counted nine animals and the <b>tenth</b> animal remains in the pen, <b>it is sacred</b> as the animal tithe <b>of its own</b> accord, even if it does not leave the pen and was not counted. The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rava</b> derive <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>If we say</b> he derives it <b>from that which is taught</b> in the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>, this is problematic. The Gemara cites the <i>baraita</i> again: And <b>I have</b> derived <b>only that</b> an animal that <b>one</b> explicitly <b>called</b> by the <b>name of</b> the <b>tenth</b> one is the animal tithe. <b>From where</b> do I derive that the tenth animal is sanctified even if <b>one did not</b> explicitly <b>call</b> it <b>the tenth</b> one? <b>The verse states: “The tenth shall be sacred,”</b> i.e., it shall be sacred <b>in any case,</b> even if it was not called the tenth. The suggestion is that Rava understands from here that the tenth is sacred even if it was not counted, provided there was a counting. Consequently, it makes no difference whether or not the owner called it the tenth or left it in the pen.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>But perhaps</b> this <i>baraita</i> is referring specifically to a case where <b>he did not call</b> that animal the <b>tenth,</b> but <b>he did call it sanctified. Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests that Rava derives it <b>from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one</b> erred and <b>called the ninth</b> animal <b>the tenth, and the tenth</b> animal <b>emerged</b> from the pen <b>but</b> the owner <b>did not speak, the ninth</b> animal is not sanctified and is not brought as an offering. But since it was called the tenth, it may be <b>eaten</b> only once it develops <b>a blemish. And the tenth</b> animal is the animal <b>tithe.</b> It is possible that Rava maintains that just as the tenth is sacred in this case, when the owner remained silent, the same applies if he left it in the pen.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion as well: <b>But perhaps it is different there, as the tenth</b> animal <b>was selected</b> when it emerged from the pen, despite the fact that it was not counted verbally. <b>Alternatively,</b> the reason it is sanctified is <b>that he pointed at it</b> as it emerged, although he did not explicitly say that it was the tenth animal. Conversely, in a case where it remained in the pen perhaps it does not have any sanctity at all.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests that Rava derives his <i>halakha</i> <b>from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one</b> erred and <b>called the ninth</b> animal the <b>tenth, and</b> the <b>tenth</b> animal <b>died in the pen,</b> the <b>ninth</b> animal may be <b>eaten</b> only once it develops <b>a blemish, and all</b> the other animals <b>are exempt</b> from having to be tithed again. The Gemara clarifies this ruling: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>all</b> the other animals <b>are exempt?</b> Is it <b>not because</b> the <b>tenth</b> animal <b>is sanctified</b> of its own accord, even without emerging from the pen?
The Gemara rejects this suggestion as well: <b>But perhaps</b> the other animals <b>are exempt</b> because they were counted <b>in a tally that is fit</b> to reach ten. <b>As doesn’t Rava say: A tally fit</b> to reach ten <b>exempts</b> from the obligation of tithe? If one began counting lambs for the purpose of tithing and at that stage the group was fit to be tithed, but ultimately he was unable to separate the tithe, e.g., if one of the animals died and there were only nine left, those that were counted while the tally was fit to reach ten are exempt from being tithed. Moreover, the owner is not required to include them in the tithe on the following occasion.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests that Rava derives his <i>halakha</i> <b>from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one</b> erred and <b>called the ninth</b> animal the <b>tenth, and</b> the <b>tenth</b> animal <b>remained in the pen, the ninth</b> animal may be <b>eaten</b> only once it develops <b>a blemish, and the tenth</b> animal <b>is</b> the animal <b>tithe.</b> The tenth animal has sanctity even though it has not left the pen. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that in such a case the <b>ninth</b> animal <b>is non-sacred?</b>
<b>A <i>tanna</i> taught before Rav Sheshet:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this?</b> It <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b>

Daf 59b

<b>Even the ninth</b> that was accidentall y designated as the tenth <b>is not sanctified</b> and may be eaten before it develops a blemish, <b>unless the name of the tenth is removed from</b> the tenth animal, i.e., if the owner erred also in that he called the tenth animal the ninth. <b>And logical</b> reasoning <b>leads</b> to this conclusion.
The Gemara explains the logical reasoning: The <i>halakha</i> is that if one designated the ninth animal as the tenth, and the tenth as the tenth, and the eleventh as the tenth, then the eleventh is not consecrated. This is because in any situation where the name of the tenth was not removed from the tenth animal, the eleventh, which was called the tenth, is not consecrated. <b>And if the eleventh</b> animal, <b>which becomes sanctified to be sacrificed</b> as a peace offering, as stated in the mishna on 60a, <b>is sanctified only if the name</b> of the <b>tenth is removed from</b> the tenth animal, then with regard to the <b>ninth</b> animal, <b>which does not become sanctified to be sacrificed</b> but is eaten once it develops a blemish, <b>is it not logical that if the name</b> of the <b>tenth is removed from</b> the actual tenth animal, then <b>yes,</b> the ninth animal has sanctity and may be eaten only once it develops a blemish, <b>but if not,</b> then it is <b>not</b> sanctified at all and may be eaten even without a blemish?
The Gemara rejects this logical derivation: <b>That</b> claim itself <b>provides</b> support for the contrary opinion. With regard to <b>the eleventh</b> animal, <b>which becomes sanctified</b> with a stringent sanctity <b>to be sacrificed</b> as a peace offering, <b>if the name</b> of the <b>tenth is removed from</b> the actual tenth animal, then <b>yes,</b> the eleventh becomes sanctified, but <b>if</b> the designation of being the tenth is <b>not</b> removed from the tenth, then the eleventh does <b>not</b> become sanctified. But with regard to the <b>ninth</b> animal, <b>which does not become sanctified</b> with the stringent sanctity <b>to be sacrificed,</b> one can say that <b>even though the name of</b> the <b>tenth</b> animal <b>is not removed from</b> the tenth animal, nevertheless the ninth becomes sanctified.
<b>Alternatively,</b> there is another distinction between the two cases. With regard to the <b>eleventh</b> animal, <b>which</b> is sanctified only after the <b>tenth</b> animal has been <b>selected,</b> as it has emerged from the pen, one can claim that <b>if the name</b> of the <b>tenth is removed from</b> the tenth animal, then <b>yes,</b> the eleventh becomes sanctified, but <b>if</b> the name of the tenth is <b>not</b> removed from the tenth animal, the eleventh does <b>not</b> become sanctified.
But with regard to the <b>ninth</b> animal, <b>which</b> becomes sanctified at a time <b>when</b> the <b>tenth</b> animal <b>has not yet been selected,</b> as the tenth animal has not yet left the pen, if the owner accidentally designated that ninth animal as the tenth it becomes sanctified, <b>and</b> in such a case this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though the name</b> of the <b>tenth</b> animal <b>is not removed from</b> the actual tenth animal. The Gemara adds that there is <b>nothing more</b> to add to that explanation, and the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda in the name of Rabbi Shimon is rejected.
<b>Rava says: A tally fit</b> to reach ten <b>exempts</b> the animals that have been counted from being tithed. The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> does <b>Rava</b> derive <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>If we say</b> he derives it <b>from that which we learned</b> in the mishna, this is problematic. The Gemara cites the relevant statement of the mishna: If before one completed tithing his animals, <b>one of</b> those <b>counted jumped</b> back into the pen <b>among</b> the animals that were not yet counted, <b>all those</b> in the pen <b>are exempt</b> from being tithed, as each of them could be the animal that was already counted. The Gemara clarifies: With regard to this <i>halakha</i> concerning which the <b>counted</b> animals <b>themselves are exempt,</b> is it <b>not</b> because they were counted with <b>a tally fit</b> to reach ten?
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>But perhaps</b> this is referring to a case <b>where</b> the tenth animal also came out of the pen, and the owner <b>tithed</b> it <b>on behalf</b> of the others that were counted. If so, they are not exempt simply because they were counted with a tally fit to reach ten but because they were actually tithed.
The Gemara counters: <b>You cannot say</b> that the mishna is addressing a situation where one of the animals for which tithe had already been separated jumped back in, as the latter clause of the mishna <b>teaches:</b> If one <b>of</b> those animals that had been <b>tithed</b> jumped back into the pen <b>among</b> the animals that were not yet counted. This indicates that in the situation described in the first clause the animals had been counted but not yet tithed.
The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>But perhaps, what</b> is the meaning of the term: Animals that had been <b>tithed?</b> This is referring <b>specifically</b> to the tenth animal, which is the actual <b>tithe.</b> And accordingly, the language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches:</b> All the animals <b>must graze</b> until they become unfit for sacrifice, and thereafter they may be eaten in their blemished state by their owner. Concerning animal tithe, this <i>halakha</i> applies specifically to the tenth animal when it reentered the pen, and not to the other nine. Therefore, the Gemara has not yet found a source for Rava’s <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rather, Rava says the verse states:</b> “Whatever <b>passes</b> under the rod, the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). This indicates that only an animal that will pass under the rod must be tithed, <b>but not</b> an animal <b>that</b> has <b>already passed</b> under the rod. Rava elaborates: <b>What</b> it the meaning of: An animal <b>that</b> has <b>already passed? If</b> it means <b>that one has separated tithe for it, is it necessary</b> for a verse <b>to state</b> this? Of course an animal that has been tithed does not need to be tithed again. <b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the animals <b>have become exempt through a tally fit</b> to reach ten? <b>Conclude from this</b> that a tally fit to reach ten renders an animal exempt from being tithed.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava:</b> In a case where <b>one had ten lambs and he brought them into the pen and counted five, and</b> then <b>one of them died, if</b> one <b>of those</b> animals <b>that had been counted died, he</b> continues to <b>count and completes</b> the tithe <b>for them. But if</b> one <b>of</b> the animals <b>that had not been counted died,</b> those animals that had <b>been counted are exempt, and</b> those animals <b>that</b> had <b>not been counted combine</b> with animals born later, to be tithed <b>in another</b> designated time of <b>gathering.</b>
§ <b>And Rava says:</b> In a case where <b>one had fourteen lambs and brought them into the pen, and six</b> of the lambs <b>emerged</b> first, <b>through this opening</b> on one side of the pen, <b>and four</b> lambs emerged afterward <b>through that opening</b> on the other side of the pen, <b>and four</b> lambs <b>remained there, if those four</b> that remained came out <b>by the opening</b> through which <b>the six</b> lambs <b>emerged, he takes</b> the last <b>one of them</b> as animal tithe. <b>And the remainder,</b> i.e., the four that emerged through the other opening, <b>combine</b> with animals born later, to be tithed <b>in another</b> designated time of <b>gathering.</b>
<b>But if not,</b> i.e., if the last four remained in the pen or came out through the same opening through which the other four lambs emerged, then the <b>six</b> that emerged first <b>are exempt</b> from animal tithe, as they were part of a tally fit to reach ten; <b>and</b> the <b>four</b> that came out next, from the other opening, and the last <b>four, combine</b> with animals born later, to be tithed <b>in another</b> designated time of <b>gathering.</b>
Rava continues: In a case where <b>four</b> of the fourteen lambs <b>emerged</b> first, <b>through this opening</b> on one side of the pen, <b>and six</b> lambs came out afterward <b>through that</b> other <b>opening, and four</b> lambs <b>remained there, if those four</b> that remained come out <b>by the opening</b> through which <b>the six</b> lambs <b>emerged,</b> the owner <b>takes</b> the last <b>one of them</b> as animal tithe, <b>and the remainder,</b> i.e., the four that went out of the other opening, <b>are exempt,</b> as they were part of a tally fit to reach ten. <b>But if not,</b> i.e., if the last four emerge via the same opening as the first four, the <b>four</b> that came out first <b>and</b> the <b>six</b> that emerged through the other opening <b>are exempt,</b> as there were enough lambs left to complete the ten when all these left. <b>And</b> the <b>four</b> that went out last <b>combine</b> with animals born later, to be tithed <b>in another</b> designated time of <b>gathering.</b>
Rava continues: In a case where <b>four</b> of the fourteen lambs <b>emerged</b> first, <b>through this opening, and four</b> lambs came out afterward <b>through that</b> other <b>opening, and six</b> lambs <b>remained there, if those six</b> that remained come out <b>through</b> any <b>one opening, he takes one of them</b> as animal tithe, <b>and the remainder,</b> i.e., the four that went out of the other opening, <b>are exempt,</b> as they were part of a tally fit to reach ten. <b>But if not,</b> i.e., if the six remain in the pen, the <b>four</b> sheep that emerged on this side and the four that came out on that side <b>are exempt. And</b> the <b>six</b> that remain <b>combine</b> with animals born later, to be tithed <b>in another</b> designated time of <b>gathering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rava <b>teaching us?</b> Is he teaching <b>that</b> any animal that comes out of the pen as part of <b>a tally fit</b> to reach ten is <b>exempt? But didn’t Rava say</b> that already <b>once?</b> The Gemara answers: Rava’s statement is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that only if the animals emerge as part of <b>a tally</b> that is <b>definitely fit</b> to reach ten do <b>we say</b> they are exempt. But if they come out as part of <b>a tally</b> with regard to which it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it is <b>fit</b> to reach ten, such as in this case <b>where</b> the remaining animals <b>are fit to</b> come out <b>here and are fit to</b> come out <b>there,</b> and therefore the first animals might not be part of a counting that will reach ten, <b>we do not say</b> they are exempt. Therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that even a tally that is uncertain to reach ten exempts the animals from tithe.
§ <b>And Rava says:</b> If one <b>had fifteen lambs, he may not say: I will separate ten and bring them into the pen, and I will take one of them</b> as animal tithe, <b>and the rest</b> will be <b>exempt. Rather,</b> he must <b>bring</b> them all <b>into the pen, and remove ten</b> of them by causing them to emerge from the opening, <b>and take one of them,</b> i.e., the one that emerges tenth, as animal tithe. <b>And the remainder combine</b> with animals born later, to be tithed <b>in another</b> designated time of <b>gathering. This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>had fifteen lambs,</b>

Daf 60a

<b>he may not say: I will separate ten</b> and bring them into the pen, <b>and I will take one of them</b> as animal tithe, <b>and the rest</b> will be <b>exempt. Rather,</b> he must <b>bring</b> them all <b>into the pen and remove ten</b> of them by causing them to emerge from the opening, <b>and take one of them,</b> the tenth one, as animal tithe. <b>And the remainder combine</b> with animals born later, to be tithed <b>in another</b> designated time of <b>gathering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if one has <b>nineteen lambs he may not say: I will separate ten</b> and bring them into the pen, <b>and I will take one of them</b> as animal tithe <b>and the rest</b> will be <b>exempt; rather,</b> he must <b>bring</b> them all <b>into the pen and remove ten</b> of them by causing them to emerge from the opening, <b>and take one of them,</b> the tenth one, <b>and the remainder are exempt?</b> According to this <i>baraita</i>, the remainder are not combined with animals born later.
<b>Rav Huna bar Seḥora interpreted</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rava at</b> the time of the <b>Festival</b> discourse: <b>We are dealing with a pen that has two openings. And nine</b> of the lambs <b>emerged</b> through <b>this opening and nine</b> of them went out through <b>that opening, and this</b> last <b>one</b> remaining in the pen <b>is fit to</b> come out <b>here or to</b> come out <b>there.</b> Therefore, all the lambs emerged as part of a tally fit to reach ten.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let him teach</b> instead that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where he counted nine, and when the tenth</b> lamb <b>arrived</b> to be counted <b>he called</b> it number <b>one</b> and began counting again <b>from the start.</b> In such a case he designated only the nineteenth lamb that emerged as number ten, and therefore all the other lambs are exempt. The Gemara explains that Rav Huna bar Seḥora <b>holds</b> that the <b>tenth</b> animal to come out of the pen <b>is sanctified of its own</b> accord, even if it was designated as number one.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let him teach</b> instead that the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a case of a designated time for <b>gathering</b> the animals, and that the pen has only one opening, <b>but he counted them pair by pair,</b> i.e., he called the first pair number one, the second pair number two, and so on. In this manner, the nineteenth lamb would be designated as number ten and thereby exempt the others. The Gemara explains that Rav Huna bar Seḥora <b>holds</b> that the <b>tenth according to the number of animals is sanctified,</b> regardless of how he counts them. Accordingly, one of the fifth pair would be the tithed animal, and the remaining nine would not be considered part of a tally fit to reach ten.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> with regard to this incident: <b>The mother of Rav Huna bar Seḥora merited</b> to give birth to such a son, <b>who explained the <i>halakha</i></b> before Rava <b>at</b> the time of <b>the Festival</b> discourse <b>in accordance with</b> Rava’s <b>own <i>halakha</i>.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>two</b> animals <b>emerged as one, one counts them as twos,</b> i.e., as though they came out one after the other. If he mistakenly <b>counted</b> two of the animals at the beginning or in the middle of the ten as <b>one,</b> and then continued his count, the <b>ninth and</b> the <b>tenth are flawed,</b> as he called the tenth: Ninth, and he called the eleventh: Tenth.
If he mistakenly <b>called</b> the <b>ninth: Tenth, and</b> the <b>tenth: Ninth, and the eleventh: Tenth,</b> the <b>three of them are sacred,</b> although each has a different halakhic status. <b>The ninth is eaten in its blemished</b> state; <b>and the tenth is</b> animal <b>tithe,</b> which is sacrificed in the Temple and eaten by its owner; <b>and</b> the <b>eleventh is sacrificed as a peace offering,</b> from which the breast and the thigh are given to the priest. <b>And</b> the eleventh <b>renders</b> a non-sacred animal that is exchanged for the peace offering consecrated as <b>a substitute</b> and he sacrifices it as a peace offering; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> The eleventh animal itself, which he called tenth, is a substitute for animal tithe, <b>and does a substitute render</b> another animal <b>a substitute?</b> Everyone agrees that a substitute is created only in exchange for an originally consecrated animal. The Sages <b>said in the name of Rabbi Meir:</b> The eleventh animal is not considered a substitute for the animal tithe, since <b>if it were a substitute it would not be sacrificed,</b> as the substitute for an animal tithe is not sacrificed. If <b>one called the ninth</b> animal: <b>Tenth, and the tenth: Tenth, and the eleventh: Tenth, the eleventh is not consecrated. This is the principle:</b> In <b>any</b> situation <b>where the name</b> of the <b>tenth was not removed from</b> the tenth animal, the <b>eleventh</b> that was called the tenth <b>is not consecrated.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>counted</b> the animals <b>pair by pair,</b> i.e., he called the first pair: One, and the second pair: Two, and so on, or if one counted them <b>hundred [<i>kinteran</i>]</b> by <b>hundred,</b> the <b>tenth</b> according <b>to his number is sanctified.</b>
The Gemara asks: When Rabbi Yoḥanan says that the tenth is sanctified according <b>to his number, what</b> does he mean? <b>Rav Mari says: It is sanctified according to his counting,</b> i.e., all the animals in whichever pair or group he calls: Ten, are sanctified, e.g., the tenth pair, which consists of the nineteenth and twentieth animals. <b>Rav Kahana says: It is sanctified according to the number of animals,</b> regardless of how he designates them.
The Gemara cites support for Rav Mari’s opinion. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>two</b> animals <b>emerged as one, one counts them as twos.</b> If he mistakenly <b>counted</b> a pair of animals in the middle as <b>one</b> and continued his count, the <b>ninth and</b> the <b>tenth are flawed,</b> as he called the tenth: Ninth, and the eleventh: Tenth.
<b>Granted, according to the one who says: It is sanctified according to his counting,</b> i.e., Rav Mari, it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>the ninth and</b> the <b>tenth are flawed,</b> because the number by which one designates them is significant, <b>and he called the tenth</b> animal the <b>ninth, and the eleventh</b> he designated as <b>tenth. But according to the one who says</b> that the animal <b>is sanctified according to the number of animals</b> regardless of how the owner designates each one, i.e., Rav Kahana, why are they flawed? It should be considered as though <b>he called the ninth</b> animal the <b>ninth, and the tenth</b> animal <b>he called: Tenth.</b>
The Gemara answers that according to Rav Kahana, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said to you: When I said</b> the designation goes according to the animal I was referring only to a case <b>where he intended to take out</b> the animals <b>pair by pair,</b> and he did not err. In such a case his designation is nullified and the animals are sanctified in accordance with the order they left the pen. But with regard to a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>emerged by itself</b> and the owner miscounted I did <b>not</b> say the designation goes according to the number of the animal, as the Torah explicitly includes a case where the sanctification follows a mistaken designation (see 60b).
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof from a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>counted them backward,</b> i.e., ten, nine, eight, and so on, the <b>tenth</b> animal <b>in the numbering,</b> which he designated as number one, <b>is sanctified. Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the tithe <b>is sanctified according to the</b> number of <b>animals</b> regardless of how he designates each animal, i.e., Rav Kahana, this works out <b>well,</b> as the tenth animal is sanctified. <b>But according to the one who says it is sanctified</b> according <b>to his counting,</b> i.e., Rav Mari, why is the tenth animal sanctified? After all, <b>he called</b> the <b>tenth</b> animal number <b>one.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> The tenth animal is sanctified according to Rav Mari <b>because it</b> has been counted as number ten <b>in Persian counting, as they call the tenth</b> one in their language by the term <b>one,</b> i.e., they count only in units of ten, and call these units: One. Therefore, in this case there is no contradiction between the designation and the number of the animal.

Daf 60b
